THE RUSSIA-UKRAINE CONFLICT COULD END SOONER IF RUSSIA DID THESE 3 THINGS. (EPISODE 2/2)

3. Focus on strategy.

A good strategy will help to use expensive resources such as: People, money, technology ... economically and effectively.

A good strategy is like a flat road. If you have it, you have almost 50% chance of winning a race.

From the beginning, Ukraine had 2 extremely good strategies: Aid from the US, the West and the support of international law when Russia was the one who initiated the conflict.

Russia is on a rocky road, although it is a large country, it will also face many disadvantages if the conflict is prolonged.

In movies, a good soldier can dodge an incoming artillery shell. But in the actual recorded video. There is no chance of survival in such a situation. Therefore, the best way to master the battlefield is to calculate every step of the soldier in advance.

To be more specific, without a good strategy and plan, rushing into battle is like throwing yourself into a giant meat grinder. It is a meaningless sacrifice.

That makes having a good strategy even more important. If the president has a good strategy, the Department of Defense will have a good plan, the troops will have good steps.

There are principles to remember:

- The value of the head of the agency lies in the vision. To create good strategies, plans, and steps.

-The value of those who execute strategies and plans lies in their knowledge, skills, experience and absolute loyalty...

Never doubt this, because when a boat is drifting on a dark sea, the one who can help it escape is the one with the compass, not the best rower.

Russia, President Putin, and the Russian Ministry of Defense must find truly influential "compasses". Ignoring all principles, ranks, ages... As long as someone says they are confident that they can do well, why not let them try, in important moments, this will be the fastest, most direct way to find talent for the country.

Finally, from faraway Vietnam, I would like to send my best wishes to Russia to always be strong to overcome all obstacles.

#viral #trending #fyp #foryou #edit #russia #russian #moscow  #putin #vladimirputin #russiaukraineconflict

THE RUSSIA-UKRAINE CONFLICT COULD END SOONER IF RUSSIA DID THESE 3 THINGS. (EPISODE 1/2)

1. Reconsider the "shortcomings" in the special military operation in Ukraine.

The Russian government should review all activities related to the special operation in Ukraine from the beginning.

For example, the allocation of finances, personnel positions, or the effectiveness of combat plans... The Wagner mercenary force is also an activity with many "unknowns".

Reviewing and handling the "shortcomings" that can affect the combat effectiveness of the Russian army will reaffirm the prestige of the Russian government, build trust, and fill the army with more fighting enthusiasm.

2. Always be fair to the soldiers.

Modern soldiers, what do they fight for? For the duty of a soldier? Or for the glory of the motherland?... All of these are correct, but...

A country of more than 140 million people. But only 500,000 people are actually sacrificing for the benefit of the country, while the remaining 140 million people are safe and working for their own benefit.

Looking back at history, soldiers used to consider sacrificing for the country as glorious, because in their society at that time, almost no one worked for personal benefit.

Whether on the front line or inside the country. All soldiers and civilians are contributing to the ideal of the motherland with everything they have. It is very fair, no one has to regret.

But today is different. Because we are living in a capitalist era. When the war is over, soldiers will have to face the pressure of life like ordinary people. That is why developed countries always pay appropriately for each soldier who goes to war.

In short, regardless of the era, social justice is the key to creating strength. Russian soldiers must have it.

रूस-यूक्रेन संघर्ष, जो 2014 में शुरू हुआ था, यूक्रेन के पश्चिमी समर्थक राजनीतिक बदलाव के बाद रूस द्वारा क्रीमिया पर कब्ज़ा करने के बाद बढ़ गया। अंतर्राष्ट्रीय समुदाय द्वारा व्यापक रूप से निंदा किए जाने के बाद, रूस समर्थित अलगाववादियों ने पूर्वी यूक्रेन के कुछ हिस्सों पर कब्ज़ा कर लिया, जिससे डोनबास क्षेत्र में युद्ध छिड़ गया।

फरवरी 2022 में, रूस ने यूक्रेन पर पूर्ण पैमाने पर आक्रमण किया, जो एक महत्वपूर्ण वृद्धि को दर्शाता है। रूस ने सुरक्षा चिंताओं और नाटो के पूर्व की ओर विस्तार को औचित्य के रूप में उद्धृत किया, जबकि यूक्रेन और उसके सहयोगियों ने इसे संप्रभुता पर एक अकारण हमला माना।

संघर्ष ने व्यापक तबाही, मानवीय संकट और वैश्विक आर्थिक व्यवधानों को जन्म दिया है। दोनों पक्षों को भारी नुकसान के बावजूद, यूक्रेन ने कुछ क्षेत्रों को पुनः प्राप्त करते हुए मजबूत प्रतिरोध किया है। पश्चिमी देशों, विशेष रूप से नाटो सदस्यों ने रूस के खिलाफ सैन्य सहायता और प्रतिबंधों के साथ यूक्रेन का समर्थन किया है।

2024 तक, संघर्ष जारी है, कूटनीतिक प्रयास स्थायी युद्धविराम बनाने में विफल रहे हैं, जिससे क्षेत्र अनिश्चितता की स्थिति में है।

#RussiaUkraineConflict #UkraineWar #EasternEuropeCrisis #GlobalTensions #RussiaInvasion #UkraineResistance #NATO #WarInDonbas #Geopolitics #peaceinukraine

The Russia-Ukraine conflict, which began in 2014, escalated after Russia annexed Crimea, following Ukraine’s pro-Western political shift. The annexation, widely condemned by the international community, was followed by Russian-backed separatists seizing parts of eastern Ukraine, sparking a war in the Donbas region.

In February 2022, Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, marking a significant escalation. Russia cited security concerns and NATO’s eastward expansion as justification, while Ukraine and its allies saw it as an unprovoked attack on sovereignty.

The conflict has led to widespread devastation, a humanitarian crisis, and global economic disruptions. Despite heavy losses on both sides, Ukraine has mounted strong resistance, reclaiming some territories. Western countries, particularly NATO members, have supported Ukraine with military aid and sanctions against Russia.

As of 2024, the conflict remains ongoing, with diplomatic efforts failing to produce a lasting ceasefire, leaving the region in a state of uncertainty.

#RussiaUkraineConflict #UkraineWar #EasternEuropeCrisis #GlobalTensions #RussiaInvasion #UkraineResistance #NATO #WarInDonbas #Geopolitics #peaceinukraine

As the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) annual session concluded, China and Brazil convened a 17-member meeting to garner support for their peace plan regarding the ongoing Ukraine war. Since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, which is the largest conflict in Europe since World War II, global relations and economics have been significantly altered, disrupting supply chains and food security worldwide. This meeting aims to address these challenges and promote a diplomatic solution to the conflict.

Putin’s Latest Statements on Ukraine, Nuclear Policies, and Military Expansion

🛑 Nuclear Strike Threshold Lowered
Putin has lowered the threshold for using Russia’s nuclear arsenal, signaling that any conventional attack on Russia, if supported by a nuclear power, could be considered a joint nuclear attack ⚡. He also issued a NATO warning, stating that if Ukraine uses long-range missiles supplied by the West, NATO countries are essentially “fighting with Russia” 💥.

💣 Military Actions & Defense Expansion

 • 🔼 Troop Increase: Putin ordered an increase of 180,000 troops 🪖, making Russia’s army the second largest in terms of active combat soldiers, right behind China.
 • 📈 Defense Budget Surge: Russia’s defense budget will rise by 25%, reaching a record high 💰. This expansion aims to reinforce Russia’s military capabilities in the ongoing Ukraine conflict 🇷🇺⚔️.

🤝 Strategic Alliances

 • Putin praised Russia’s cooperation with OPEC+ ⛽ and BRICS 🌍, highlighting these partnerships as crucial for countering Western influence and strengthening Russia’s geopolitical stance amid increasing tensions.

These updates come from a series of recent statements during key meetings, including the UN Security Council 🏛️ and ongoing discussions about Russia’s military and global strategy 🛡️.

Reports have emerged of two Chinese nationals, allegedly serving as mercenaries for Russia, being killed in Ukraine. According to social media posts, including one from the X (formerly Twitter) account PS01△, the Ukrainian Armed Forces reportedly killed the two men, who were described by Russian pro-war sources as "Sprite" and "Cola." Despite many foreign fighters being involved in Russia’s invasion of Ukraine since 2022, there has been no confirmed evidence of Chinese nationals participating in combat until now. The reports remain unverified, with Newsweek unable to independently confirm the claims.

Ukrainian Drone Operator Shows Mercy to Wounded Russian Soldier

Watch the incredible 18-minute video of a Ukrainian drone operator sparing the life of a wounded Russian soldier in eastern Ukraine's Donbas region ¹.

The drone footage, set to an ominous tune, shows the soldier surviving two attempts on his life before the operator decides to help him to safety.

A Stunning Turn of Events

After dropping five lethal grenades, the drone controller returns to find the Russian soldier begging for his life.

The Ukrainian operator takes pity on the injured soldier, dropping off water and instructions to reach Ukrainian lines.

A Perilous Journey

The Russian soldier, exhausted and battered, makes his way through No Man's Land, guided by the Ukrainian drone.

He even takes a cigarette break before continuing, lying in a crater for a few minutes.

A Remarkable Act of Humanity

The Ukrainian drone leads the soldier to safety, where he's met by two infantrymen who march him to their command post.

This remarkable footage is believed to be part of the K-2 Battalion's recruitment efforts [1).

Share Your Thoughts!

What do you think about this incredible act of mercy?

In a significant move, Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the U.S. for the third time in three months, discussing the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict. PM Modi reiterated India's stance for a diplomatic and peaceful solution, emphasizing the impact of the war on developing nations. While India supports efforts for peace, PM Modi remained cautious about hosting a peace conference unless both Russia and Ukraine participate.

“LIMITING” NATO'S POWER
When will Nato stop provoking Russia?

According to Russia's assessment. Will Nato's actions in Ukraine lead to a direct confrontation with Russia? Nato itself is a group of European military powers, they have enough capacity to calculate all the consequences when that happens.

The reason they continue to provoke Russia is because they know the “limit” of their military strength, they know that Russia's military capacity without using nuclear weapons cannot defeat Nato.

There will be no other way. To end all threats from the West. Russia will have to push its military capacity to be on par with Nato. Let's leave nuclear weapons out of the race. Russia's strength exists within itself. That strength once helped the Soviet Union defeat Nazi Germany.

Russia is aiming to return to the world's leading position as the Soviet Union once was. Therefore, a future military capacity equal to, or greater than, Nato is necessary.

"रूस-यूक्रेन संघर्ष: कालक्रम और संभावित समाधान"
 रूस-यूक्रेन संघर्ष, जो 2014 में शुरू हुआ, फरवरी 2022 में तेज हो गया जब रूस ने यूक्रेन पर पूर्ण पैमाने पर आक्रमण शुरू किया। संघर्ष की जड़ें सोवियत संघ के पतन से जुड़ी हैं, जहां यूक्रेन पश्चिम के साथ घनिष्ठ संबंध बनाना चाहता था, जबकि रूस का लक्ष्य अपने पूर्व क्षेत्रों पर प्रभाव बनाए रखना था। जब रूस ने क्रीमिया पर कब्ज़ा कर लिया और पूर्वी यूक्रेन में अलगाववादी आंदोलनों का समर्थन किया तो तनाव बढ़ गया। कालानुक्रमिक रूप से, युद्ध में कई युद्धविराम और शांति वार्ता विफल हो गईं, जिससे व्यापक तबाही, बड़े पैमाने पर विस्थापन और वैश्विक आर्थिक व्यवधान, विशेष रूप से ऊर्जा और खाद्य आपूर्ति में व्यवधान हुआ। इस संघर्ष ने अंतरराष्ट्रीय अभिनेताओं को आकर्षित किया है, जिसमें नाटो और यूरोपीय संघ यूक्रेन का समर्थन कर रहे हैं, जबकि रूस को प्रतिबंधों का सामना करना पड़ रहा है। एक संभावित समाधान बातचीत के जरिये समाधान में निहित है जो रूस की सुरक्षा चिंताओं को संबोधित करते हुए यूक्रेन की संप्रभुता का सम्मान करता है। कूटनीतिक प्रयास, अंतर्राष्ट्रीय मध्यस्थता और बातचीत के माध्यम से विश्वास का पुनर्निर्माण युद्धविराम का मार्ग प्रशस्त कर सकता है, जिससे अंततः युद्ध कम हो सकता है।

World on Edge: The Threat of World War III? 🚀

Reported by @firstpost , The world is witnessing a significant escalation in the Ukraine conflict as Russia delivers a chilling warning to the West. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has cautioned that allowing Ukraine to launch deeper strikes into Russian territories is akin to "playing with fire" 🔥. Lavrov’s statement, invoking the threat of nuclear retaliation, underscores the gravity of the situation.

With Ukraine urging for more aggressive measures, the possibility of deeper strikes inside Russia has ignited fears of a broader conflict. Lavrov warned that World War III, if it were to occur, wouldn’t be limited to Europe but would have catastrophic global consequences. 🌐

This isn’t the first time Russia has raised the specter of nuclear conflict during the ongoing war. Russian leaders, including President Vladimir Putin, have repeatedly reminded the world that the use of nuclear weapons is not off the table. Dmitry Medvedev, another key Russian figure, has also emphasized that any attack on Russian soil could trigger a devastating response beyond Ukraine’s borders.

As tensions escalate, the international community is on high alert. Are we inching closer to a global conflict? The world watches with bated breath.

A Catholic Reverend father has been ousted by Police authorities for lying to donors after he raised at least $650,000 for overseas medical clinics he claimed to operate, but in reality used the donations to fuel an extravagant lifestyle that included ‘heavenly’ meals, trips to the Hamptons and plastic surgery.

Pawel Bielecki, known as “Father Paul,” claimed he ran medical clinics in war-torn Lebanon, meanwhile he was 5,600 miles away in Manhattan, New York..

“Bielecki exploited his position as a friar to gain the trust of victims across the country and steal hundreds of thousands of dollars from them,” said Damian Williams, US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, which collared the clergyman on Aug. 17 on charges of wire and mail fraud.
 
For eight years, the priest allegedly preyed on the compassionate members of his flock, soliciting donations on local radio shows and crowdfunding websites for non-existent Lebanese hospitals and ambulances, authorities said.

The cleric allegedly exploited the horrific August 4, 2020 chemical explosion in Beirut, which killed 218 people to fill his wallet, claiming he was hurt in the attack.

But prosecutors said he wasn’t even there and “made several purchases at coffee shops, restaurants and other businesses” in Manhattan on the day of the disaster.

In a historic visit that marks a significant moment in global diplomacy, Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in Kyiv, becoming the first Indian Prime Minister to visit Ukraine since its independence. This visit comes at a crucial time as Ukraine faces ongoing conflict with Russia, and the world looks on in concern.
During his visit, PM Modi engaged in one-on-one and delegation-level talks with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, focusing on finding a peaceful and negotiated resolution to the conflict that has not only devastated Ukraine but also impacted global stability. Both leaders emphasized the importance of dialogue and diplomacy in resolving such critical issues.
President Zelenskyy, expressing his gratitude, described the meeting as "historical," underscoring that it was about the nations and their people rather than individual leaders. The discussions highlighted the shared values of democracy, sovereignty, and the right to peaceful coexistence.
PM Modi's visit is a testament to India's commitment to global peace and its willingness to play a constructive role in resolving international conflicts. This visit also reflects India's balanced foreign policy, seeking to foster peaceful solutions through dialogue while maintaining strong bilateral ties.
As the world watches, the outcomes of this meeting may have far-reaching implications for the ongoing conflict and the broader international community's approach to peace and security.

Ukraine has launched one of its largest drone attacks on Moscow, as it presses on with a major incursion into Russia’s Kursk region, Russian authorities said.

Russia’s Ministry of Defence said on Wednesday that air defence forces shot down 11 drones over Moscow and its surrounding region, with some reportedly downed over the city of Podolsk some 38km (24 miles) south of the Kremlin.

“This is one of the largest ever attempts to attack Moscow with drones,” Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin said on the Telegram messaging app. No damage or casualties were reported, he said in an earlier post.

Drone attacks on Moscow are rare. Ukraine’s latest attempt to target the Russian capital appeared to be larger than a previous attack in May 2023, when at least eight drones were struck down.

Wednesday’s barrage was part of a broader attack on Russia, with the Defence Ministry saying its air defence units destroyed 45 Ukrainian drones in total overnight.

In addition to the 11 drones destroyed over the Moscow region, 23 drones were downed in the border region of Bryansk, six in the border region of Belgorod, three in the Kaluga region, which borders the Moscow region to its northeast, and two in the embattled Kursk region, the ministry said.

US Targets Over 400 Entities in New Sanctions Against Russia

The US imposed sanctions on over 400 entities and individuals for aiding Russia’s war in Ukraine. This includes Chinese firms suspected of helping Russia evade Western sanctions and build its military. The new measures target companies involved in shipping machinery and microelectronics to Russia, as well as networks involved in procuring military supplies. The sanctions also add 123 entities to the US export control list. Ukrainian President Zelenskiy welcomed the sanctions, emphasizing their importance in weakening Russia’s war efforts.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has visited the border areas in the Sumy region from which his forces staged a major offensive into Russia’s Kursk region this month.

The president said on Thursday that he had met Oleksandr Syrskii, commander-in-chief of the army, receiving reports on the “operational situation across all active combat zones”, in a video posted on social media platform X.

The Ukrainian army’s surprise incursion into Kursk on August 6 saw it take control of dozens of settlements, forcing tens of thousands of civilians to flee and taking hundreds of prisoners captive.

Zelenskyy said Ukraine had “replenished the exchange fund”, a reference to the capture of Russian soldiers who could be exchanged for Ukrainian prisoners of war held by Moscow.

Ukrainian officials have said the goals of the offensive included creating a “buffer zone” on Russian territory, seeking an end to the war on “fair” terms and stretching Russian forces.

In his statement on Thursday, the president said there had been a decrease in shelling and civilian casualties in Sumy since the Kursk operation.

The governor of Russia’s Belgorod region on Ukraine’s northern border has declared a regional state of emergency blaming relentless bombardment by Ukraine.

“The situation in the Belgorod region continues to be extremely difficult and tense,” Vyacheslav Gladkov said in a video posted on the Telegram messaging app.

Daily shelling by Ukraine’s armed forces had destroyed houses, and had killed and injured civilians, he added.

“Therefore, we are making a decision, starting today, to declare a regional emergency situation throughout the Belgorod region … with a subsequent appeal to the government to declare a federal emergency situation.”

Gladkov’s announcement comes as Russia battles to push back Ukrainian forces in neighbouring Kursk after thousands of soldiers launched a surprise assault across the border in the early hours of August 6.

Russia Launches Operation; Basically Grounded But With Tanks
*
Russia has imposed a "counter-terrorism operation" in three regions to halt a Ukrainian incursion. Now, authorities in Kursk, Belgorod, and Bryansk can restrict movement and tap phones.

This after Ukrainian troops advanced 10km into Russia, the deepest since the invasion in February 2022.

Russia's National Counter-Terrorism Committee says it's to ensure public safety. Powers include home entry, traffic control, and electronic monitoring.

76,000 have been evacuated from Kursk. Up to 1,000 Ukrainian troops have reportedly seized multiple villages and threaten Sudzha town.

A video shows armed Ukrainians at Sudzha's Gazprom facility, confirmed by BBC Verify. Another video shows a damaged Russian convoy near Oktyabrskoe.

Russia sent reinforcements, including tanks and rocket systems. Moscow claims to be repelling the invasion, but these claims are unverified.

As fighting nears Kursk nuclear plant, the UN urges "maximum restraint" to avoid a nuclear accident.

Russian Dissidents Refuse to Sign Putin's "Sorry We Got Caught" Petition
*
In a plot twist worthy of a spy novel, two Russian dissidents, Vladimir Kara-Murza and Ilya Yashin, were released in a prisoner swap but refused to sign a mercy petition to Putin. During a Germany press conference, they vowed to return home, stressing their opposition to Putin's war in Ukraine. The swap also freed US journalist Evan Gerschkovich and ex-Marine Paul Whelan, while convict assassin Vadim Krasikov got a get-out-of-jail-free card. The dissidents pledged to fight for a free Russia and criticized the ethics of the swap. Kara-Murza, who was held in solitary for over 10 months, likened his release to a surreal movie. Yashin, still longing to return to Russia, acknowledged that his presence complicates further negotiations. Sasha Skochilenko echoed the surreal experience, ecstatic to reunite with family. They paid tribute to the late critic Alexei Navalny, asserting Putin's direct role in his death, and insisted that Russia deserves better than a "corrupt KGB dictator."

The first batch of long-awaited F-16 jets have arrived in Ukraine, Lithuania’s foreign minister and a United States official have said, an effort Kyiv has said will help rebuild its depleted air force.

Ukraine has been eager to acquire F-16s, built by Lockheed Martin, because of their destructive power and global availability.  The fighter jet is equipped with a 20mm cannon and can carry bombs, rockets and missiles.

“F-16s in Ukraine. Another impossible thing turned out to be totally possible,” Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis wrote on X on Wednesday.

A US official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that the delivery had been completed. The Ukrainian government has not confirmed receipt of the jets.

Ukraine has been pushing its Western allies for F-16s for months, saying they were critical in fighting back against the onslaught of missiles Russia has fired against it. The West has moved haltingly towards providing the jets, after previous concerns that arming Ukraine with advanced weaponry would further escalate the war with Russia.

The US has also been training Ukrainian pilots on how to fly the jets and has already graduated the first group of pilots on its operation.

“JUST LET HIM DO WHAT HE WANTS”

Because that is the most pleasant way for the Russia-Ukraine conflict to end peacefully through negotiations.

Efforts from major countries can partially contain the heat of the conflict.

But it would be better if the negotiation took place voluntarily on both sides.

The reason why the Ukrainian side, despite the losses they are facing, rejected negotiations on Russia's terms is because. 

Mr. Zelensky believes: The Ukrainian side has not yet tried to do everything possible to save the situation, and they will regret it if they surrender to Russia early while there is still a chance to regain territory, even if it is the smallest.

So, let him do what he wants.

From the first Swiss summit, to the second Ukrainian peace conference.

Mr. Zelensky can hold the summit many more times. But please be patient, let him try to do everything he can for Ukraine.

Give him a chance so he won't regret it later.

Give him time to realize that for himself. Only the path of negotiation on Russia's terms can bring peace to the two countries.

And only negotiations that take place voluntarily can completely resolve the conflict hidden deep in the hearts of both sides.

So, just let him do what he wants.

On March 6, Russia fired a missile into the Ukrainian port of Odesa that exploded about 400 metres (1,300ft) from where Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was preparing to tour the city with Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis.

“As we were getting into our cars, we heard a large explosion,” Mitsotakis later told reporters. “We were all concerned, especially if you consider that we were in an open space with no cover. It was quite savage.”

Many Western leaders have visited Zelenskyy, but this was the only occasion when there was a plausible threat to their life and safety. Analysts in Athens do not believe it was an accident.

“It was a message to Greece, a message to the Russophilic portion of Greek society,” said Konstantinos Filis, a professor of international relations who directs the Institute of Global Affairs at the American College of Greece.

That Russophilic population is dropping dramatically.

According to Dianeosis, an Athens-based think tank, about 70 percent of Greeks had a favourable view of Russia before the full-blown war in Ukraine. That fell to 50 percent after the 2022 invasion and to 30 percent last year.

Russia has suffered multiple diplomatic and judicial blows during the past week over its war on Ukraine, despite President Vladimir Putin’s high-profile visits to North Korea and Vietnam and Moscow’s claims that it is founding a “Eurasian security architecture that will replace the discredited Euro-Atlantic security arrangements”.

Putin signed a “comprehensive strategic treaty” with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 19, incorporating what he said was a defensive alliance. South Korea’s government condemned the agreement. Its national security adviser, Chang Ho-jin, declared that Seoul would reconsider lifting a ban on arms supplies directly to Ukraine. Until now, South Korea has only sold weapons to Ukraine’s allies.

Chang later added that the type of weapons supplied to Ukraine would depend on Russia’s cooperation with North Korea. Putin said it would be a “grave mistake” if South Korea changed its policy of not supplying belligerents.

Russia also suffered judicial embarrassments. The International Criminal Court at The Hague issued arrest warrants on Tuesday for former Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of Military Staff Valery Gerasimov, saying that they bore responsibility for attacks on Ukrainian electricity infrastructure. The court said, “There are reasonable grounds to believe that the alleged strikes were directed against civilian objects,” and that “the expected incidental civilian harm and damage would have been clearly excessive to the anticipated military advantage.”

United States President Joe Biden has eased a ban on Ukraine using US weapons inside Russian territory to help the country defend its northeastern Kharkiv region from attack.

Several US officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, told multiple media outlets on Thursday that Kyiv would be allowed to use the weapons on the border of the Kharkiv region which came under renewed Russian attack earlier this month.

The US decision, which has predictably angered Kremlin officials, marks a policy shift by Biden who had refused to let Kyiv use US weapons beyond Ukraine’s borders, and comes as France and other European countries indicated Ukraine would be allowed to use their weapons on military targets inside Russia.

Kyiv will be authorised to strike military targets on the border with the Kharkiv region, where Russia has overrun a number of villages since May 10, forcing the evacuation of thousands of residents.

“The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,” a US official told the Reuters, AFP and The Associated Press news agencies. The change was first reported by online media outlet Politico.

In a decisive statement, Defense Minister Boris Pistorius emphasized the urgent need for Germany to bolster its armed forces, the Bundeswehr, to achieve full operational readiness before the decade's end. His comments come amid rising concerns over European security following Russia's extensive invasion of Ukraine.

Speaking during a session in the Bundestag, Germany's lower house of parliament, Pistorius stressed the necessity for preparedness. "We must be ready for war by 2029," he declared, underscoring the importance of deterrence to prevent potential conflicts. Pistorius highlighted that achieving this goal hinges on securing adequate finances, materials, and personnel.

"In an emergency, we need strong young women and men who can defend this country," he said, advocating for a new form of military service. He noted that this service model "cannot be completely free of obligations," reflecting his belief in the essential role of conscription in national defense.

Pistorius, affiliated with Chancellor Olaf Scholz's center-left Social Democrats, has tasked his ministry with exploring various models for reintroducing military conscription. Germany had suspended compulsory military service in 2011. Recent surveys, such as one conducted by research institute Forsa in March, indicate that about half of German citizens support its reinstatement.

The United States has announced a new $275 million military aid package for Ukraine to help defend against Russia’s assault on Kharkiv. This aid includes ammunition for HIMARS, artillery rounds, missiles, anti-armor systems, and precision aerial munitions. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken emphasized the importance of quickly delivering this aid to support Ukraine's military efforts.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy recently visited Kharkiv, reporting progress in regaining control of northern border areas. In contrast, Russian officials claim control over parts of Vovchansk, illustrating the ongoing conflict.

Russia's intensified attacks on Kharkiv have prompted the evacuation of children and over 11,000 residents since May 10. The destruction of the train network further strains Ukraine’s defenses. President Zelenskyy has called for more air defense systems from Western allies, highlighting the urgency of additional support.

Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said he is pushing partners to get more directly involved in the war by helping to intercept Russian missiles and allowing his country to use Western weapons against military equipment amassing near the border.

“It’s a question of will, but everyone says a word that sounds the same in every language: everyone is scared of escalation,” the 46-year-old leader told the Reuters news agency in Kyiv on Monday.

“Everyone has gotten used to the fact that Ukrainians are dying – that’s not escalation for people,” he said.

Zelenskyy proposed that the armed forces of neighbouring NATO countries could intercept incoming Russian missiles over Ukrainian territory to help Ukraine protect itself.

Russia has fired thousands of missiles and drones at Ukraine since the start of its invasion in 2022 and launched an assault in the northeastern border region of Kharkiv on May 10 that resulted in their biggest territorial gains in a year and a half.

“Russians are using 300 planes on the territory of Ukraine. We need at least 120-130 planes to resist in the sky,” Zelenskyy said, again calling on Western allies to supply with additional air defence systems. Ukraine is waiting for the delivery of US-designed F-16 fighter jets.

Russian forces have started the first stage of exercises ordered by President Vladimir Putin to simulate preparation for the launch of tactical nuclear weapons, the Defence Ministry said on Tuesday.

Moscow has linked the exercises to what it calls “militant statements” by Western officials, including French President Emmanuel Macron, which it said created security threats for Russia.

Nuclear analysts say the exercises are designed as a warning signal by Putin to deter the West from wading more deeply into the war in Ukraine. Western countries have provided weapons and intelligence to Kyiv but have refrained from sending troops.

The Defence Ministry said the first stage of the exercise involved Iskander and Kinzhal missiles.

It is aimed at ensuring that units and equipment are ready for “the combat use of non-strategic nuclear weapons to respond and unconditionally ensure the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Russian state in response to provocative statements and threats of individual Western officials against the Russian Federation”, the ministry said.

The drills involve missile forces in Russia’s Southern Military District, which lies adjacent to Ukraine and also includes parts of Ukraine that Russia now controls.

Belarus, where Russia said last year it was deploying tactical nuclear weapons, will also be involved, the two countries have said.

Tactical, or non-strategic, nuclear weapons are less powerful than the strategic arms designed to wipe out whole enemy cities, but they nevertheless have vast destructive potential.

Some Western analysts believe non-strategic nuclear weapons have acquired greater importance in Moscow’s thinking since the start of the war in Ukraine, where its conventional forces struggled in the first two years.

In theory the use of such a weapon could deliver a stunning shock to the West without necessarily triggering a full-blown nuclear war, though the risk of triggering a cycle of escalation would be huge.

Russia’s offensive in Ukraine’s northeastern border region of Kharkiv may just be the “first wave” in a wider assault, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has warned as he appealed to allies to send more air defence and fighter jets.

Russian forces, which had made only moderate advances in recent months, launched a surprise assault in the Kharkiv region on May 10 that resulted in their biggest territorial gains in a year and a half.

Zelenskyy conceded on Friday, in an interview with the AFP news agency, that Ukraine only has a quarter of the air defences it needs to hold the front line while the war grinds on.

He said Russian forces managed to advance between five to 10km (3-6 miles) along the northeastern border before being stopped by Ukrainian forces.

On Saturday, Kharkiv’s Governor Oleg Synegubov said “a total of 9,907 people have been evacuated” from the region following a ground attack by Russian troops.

Al Jazeera’s John Holman, reporting from Kharkiv, said that at present Ukraine is “outmanned in terms of soldiers” in parts of the front line even before the latest Russian attacks.

https://www.yahoo.com/news/death-toll-belgorod-apartment-building-202525478.html At least 15 people were killed in the Russian city of Belgorod after an apartment building collapsed on May 12, Russia's Emergency Situations Ministry claimed.

Two children are among those killed, the ministry claimed.

According to the Belgorod Oblast Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov, a part of a 10-story apartment building collapsed there earlier in the day.

Gladkov also claimed that the building was hit by a Ukrainian projectile during an air raid alert in the oblast.

Russian air defenses allegedly shot down six Tochka-U missiles and six rockets over Belgorod Oblast, according to the Russian Defense Ministry. The ministry claimed that the residential building was "damaged" by a Tochka-U missile fragment.

Ukrainian officials did not comment on the claims. The Kyiv Independent could not independently verify the reports.

The State Department notified Congress on Wednesday that it had determined Russian forces have employed chemical weapons against Ukrainian troops. The congressional notification came in accordance with the U.S. Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act of 1991 (CBW).

“The Department of State has made a determination under the CBW Act that Russia has used the chemical weapon chloropicrin against Ukrainian forces in violation of the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC),” the State Department announced. “We make this determination in addition to our assessment that Russia has used riot control agents as a method of warfare in Ukraine, also in violation of the CWC.”

Chloropicrin was first used as a weapon during World War I.

A recent report from a U.N. sanctions committee has revealed that a North Korean-made Hwasong-11 series ballistic missile was responsible for striking Kharkiv on January 2. Both Ukrainian and U.S. officials have previously alleged Russia’s utilization of North Korean-produced missiles in attacks on Ukraine. The report further suggests that Russia’s acquisition of these missiles violates U.N. sanctions, raising concerns about Moscow’s military cooperation with Pyongyang.

Inspectors conducting a field investigation in Kharkiv found fragments from the missile that indicate its North Korean origin. Notably, the report emphasizes the absence of evidence linking the missile to Russian manufacturing. As Russia’s top weapons supplier, North Korea’s provision of advanced military equipment to Moscow underscores growing apprehensions about the extent of collaboration between the two nations and its potential implications for regional security dynamics.

On Sunday, the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) issued a fervent plea to the government, urging immediate diplomatic interventions to aid Nepalis adversely impacted by the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Tikaram Pokharel, spokesperson for the commission, emphasized the necessity for diplomatic efforts to facilitate the rescue of affected Nepalis and ensure prompt medical treatment for the injured.

In a formal statement, Pokharel stressed the urgency of repatriating the bodies of Nepalis who lost their lives in the conflict. The NHRC also underscored the critical importance of intervening to safeguard the lives of individuals such as Kritu Bhandari, who have been staging a hunger strike in Kathmandu for 17 days, demanding the rescue of fellow Nepalis.

The NHRC's field inspection team reported a concerning deterioration in the health conditions of those participating in the hunger strike on a daily basis.

Ukraine’s top commander has said Kyiv’s outnumbered troops fell back to new positions west of three villages on the eastern front, where Russia has concentrated significant forces in several locations.

Sunday’s statement by Colonel General Oleksandr Syrskii reflected on Ukraine’s deteriorating position in the east, which Kyiv hopes it can stabilise once it receives United States weapons under a $61bn aid package approved in the US this week.

“The situation at the front has worsened,” Syrskii wrote on the Telegram app, describing the “most difficult” areas as west of occupied Maryinka and northwest of Avdiivka, the town captured by Russian forces in February.

Kyiv’s troops, he said, had taken up new positions west of the villages of Berdychi and Semenivka, both north of Avdiivka, and Novomykhailivka, further south near the town of Maryinka.

“In general, the enemy achieved certain tactical successes in these areas, but could not gain operational advantages,” Oleksandr Syrskii said, adding that Russia had committed four brigades to the assault.

Pentagon swiftly dispatches $1 billion worth of weapons to Kyiv following President Biden's signing of a $95 billion foreign aid bill. The move aims to bolster Ukrainian forces, who have faced challenges against Russian incursions. Biden emphasized the urgency, stating, "We need to move fast." The package, which includes critical air defense systems and artillery, signifies a shift in Washington's Ukraine policy, overcoming previous delays caused by partisan disputes. Biden stressed the importance of standing by allies and opposing tyrants, reaffirming America's role as the "indispensable nation." The aid package, including advanced weaponry like Stinger missiles and infantry vehicles, is seen as vital in addressing the gaps caused by months of delay. Ukrainian President Zelenskyy welcomed the support, while the Kremlin condemned it, warning of consequences. In addition to aid for Ukraine, the bill includes provisions affecting Israel, Taiwan, and a requirement for TikTok's parent company to divest its U.S. operations. Biden and his administration have underscored the significance of aiding Ukraine, highlighting the potential ramifications of inaction on NATO cohesion and regional stability. Zelenskyy expressed gratitude for the support, emphasizing the need to counter Putin's influence for the preservation of freedom.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Sunday that Kyiv will lose the war against Russia if the US Congress does not approve military aid to battle Moscow’s invasion.

Republicans in Congress have been blocking tens of billions of dollars in military assistance for Kyiv for months.

“It is necessary to specifically tell Congress that if Congress does not help Ukraine, Ukraine will lose the war,” Zelensky said during a video meeting of Kyiv-organised fundraising platform United24.

Zelensky said it would be “difficult” for Ukraine to “stay” (survive) without the aid.

He said that “if Ukraine loses the war, other states will be attacked.” Read details in the link in our bio.

Trump has repeated said that he can halt the controversy between Russia and Ukraine within a day.

सात अक्टूबर, इसराइल पर हमास के हमले और गज़ा में जंग के एक साल हो गए हैं। क्रिया के प्रतिक्रिया में इसराइल के कारवाई में ४० हजार से ज्यादा फिलिस्तीनी मारे गए हैं तो लाखों विस्थापित हुए हैं। हजारों के अंगभंग हुए हैं। इसराइल ने गाजापट्टी में भारी तबाही मचायी है और खंडहर में तब्दील कर दिया है। इसी बीच १२०० अधिक इस्रायली मारें गए हैं। युद्ध की शुरुवात हमास ने किया। अब यह युद्ध मध्यपूर्व में थमनें का नाम नहीं ले रहा है। अब ये युद्ध लेबनान के चरमपंथी संगठन हिजबुल्लाह से हो रहा है तो इसमें ईरान और सिरिया भी सामिल है। इनको भी इसराइल ने करारा जवाब दे रहा है। हमास, हिजबुल्लाह ओर  ईरान के प्रमुख नेताओं को इसराइल ने मार डाला है। हालांकि इस मामले में साऊदी अरब कोई प्रतिक्रिया नहीं दे रहा है। 
चारों ओर से शत्रु देशों से घिरे होने के बाबजूद इसराइल बहुत ही आक्रामक शैली से निपट रहा है। इसराइल के शत्रु देश इसराइल को राष्ट्र नहीं मानते हैं और इसराइल को नक्शे से मिटा देने की सपना देखते हैं। इसी के जबाब में इसराइली अपनी जान की बाजी लगाकर इसराइल का रक्षा कर रहे हैं। यहुदी भी ग्रेटर इसराइल बनाने की सपना पूरा करने के लिए तत्पर हैं। इसराइल को यूरोपीय देश और अमेरिका समर्थन करते आ रहे हैं।

The Israel-Hamas war erupted on October 7, 2023, after #Hamas launched a terrorist attack. 1200 lives were lost, most Israeli citizens, with 251 hostages taken, including women and children.
#Israel responded with airstrikes and a land invasion of #Gaza , sparking a war that has claimed 41,000 lives. Innocent families, schools, and hospitals have been affected, displacing 1.9 million people in Gaza.
The #US has provided Israel with weapon systems and medical aid since the war began. The #Biden Administration strongly supports #Netanyahu , fueling US-Israel ties amid the conflict.

7 اکتوبر 2023 کو شروع ہونے والی غزہ جنگ اب ایک سال تک جاری رہی ہے اور غزہ اور اسرائیل سے لبنان تک پھیل چکی ہے۔ اس جنگ کے نتیجے میں اسرائیل نے ایران، شام، عراق اور یمن پر حملے کیے ہیں اور فلسطینیوں پر بھی حملے کیے ہیں۔

جنگ اس وقت شروع ہوئی جب حماس نے اسرائیل پر ایک ہزار راکٹ فائر کیے اور مقبوضہ فلسطینی علاقوں میں اسرائیلی بستیوں اور فوجیوں پر حملہ کیا، جس میں ایک ہزار سے زیادہ اسرائیلی ہلاک ہوئے۔ سینکڑوں اسرائیلی شہریوں اور فوجیوں کو یرغمال بنا کر غزہ لایا گیا۔ اسرائیل نے اگلے دن غزہ کے شہریوں پر اپنی بدترین فضائی بمباری کے ساتھ ساتھ زمینی کارروائی کا جواب دیا جو آج تک جاری ہے۔ گزشتہ ایک سال کے دوران اسرائیلی حملوں میں تقریباً 42 ہزار فلسطینی شہید ہو چکے ہیں جن میں 16 ہزار بچے اور 11 ہزار خواتین شامل ہیں جب کہ ایک لاکھ سے زائد فلسطینی زخمی ہو چکے ہیں۔

اقوام متحدہ اور عالمی طاقتوں کی طرف سے جنگ بندی کی کوششیں اور ناکامی ہوئی ہے لیکن سب بے سود رہی۔ نومبر 2023 میں جنگ کے آغاز کے ایک ماہ بعد، دونوں فریقوں نے بین الاقوامی ثالثوں کی موجودگی میں 4 روزہ جنگ بندی پر اتفاق کیا، جس کے دوران دونوں فریقوں نے قیدیوں کا تبادلہ کیا۔ بعد ازاں امریکی صدر جو بائیڈن اور دیگر ممالک نے جنگ بندی کے لیے کئی کوششیں کیں لیکن مستقل جنگ بندی نہ ہونے کے باعث معاہدہ نہ ہو سکا۔

امریکہ نے گزشتہ سال اکتوبر سے اسرائیل کو 17 بلین ڈالر کی فوجی امداد دی ہے جو اسرائیلی دفاعی نظام کو فعال رکھنے، بحری جہازوں کے لیے تیل خریدنے اور دیگر ہتھیاروں کے لیے استعمال کی گئی۔ مزید برآں، امریکہ ایران کو انٹیلی جنس معلومات فراہم کرتا رہا ہے تاکہ حزب اللہ اور ایران کے حملوں کو روکا جا سکے۔

غزہ جنگ کے نتیجے میں کئی سینئر کمانڈروں کی ہلاکت، ہزاروں لبنانی شہریوں اور لاکھوں بے گھر ہوئے ہیں۔ اسرائیل ایران پر حماس اور حزب اللہ کی حمایت کا الزام لگاتا ہے اور اپریل میں اسرائیل نے شام کے شہر دمشق میں ایرانی قونصل خانے کی عمارت پر فضائی حملہ کیا تھا جس کے نتیجے میں سات اہلکار مارے گئے تھے۔

جنگ کے ایک سال بعد، غزہ میں 20 لاکھ فلسطینی اب بھی بے گھر ہیں، جب کہ شمالی اسرائیل میں رہنے والے تقریباً 20 لاکھ اسرائیلی یا تو بے گھر ہیں یا نظر بند ہیں۔ ہزاروں ٹن بم گرانے اور ہزاروں فوجیوں کے ساتھ زمینی آپریشن کرنے کے باوجود اسرائیل غزہ سے حماس کا صفایا نہیں کر سکا اور آج بھی غزہ میں مزاحمت کا سامنا ہے۔

**Yemen Civil War (2015-present)**

The Yemen Civil War, which began in 2015, has evolved into one of the most devastating humanitarian crises of the 21st century. This conflict erupted when Houthi rebels, an armed group from the Zaidi Shia minority, seized control of Yemen's capital, Sana'a, and eventually forced President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi into exile. The situation quickly escalated into a full-scale civil war involving multiple factions and international powers.

A key component of the conflict has been the intervention of a Saudi-led coalition, which includes the United Arab Emirates and several other Arab states. This coalition has been fighting against the Houthis in support of the internationally recognized Yemeni government. The coalition's intervention has included airstrikes, blockades, and ground operations, aimed at restoring Hadi's government and curbing the influence of Iranian-backed Houthis.

The humanitarian impact of the war has been profound. Yemen has faced severe food shortages, widespread disease outbreaks, and the destruction of infrastructure, leading to what the United Nations has described as the world's worst humanitarian crisis. Millions of Yemenis have been displaced, and the country has struggled to cope with the scale of suffering.

Efforts to broker peace and reach a resolution have been ongoing, with various international organizations and mediators working to bring the warring parties to the negotiating table. Despite these efforts, a lasting solution remains elusive, and the conflict continues to cause immense hardship for the Yemeni people.

The Yemen Civil War highlights the complex interplay of local, regional, and international factors in modern conflicts, and underscores the urgent need for a comprehensive and humanitarian-focused approach to resolving such crises.

**#YemenCivilWar #HumanitarianCrisis #SaudiCoalition #HouthiRebels #InternationalIntervention #YemenConflict #HumanRights #Displacement #PeaceEfforts #MiddleEastCrisis #GlobalAid**

Now that Iran and Saudi Arabia have agreed to reestablish diplomatic relations following their talks in Beijing earlier this month, hopes have emerged that the eight-year civil war in Yemen may finally be coming to an end. However, there is yet to be any specific plan to include the troubled South Arabian nation within bilateral peace negotiations.

The Iran-Saudi reconciliation seems to be making progress since it was first announced. Iran Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, released a press statement on Monday announcing that embassies will reopen in both Tehran and Riyadh by May 10, six years after they were closed.

Abdollahian tweeted, “I received congratulation calls from the prime minister and foreign minister of Qatar, as well as the foreign ministers of Iraq and Oman, on the agreement between Iran and Saudi Arabia to normalize ties.”

Hezbollah and the Lebanese government both accuse Israel of being behind the assaults, despite Tel Aviv's silence on the subject. Hassan Nasrallah, the Secretary-General of Hezbollah, has promised revenge, calling Israel's actions "hell."

Emmys 2024: Gaza Ceasefire Becomes a Red Carpet Statement for Hollywood Stars & Activists by Mehr jan

Stars like Nicola Coughlan and Devery Jacobs wore symbolic pins supporting peace, while protesters gathered outside to amplify the message. This political statement continues a trend of award shows becoming platforms for raising global issues, including the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

At the 2024 Emmys, celebrities and activists used the red carpet to call for a Gaza ceasefire. Stars like Nicola Coughlan and Devery Jacobs wore symbolic pins supporting peace, while protesters gathered outside to amplify the message. This political statement continues a trend of award shows becoming platforms for raising global issues, including the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

At least nine lives lost and 2,750 injured as handheld pagers explode across Lebanon, marking a devastating moment in the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict. Among the victims is an eight-year-old girl, highlighting the tragic toll on innocent lives. 

Hezbollah has labeled the explosion a significant security breach, with accusations directed at Israel amidst escalating tensions. Reports of near-simultaneous blasts have sent shockwaves through communities, leading to widespread panic and urgent calls for blood donations in hospitals. 

Source: @aljazeeraenglish

According to an Israeli media outlet on Saturday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has chosen to extend a military operation on the northern front with Lebanon, according to the Anadolu news agency.

Without naming the participants in the meeting, Channel 13 stated that Netanyahu made the remarks on Thursday during a strategic dialogue session to address the escalation on the northern front.

"A broad and strong operation on the northern front is imminent for Israel," the speaker declared.

A senior source from Netanyahu's administration, who wished to remain anonymous, was quoted by the station as saying that "no date has been set" for the escalation but that "it is expected in the near future."

Local media said that on Sunday, Israeli planes dropped flyers in southern Lebanon asking people to leave.

The state-run National News Agency said that the pamphlets urged people living in al-Wazzani and neighboring areas to relocate.

The network stated that four persons were hurt as they were being evacuated from their houses in southern Lebanon's Kfar Kila and Odaisseh by Israeli artillery shelling.

Early on Sunday, the Israeli army said that some forty rockets fired from southern Lebanon toward northern Israel had set multiple fires.

غزہ کے مغربی کنارے میں اسرائیلی بربریت کا ایک اور اندوہناک واقعہ پیش آیا ہے جس میں صیہونی فورسز نے فلسطینیوں کو شہید کرنے کے بعد ان کی لاشیں چھت سے پھینک دیں۔

فلسطینی حکام کے مطابق تصدیق نہیں ہو سکی ہے کہ پھینکے گئے افراد مر چکے تھے یا زندہ تھے تاہم بتایا جا رہا ہے کہ  مغربی کنارے میں اسرائیلی فوج نے فلسطینیوں کی لاشیں چھت سے پھینکی ہیں۔

 غیر ملکی خبر رساں ادارے کا بتانا ہے کہ  اسرائیل فوج لاشیں پھینکنے کی تحقیقات کر رہی ہے۔

دوسری جانب اسرائیلی فوج نے جنین شہر کے قریب آپریشن میں7 فلسطینیوں کو شہید کیا، آپریشن کے دوران صحافیوں پر بھی فائرنگ کی گئی۔

واضح رہے کہ  اسرائیلی فوج کے غزہ کے وسطی، شمالی اور جنوبی حصوں میں حملوں میں متعدد فلسطینی شہید ہوگئے ہیں گزشتہ 24گھنٹوں  کے دوران مزید 28فلسطینی شہید ہوگئے جبکہ گزشتہ برس اکتوبر سے اب تک 41 ہزار سے زائد فلسطینی شہید اور ایک لاکھ سے زائد زخمی ہو چکے ہیں۔

لبنان کی مزاحمتی تنظیم حزب اللہ کی جانب سے شمالی اسرائیل میں ائیر ڈیفنس بیس پر راکٹ حملے کیے گئے۔
عرب میڈیا کے مطابق اسرائیل نے حزب اللہ کے کئی راکٹ تباہ کرنے کا دعویٰ کیا ہے تاہم کسی جانی و مالی نقصان کی تاحال کوئی اطلاع سامنے نہیں آ سکی۔
غزہ پر اسرائیل کے حملوں میں 24 گھنٹوں کے دوران 40 فلسطینی شہید ہو گئے۔
اسرائیل نے مقبوضہ مغربی کنارے میں پھر فوجی آپریشن کر دیا، طولکرم میں اسرائیلی آپریشن میں بچی سمیت 5 فلسطینی شہید ہو گئے جبکہ 20گھر دھماکوں سے تباہ کر دیے گئے، متعدد فلسطینی گرفتار ہو گئے۔
ترک حکومت نے ترک امریکی کارکن عائشہ نور کی موت کے ذمہ دار اسرائیلی حکام کی گرفتاری کے لیے عالمی وارنٹ جاری کرانے پر غور شروع کر دیا۔
نوبیل انعام یافتہ ملالہ یوسفزئی نے کہا کہ عالمی قانون کی خلاف ورزی پر اسرائیل کا احتساب ہونا چاہیے اور غزہ میں اب جنگ بندی ہونی چاہیے۔

The United Nations has condemned Israel following an airstrike on a school in Gaza, which resulted in the deaths of 18 people, including six U.N. workers. The school, located in the Nuseirat refugee camp, was sheltering over 12,000 displaced Palestinians. U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres called the strike a violation of international humanitarian law and demanded an immediate halt to the violence in Gaza.

The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) defended the strike, claiming it was a targeted operation against Hamas members using the school as a command center. However, no evidence was provided to support this claim, and the U.N. Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) reported the attack as the deadliest single incident involving its staff.

The Israel-Palestine conflict traces back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Jewish and Arab nationalistic aspirations clashed over the same land. After World War II, the creation of Israel in 1948 sparked intense conflict, leading to wars in 1948, 1967, and beyond. Israel established control over key territories such as the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem after the Six-Day War in 1967. Palestinians demand statehood, sovereignty over the occupied territories, and the right to return for refugees displaced by the conflict.

Presently, peace efforts remain stagnant, with Israel expanding settlements in the West Bank and Palestinian factions divided between the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank and Hamas in Gaza. Violent clashes continue, fueled by deep-seated grievances.

The future remains uncertain. While some push for a two-state solution, others argue for a binational state or separate paths, but political and ideological divides make any resolution elusive.

The world population rose up to demand urgent aid for Palestine. 

No nation has actually done anything on Palestinian soil. Your response was silence - more bodies and wounded. 

Currently Rafah is the most populated area in the world, deprived of drinking water, food and medical care/materials. 

The orphan rate continues to grow.

We helplessly witness a Genocide hoping that a country will stop this carnage, stop the sale of military equipment.

There is no safe place, even in the camps.

Après tant de sang coulé et de corps encore sous les décombres, la population a demandé à la terre entière à plusieurs reprises un cessez le feu. 
La population mondiale s’est soulevée pour revendiquer une aide urgente pour la Palestine. 

Aucune nation n’a concrètement fait quelque chose sur le sol palestinien. Votre réponse a été votre silence et davantage de cadavres et de blessés. 

En ce moment Rafah est la zone la plus peuplée au monde, dépourvue d’eau potable, de nourriture et de soins/matériels médicaux. 

Le taux d’orphelins ne cesse de croître. 

Nous assistons de manière impuissante à un Génocide en espérant qu’un pays arrête ce carnage, arrête la vente/dont de matériel militaire. 

Il n’y a pas d’endroit sûr, même dans les camps.

Following more than ten years of diplomatic isolation, Saudi Arabia has formally reopened its embassy in Damascus, Syria, signaling a major milestone in last year's rapprochement between the two nations.

The reopening of the Kingdom's diplomatic mission in Syria, according to Saudi Chargé d'Affaires Abdullah Al-Harith, "represents an important moment in the history of relations between our two brotherly countries," at a ceremony hosted on Monday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Damascus. Additionally, he emphasized Riyadh's dedication to cultivating bilateral ties with Damascus.

Following his passing in July, Dr. Ismail Haniyeh, the late leader of Hamas, was the subject of proceedings that the International Criminal Court (ICC) announced on Friday, according to Reuters.

A request for arrest warrants against Israeli and Hamas leaders issued earlier this year is presently being considered by the ICC.

The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, Karim Khan, requested arrest warrants for Hamas leaders in May. He claimed that there were good reasons to believe Yahya Sinwar, Dr. Ismail Haniyeh, and military chief Mohammed Al-Masri were criminally responsible for alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity.

The prosecutor declared in the same announcement that he was also requesting arrest warrants for Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. No updates about those requests have been received.

The Palestinian-led International Solidarity Movement (ISM) claimed on Friday that Israel "deliberately" targeted a Turkish-American activist, calling for accountability for Israeli forces' increasing violence against international activists and Palestinian civilians in the Occupied West Bank, according to Anadolu Agency.

According to an ISM statement, Aysenur Ezgi Eygi was part of a peaceful rally in Beita against illegal Israeli settlements when the Israeli army opened fire.

The Movement stated that Eygi was standing with other human rights monitors when she was fatally shot in the head by a sniper, making her the 18th protester slain in Beita since 2020.

I regret any deviation from the intended focus of this platform, however in light of my background in interfaith dialogue, I have found myself the recipient of numerous questions concerning my stance on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. I want to take this opportunity to express my viewpoint. 

It is imperative to highlight that I do not lay claim to professional expertise on this subject. Rather, I speak as a Muslim American who has been nurtured amidst a milieu of diverse religious and cultural backgrounds. I refrain from professing any proficiency in political matters, and I acknowledge my limited knowledge of the intricate historical dynamics underlying these conflicts.

The Gaza Health Ministry has initiated a polio vaccination program in the southern Gaza Strip, aimed primarily at children under the age of ten, according to Anadolu.

The initiative, which began on Saturday in Khan Younis, aims to vaccinate more than 90% of Gaza's children by September 12.

The immunization push, which is being performed in partnership with the World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, and the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA), began at Nasser Hospital after the organizations held a joint news conference.

Three security and government sources told Reuters that President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi received an intelligence briefing that triggered worries about food security, which led to the largest wheat tender in Egypt's history, which was over 20 times larger than typical.

Tens of millions of Egyptians rely on wheat, which is imported by Egypt, one of the largest countries in the world, to make subsidized bread. To prevent public discontent, successive governments had kept the price steady for decades. However, in June, Sisi's government increased the price by 300 percent.

It has not yet been disclosed how Sisi contributed to the earlier this month tender, which called for 3.8 million metric tons of wheat but only received 7% of that amount. When contacted for comment, his office did not provide one.

The Turkish newspaper Anadolu, Egypt today refuted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's allegations that Hamas was receiving armaments through Egypt's border with the Gaza Strip. Netanyahu's claim was described by the Egyptian Foreign Ministry as an attempt to obstruct mediation efforts aimed at reaching a prisoner swap and truce in Gaza.

Netanyahu reaffirmed yesterday that he will not allow Israeli forces to leave the demilitarized zone that runs along Egypt's border with Gaza, known as the Philadelphi Corridor. The Israeli prime minister asserted that Hamas may rearm using the passage as a "lifeline."

"Hindering mediation efforts by Egypt, Qatar, and the US, as well as trying to involve Egypt to divert Israeli public opinion and obstruct a ceasefire and hostage swap deal," Cairo charged Netanyahu.

According to a report from Reuters, emergency workers are trying to determine how many people are still missing after waters burst over a dam in eastern Sudan, causing the deadliest in a series of floods that have ravaged a country already torn apart by 500 days of war.

The collapse of the Arbaat Dam on Sunday killed 30 people and possibly killed scores more, the latest in a string of inundations around the country as this year's rainy season arrives sooner and heavier than in previous years.

War-shattered Sudan is already dealing with one of the world's worst starvation and displacement crises, and the floods have hampered assistance distribution, which has already been interrupted by the army's war with its adversary, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.

The Israeli military has bombed a warehouse sheltering displaced Palestinians in the az-Zawayda area of central Gaza, killing 15 members of one family, including nine children.

The civil defence spokesman in Gaza, Mahmoud Basal, said on Saturday that 15 people killed in the overnight attack were members of the al-Ejlah family, with three women among the dead. The total death toll from the attack was 16.

Reporting from Deir el-Balah in central Gaza, Al Jazeera’s Tareq Abu Azzoum said three Israeli missiles hit the warehouse, located a few kilometres south of the Nuseirat refugee camp.

“A massive fire broke out, burning everything in the warehouse as children were torn to pieces. Rescue efforts are still continuing to try to recover more bodies,” he said.

“There is a great level of frustration and grief. The bodies are now being lined up at Al-Aqsa Hospital’s morgue as the family gets ready to bury them.”

The attack killed the family’s patriarch, Sami, along with his wife, mother and all of his children, according to Abdalhadi al-Ejlah, a cousin of the victims.

Palestinian detainees are enduring severe physical and psychological torture in Israeli facilities, the Al Mezan Center for Human Rights has said, calling for accountability for the abuses.

The prisoners “have been exposed naked to the scorching sun while standing on sharp gravel stones, subjected to verbal abuse, and threatened with rape, death, and bombing, along with threats against their families”, it said in a statement on Tuesday.

The rights group said that recent testimony and evidence “reveal a level of violence that resounds with the atrocities documented in Guantanamo and Abu Ghraib”, referring to the United States-run detention facility in Cuba and the prison in Iraq where US soldiers abused detainees.

Al Mezan said that the detainees have also been “deprived of food, water, sleep, and access to sanitation for extended periods, all while facing extremely harsh living conditions”.

The group estimated at least 2,650 Palestinians taken from the Gaza Strip after October 7 remain in Israeli custody, including 12 children and two women.

Among them, approximately 300 are facing trials, while 2,350 are classified as “unlawful combatants” without a defined detention period or specific charges.

"Israeli media outlets are stirring up a frenzy about the occupation state facing a serious threat from a draft resolution which the Palestinian Authority has presented to the UN General Assembly. The resolution seeks to implement the International Court of Justice’s 19 July advisory opinion. The opinion reiterated the illegality of Israel’s occupation, annexation and settlement expansion, and called for action “to bring to an end as rapidly as possible the unlawful presence of the State of Israel in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.” Although “advisory” and thus “non-binding”, legal experts point out that the laws upon which it is based are binding on all UN member states."

Germany has suspended new war weapon sales to Israel while it resolves legal challenges, a source close to the Economy Ministry and a Reuters data analysis reveals.

According to data from the Economy Ministry, which authorizes export licenses, Germany authorized arms exports to Israel last year totaling 326.5 million Euros ($363.5 million), including military hardware and weaponry. This represents a ten-fold increase from 2022.

But this year, permissions have decreased; from January to August 21, only 14.5 million euros' worth of approvals were given, according to statistics that the Economy Ministry gave in response to a parliamentary query.

Hamas Picks New Boss: Because Even Terrorist Groups Need New Management Sometimes
*
Over the past week, top Hamas leaders gathered in Qatar to pick a new political head after Ismail Haniyeh was killed. They arrived from across the Middle East, some still shaken after fighting Israel in Gaza. Haniyeh, the group's previous leader, died in a blast in Tehran allegedly by Israel. Talk about a hostile takeover!

At the mourning ceremony in Doha, leaders lined up to pay their respects, but really, they were eyeing his vacant position. One man stood out—Abu Omar Hassan, head of Hamas's Supreme Shura Council. No, he's not a Bond villain...yet.

After two days of intense meetings, they went with Yahya Sinwar, who’s been leading Hamas in Gaza since 2017. He's close to the militant wing—basically, he's their LinkedIn top candidate. Israel believes he planned attacks on southern Israel and now he's top of their hit list. Some Hamas leaders wanted a more moderate leader, but apparently, extremism got the majority vote.

Citing security concerns, German flag carrier Lufthansa extended its flight suspension to the Middle East crisis zone on Wednesday, according to the Anadolu Agency.

The Lufthansa Group declared in Frankfurt that the links to Tel Aviv, Beirut, Tehran, Amman, and Erbil will be suspended until Tuesday, August 13. All rights reserved.

The group's airlines, as well as both freight and passenger planes, are subject to the flight restriction. The Lufthansa Group comprises Swiss, Austrian, Brussels Airlines, and Eurowings in addition to its main carrier.

Israel has returned the bodies of nearly 90 Palestinians killed in its military offensive in the Gaza Strip, the Palestinian Ministry of Health has said.

Yamen Abu Suleiman, the director of the Palestinian Civil Emergency Service in Khan Younis in southern Gaza, said on Monday that it was unclear whether the bodies had been dug up from cemeteries by the army during the ground offensive, or whether they were “detainees who had been tortured and killed”.

“The occupation provided us with no information about the names, or ages, or anything. This is a war crime, a crime against humanity,” Abu Suleiman said.

He said the bodies would be examined in an attempt to determine the causes of death and to identify them, before being buried in a mass grave at a cemetery near Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

Gaza’s Government Media Office said Israel had sent 89 bodies as “bones and decomposed bodies in an inhumane manner”.

At least nine people, including a local commander of Hamas’s military wing, have been killed in two separate Israeli air strikes near Tulkarem in the occupied West Bank.

Medical sources confirmed to Al Jazeera on Saturday that one of the people killed in the first attack was Haitham Balidi, leader of the Qassam Brigades in the Nablus area. Another person was identified by a relative as one of the leaders of al-Quds Brigades, the armed wing of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad group.

The identities of the other people were not immediately clear. Family members went to a hospital in Tulkarem to identify the dismembered bodies brought there.

The Israeli military said the car contained a “terrorist squad” that was on its way to carry out an attack, without providing evidence.

A few hours later, a second air attack on a vehicle in Bal’a, east of Tulkarem, killed four people, according to Wafa news agency.

Shortly after the initial attack, Israeli forces launched raids in Tulkarem, resulting in confrontations with Palestinian fighters. Israeli forces also fired tear gas at journalists who were covering the raid.

More than 50 people have been killed in Israeli attacks in central and southern Gaza, with one air raid hitting a school where thousands of displaced people were sheltering, according to Palestinian officials.

At least 30 people were killed in an Israeli attack on Khadija School in Deir el-Balah, central Gaza, the Palestinian Health Ministry said on Saturday.

Fifteen children and eight women were among those killed in the attack on the school in Deir el-Balah, Gaza’s Government Media Office said, and more than 100 people were wounded.

The Israeli military said in a statement it had targeted a “Hamas command and control centre inside the Khadija school compound in central Gaza”.

The statement said the school was being used to launch attacks against troops and as a weapons cache and that it warned civilians before the raid.

Multiple rockets were launched at Iraq's Ain Al-Asad Air Base, which houses US-led forces, late yesterday, according to US and Iraqi sources. No damage or deaths were reported, according to Reuters.

Two US officials stated that the base itself was not targeted in the attack.

The incident occurred two days after a military summit in Washington, where Iraqi and US officials discussed winding down the coalition's operations a decade after it was created to combat Daesh in Iraq and Syria.

There was no dramatic statement at the end of the negotiations, but US and Iraqi sources suggest it will begin to wind down gradually in the coming weeks.

JERUSALEM: Facing intense pressure to quickly cut a ceasefire deal with Hamas in Gaza, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is to deliver a landmark speech to the US Congress on Wednesday.

While Netanyahu will become the first foreign leader to address a joint meeting of the two chambers four times, pulling ahead of Britain’s Winston Churchill on three, an expected meeting between Netanyahu and US President Joe Biden is still not confirmed.

Publicly, Biden has voiced strong support for Israel, but he expressed concern over an offensive on the southern city of Rafah in May and for a while suspended deliveries of heavy bombs to Israel.

“Never before has the atmosphere been so fraught,” said Council on Foreign Relations Middle East specialist Steven Cook. “There is clearly tension in the relationship, especially between the White House and the Israeli prime minister,” Cook said in a commentary.
One Jewish senator, Democrat Brian Schatz of Hawaii, announced he would boycott Wednesday’s speech, saying he would not listen to “political rhetoric that will do nothing to bring peace in the region”.

On July 19, the International Court of Justice found Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories “illegal”, months after it called for the country to stop genocide in Gaza.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has issued a significant advisory opinion declaring Israel's presence in the Palestinian territories illegal. 

This ruling, released on July 19, 2024, emphasizes that Israel must cease its occupation and dismantle settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which the court deems violations of international law. 

The ICJ's opinion stems from a request by the UN General Assembly following a Palestinian initiative.

KEY FINDINGS OF THE ICJ RULING:

📌 ILLEGAL OCCUPATION: The court stated that Israel's ongoing presence in the Palestinian territories is "unlawful" and must be ended "AS RAPIDLY AS POSSIBLE." It highlighted various policies, including the expansion of settlements and discriminatory practices against Palestinians, as breaches of international law.

📌 CALL FOR REPARATIONS: The ICJ also called for Israel to provide reparations for damages inflicted on individuals in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, although the specifics of these reparations remain to be determined. This includes RESTITUTION, COMPENSATION, AND SATISFACTION FOR THE AFFECTED INDIVIDUALS.

📌 GLOBAL IMPLICATIONS: The ruling urges all nations to collaborate with the UN to address Israel's illegal presence and uphold the Palestinian people's right to self-determination. It signals a shift in international attitudes towards the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and could influence future diplomatic relations and policies regarding Israel.

President Tayyip Erdogan's abrupt decision to call his estranged Syrian counterpart, Bashar Al-Assad, for negotiations has sparked fears among Syrians in Turkey that they may be deported, a week after a wave of anti-migrant violence left many terrified, according to Reuters.

Ankara severed ties with Damascus in 2011, when Syria's civil conflict broke out and Turkish forces supported anti-Assad forces in the north. However, in the previous two weeks, Erdogan has emphasized the necessity for reconciliation with Turkey's neighbor.

On Sunday, he was quoted as saying he would invite Assad "any time" to work on resuming previous relations with Syria, which had been severed by the war that involved the US, Russia, Turkey, and several armed groups.

text:
United Nations human rights experts have accused Israel of carrying out a “targeted starvation campaign” that has resulted in the deaths of children in Gaza.

“Israel’s intentional and targeted starvation campaign against the Palestinian people is a form of genocidal violence and has resulted in famine across all of Gaza,” 10 independent UN experts said in a statement on Tuesday.

Israel’s diplomatic mission to the UN in Geneva dismissed the statement and accused the experts of “spreading misinformation” and “supporting Hamas propaganda”.

Gaza health authorities have said at least 33 children have died of malnutrition, mostly in northern Gaza, which had until recently faced the brunt of the Israeli military campaign launched in October.

In recent months, Israel’s ground invasion has also spread to southern Gaza, reducing aid flows into the enclave amid restrictions by Israel, which has accused UN agencies of failing to distribute supplies efficiently.

The deaths of a baby “barely six months old”, a nine-year-old boy and a thirteen-year-old boy since May 30 showed “there is no doubt that famine has spread from northern Gaza into central and southern Gaza,” the experts said.

The United Nations has expressed strong opposition to Israel's recent evacuation orders in Gaza, sparking significant international concern and public outcry.

The side streets and alleyways in Tehran's working-class district around Imam Hussein Square are crowded with secondhand stores and small repair shops that renovate all kinds of home products. But with little to do, most shopkeepers sit in front of their establishments.

Abbas, 60, and his 32-year-old son Asgar sat in two of the secondhand, faux-brocaded armchairs for sale. When asked about their business, Abbas, who did not want his surname publicized for fear of drawing the government's attention, was perplexed.

Speaking to the Quds Press, Israeli occupation forces destroyed Gaza's second largest historical mosque yesterday, reducing it to ruins.

According to the AFP, Israeli jets fired four missiles against the Ibn Uthman Mosque in the Shuja'iyya district of central Gaza City, a week after launching a brutal onslaught in the area.

According to experts, the mosque is the second largest archaeological mosque in the Gaza Strip after the Great Al-Omari Mosque, located in the Al-Daraj district in the city's center, and serves as testimony of Gaza City's ancient history.

Wildfires in Alberta, Canada, and BC Force Evacuations.

Wildfires raging in northern Alberta have forced evacuations of three communities, according to provincial authorities. The affected areas include John D'Or, Fox Lake, and Garden River, covering approximately 62,000 hectares and impacting 5,000 residents. Alberta is currently battling 158 wildfires, with 55 out of control.
The provincial wildfire service stated, "Fire activity is expected to remain intense throughout the weekend due to hot and dry weather." Over 200 firefighters, 10 helicopters, and 43 heavy equipment pieces are engaged in firefighting efforts, with lightning identified as the cause.

Meanwhile, British Columbia faces 319 active wildfires, prompting evacuation orders and alerts. The BC Wildfire Service reported that thunderstorms are exacerbating fire activity, with nearly a thousand firefighters deployed.

Saudi Arabia’s Foreign Minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan, addressed European nations, urging them to impose sanctions on Israeli officials violating international human rights laws amid the conflict in Gaza. He emphasized that the situation in Gaza impacts the broader Middle East, including southern Lebanon, and criticized Israel’s settlement expansion in the West Bank, which he argued undermines the peace process. Prince Faisal called for a two-state solution for Palestine and praised European countries that have recognized Palestine as a state. He also reiterated calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and humanitarian aid delivery to the population.

On Thursday last week, the US House of Representatives passed an amendment to restrict the US State Department from utilizing Gaza’s Health Ministry statistics to mention the mortality counts for Israel’s genocide in Gaza. Israel frequently claims that it has no information on the Palestinian civilians killed or injured by its bombs, preferring to focus the narrative on allegedly eradicating Hamas. The latest pro-Israel gesture by Congress, therefore, means that the State Department is now entirely implicated in trying to erase the truth of genocide from global consciousness. For Palestinians, the act is another step toward their elimination and eradication from both memory and statistics.

In the previous three months, the Nigerian military has killed 2,245 terrorists in operations against Boko Haram and the ISWAP, the West African branch of ISIS/Daesh, according to an official quoted by Anadolu Agency on Friday.

Maj. Gen. Edward Buba, head of defense media operations, stated that operations against terrorist groups were carried out in numerous states across the country between April and June.

Furthermore, Buba stated that 1,993 people kidnapped for ransom were rescued during the operations, and 2,783 firearms and a substantial amount of ammunition belonging to terrorists were seized.
