As stated by the World Food Programme, famine is a real possibility in 14 parts of Sudan if the conflict that began in April last year continues, according to statistics from a global hunger monitor released on Thursday. This would make it the world's largest hunger crisis.

According to an update from the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC), the areas are located in Khartoum, the Darfur and Kordofan regions, and El Gezira state.

As previously reported by Reuters, some 755,000 people in Sudan are experiencing "catastrophe," the most severe form of intense starvation. According to the report, 8.5 million people, or 18% of the population, are facing food shortages that could lead to acute malnutrition and death, as well as the need for emergency coping techniques.

The Sultanate of Oman said on Saturday that it has assisted the fulfillment of a prisoner swap agreement between Sweden and Iran and that the released detainees would be moved to Muscat, according to Anadolu Agency.

According to the Oman News Agency, the agreement was reached in response to "the Iranian and Swedish governments' request to help settle the issue of citizens detained in the two countries," and "the Omani efforts resulted in an agreement between the two sides on the mutual release."

"Those released were transferred from Tehran and Stockholm to Muscat today, 15 June 2024, for their repatriation," said the statement.

📌 Oxfam has reported that Israel has reduced the amount of water available to Gazans by 94% since the onset of the conflict on October 7, 2023. The organization's analysis highlights that the water supply has plummeted to just 4.74 liters per person per day, which is significantly below the recommended minimum for emergencies and equivalent to less than a single toilet flush.

📌 The report, titled "WATER WAR CRIMES," details how Israel's actions, including the cutting of external water supplies, systematic destruction of water infrastructure, and obstruction of humanitarian aid, have contributed to this crisis. Since the beginning of the conflict, Israeli military attacks have damaged or destroyed water and sanitation facilities at an alarming rate, with five sites affected every three days. 

📌 The destruction of essential infrastructure has led to a catastrophic public health situation, with over a quarter of Gaza's population suffering from preventable diseases due to the lack of clean water and sanitation.

📌 Oxfam has called for urgent international action to address the humanitarian crisis, including a ceasefire and the lifting of the blockade on Gaza to allow for the restoration of water and sanitation services. The organization emphasizes that the systematic deprivation of water constitutes a violation of international law and poses immediate and long-term threats to the health and survival of the Palestinian population in Gaza.

According to the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), Israeli attacks on residential areas in the Gaza Strip since October 7 have resulted in 39 million tonnes of debris. According to the program, the debris is equivalent to 107 kg of rubble per square meter. These horrific statistics were disclosed in a report published by the UNEP on Tuesday on the environmental impact of Israel's military offensive on the Palestinian territory.

Due to the security situation and access constraints in the area, the program generated the report remotely using information collected from UN efforts on the ground. It stated that fieldwork will be undertaken when security conditions allow.

AMEENA is now in 26th week . Like to share our friend Rakesh Jhunjhunnwala view 

Read carefully till the end!
The real truth of life!

Rakesh Jhunjhunnwala's last words before he passed away with a net worth of 45000 crores:

I have reached the pinnacle of success in the business world. My life is an achievement in the eyes of others. However, I had no happiness except work. Money is just a truth I use.

Laying in a hospital bed at this point and looking back on my whole life, I realize that the identity and money I was proud of, faded and worthless before death.

You can hire someone to drive your car or earn money. But, you can't hire someone to suffer and die.

Lost physical items can be found. But there is one thing that is never found when lost - and that is "Life".

Whatever stage of life we are in, in time we will face the day when the heart stops.

Love your family, partner and friends...🙏treat them well, don't cheat them, never be dishonest or treacherous.

As we grow older and wiser, we slowly realize that wearing a watch costing Rs 300 or Rs 3000 or Rs 2- 4 lakh - all tells the same time.

Whether we have a wallet of 100 or 500 - everything inside is the same.

Whether we drive a car worth 5Lacks or a car worth 50Lacks. The path and the distance are the same and we reach the same destination.

Whether we live in a house of 300 square feet or 3000 square feet - loneliness is the same everywhere.

You will realize that your true inner happiness does not come from the material things of this world.

Whether you fly in first class or economy class, if the plane goes down, you are going to go down with it.

That's why.. I hope you realize, you have friends, brothers and sisters, with whom you chat, laugh, sing, share pleasantries,.... That's true happiness. !!

An indisputable fact of life:

Don't educate your children just to be rich. Teach them to be happy. When they grow up, they will know the value of things and not the cost.

Due to intense Israeli raids that damaged at least one hospital, three hospitals—two in southern Lebanon and one in a southern suburb of Beirut—announced on Friday that their operations would be suspended.

The Sainte Therese Hospital's administration announced the "suspension of hospital services" due to "severe damage" to the structure and equipment as a result of nighttime raids that caused significant damage in the surrounding area. The hospital is located in the Hadath neighborhood in the southern suburb.

Because all routes and supply lines have been shut off and staff access to the hospital is restricted, the administration of the Meiss Ej Jabal Hospital in southern Lebanon announced the hospital's evacuation as well as the "suspension of work in all its departments."

Russia and Ukraine Exchange 206 POWs in UAE-Brokered Deal

Russia and Ukraine swapped 206 prisoners of war in a deal mediated by the UAE. Ukraine's President Zelensky confirmed 103 Ukrainian servicemen were released, including 82 privates and 21 officers captured from key regions like Kyiv, Donetsk, and Kharkiv. Russia stated its freed soldiers, captured during Ukraine's incursion into Kursk, will receive medical and psychological aid before returning home. This exchange follows a similar one in August and coincides with Russian advances in eastern Ukraine, notably capturing the village of Zhelanne Pershe in the Pokrovsk district.

🧭 Navigating sanctions: The role of transshipment hubs in Western-made components to Russia⁠
⁠
⚖️ Sanctions and frosty trade relations have been a consistent theme of international trade in the past half-decade, but even more so after the Russian invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022.⁠
⁠
🚫 Since then, Western governments have attempted to curtail direct and indirect trade with Russia, both to impose economic punishment and diminish Russia’s ability to produce military equipment.⁠
⁠
🌎 However, the world of international trade is often quite opaque, and while governments can introduce sanctions, their effectiveness is not guaranteed.⁠
⁠
✍ In our latest #TRADEFINANCETALKS Magazine Issue 22, Trade Finance Global’s Deepesh Patel spoke with Ravi Amin, CTFC, Trade Compliance Subject Matter Expert, at S&P Global Market Intelligence to discuss S&P Global Market Intelligence’s whitepaper, “Are transshipment hubs facilitating the movement of Western-made components to Russia?”⁠
⁠
📖 Read our article in the link in bio 👆⁠

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has praised Ukrainian forces for hitting military targets inside Russia after the army reported several attacks, including on an airfield and an oil depot.

“I would like to thank each of our soldiers and all those who work in our defence industry for striking Russian airfields, oil refineries and logistics,” he said in a statement on Saturday.

Kyiv has stepped up aerial attacks on Russian territory, saying it carries out the attacks in retaliation for the bombardment Ukraine has faced since Russia invaded more than two years ago.

Earlier on Saturday, Ukraine’s military said it had sunk a submarine in Russian-controlled Sevastopol, attacked a southern Russian airfield and hit oil depots and fuel and lubricant storage facilities in Belgorod, Kursk and Rostov regions.

“A Russian submarine went to the bottom of the Black Sea,” the Ministry of Defence said in a post on X, naming the vessel as the B-237 Rostov-on-Don attack submarine.

The military’s general staff said the attack on Sevastopol port also significantly damaged four launchers of the S-400 anti-aircraft “Triumf” defence system.

Hassan Kassar was left homeless in a destroyed city after a flood destroyed his four children in the Libyan town of Derna a year ago. The political divisions in the nation have caused delays in the city's rehabilitation, according to Reuters.

While shopping for his daughter's wedding in Egypt, Kassar, 69, was caught in the path of two dilapidated dams that failed to withstand the heavy downpour. The result was a wall of water that swept through the city and into the sea.

"That day was gloomy. A horrible day," he recalled, recalling the moment he came to the city to discover his house had vanished, that tents had been erected everywhere, and that neighbors had informed him that his children were missing.

Geneva will host the start of peace negotiations on Wednesday.

ریاض: یوکرین کے صدر وولودیمیر زیلنسکی سرکاری دورے پر سعودی عرب پہنچ گئے جہاں اُن کا پُرتپاک استقبال کیا گیا۔
سعودی عرب کے سرکاری خبر رساں ادارے کے مطابق یوکرین کے صدر وولودیمیر زیلنسکی جدہ پہنچ گئے۔ قومی سلامتی کے مشیر اور یوکرین میں سعودی سفیر نے ان کا ایئرپورٹ پر استقبال کیا۔
بعد ازاں یوکرینی صدر شاہی محل پہنچے اور سعودی ولی عہد شہزادہ محمد بن سلمان سے ملاقات کی۔ دونوں رہنماؤں نے روس جنگ سے پیدا ہونے والی صورت حال پر تبادلہ خیال کیا۔
ملاقات میں زیلنسکی اور سعودی ولی عہد کی 3 ماہ قبل ہونے والی ملاقات میں امن منصوبے کو فروغ دینے اور جنگی قیدیوں کے تبادلے پر طے پانے والے امور پر عمل درآمد کا جائزہ بھی لیا گیا۔
خیال رہے کہ فروری 2022 میں روس نے یوکرین پر حملہ کر دیا تھا اور اس کے چار علاقوں پر قبضہ کرکے نام نہاد ریفرنڈم کرایا اور ان علاقوں کو روس میں ضم کرلیا۔
مغربی ممالک کی حمایت یوکرین کو حاصل ہونے کے باوجود 2 سال سے روس نے جنگ مسلط کر رکھی ہے اور دونوں جانب جانی اور مالی نقصان ہو رہا ہے۔
سعودی عرب کے بدستور روس اور یوکرین کے ساتھ تعلقات قائم ہیں۔ اس لیے وہ جنگ بندی میں ثالثی کا کردار بہتر طور پر نبھا سکتا ہے۔
سعودی عرب نے روس یوکرین جنگ پر ثالثی کا کردار ادا کرنے کی کوشش میں  گزشتہ برس اگست میں جنگ بندی مذاکرات کی میزبانی بھی کی تھی جس میں روس کے علاوہ 40 سے زائد ممالک کے نمائندوں نے شرکت کی تھی۔
یاد رہے کہ یوکرینی صدر وولودیمیر زیلنسکی نے مئی 2023 میں جدہ میں ہونے والی عرب لیگ کے سربراہی اجلاس میں بھی شرکت کی تھی۔

According to US officials, President Joe Biden has authorized Ukraine to use American-supplied weapons to attack targets in Russia, specifically in the Kharkiv region.

The officials stated that their directive is to ensure that Ukraine can utilize US weapons for “counter-fire purposes” in order to retaliate against Russian forces that are attacking or preparing to attack them.

In recent weeks, Russian forces have made advancements in the Kharkiv region following an unexpected offensive in the vicinity, near the Russian border.

Ukrainian officials reported on Friday that three individuals were killed and 16 injured when a residential building in a suburb of Kharkiv city was hit by Russian shelling.

“Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of Army Tactical Missile System [ATACMS] or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,” The officials stated.

When questioned about whether the new policy involved engaging Russian aircraft, an official responded: “We’ve never told them [Ukraine] they can’t shoot down a Russian airplane over Russian soil that’s coming to attack them”.

The White House and state department did not provide an immediate comment.

Earlier, the UK indicated that it was willing to ease restrictions on how Ukraine could utilize weapons provided by the West.

Despite concerns about potential escalation of the conflict, several European leaders have recently advocated for relaxing restrictions on the use of such weapons.

However, Washington, which is the main supplier of Ukraine’s weaponry, has been reluctant to ease these restrictions due to fears of escalation.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken suggested this change during his visit to Moldova on Wednesday.

He said that: “At every step along the way, we’ve adapted and adjusted as necessary, and so that’s exactly what we’ll do going forward”.

Data With Geopolitics Explained

Weapons Sales (SIPRI TIV Million)(December 2022)

In a more fractured world, we're seeing more conflicts. These conflicts are often fought with weapons traded between countries. This dataset shows the weapons sales by country in December 2022. The unit, SIPRI TIV Million, is used to measure the volume of sales of weapons, not the price. If used by another force, these weapons are valued at 40% of TIV and weapons that have been refurbished or modified are valued at 66% of TIV. TIV refers to trend-indicator value and reflects military capability, not financial value. As we can see, the United States is leaps and bounds clear of anybody else, likely due to aid to Ukraine. France, Russia, China, Italy, Germany, the UK, Spain, Israel, and Poland make up the 2nd to 10th position.

Attached Dataset:
https://www.datawrapper.de/_/Pqu8p/

As the Russia-Ukraine conflict persists, Egypt, Israel, Oman, Nigeria, and South Africa have turned to India for wheat supplies, fearing a global food crisis. The disruption in wheat exports from Russia and Ukraine, major global wheat exporters, has led to shortages and soaring prices. India, the world's second-largest wheat producer, is also exploring new markets like Turkey and Sudan. The government is actively addressing logistical challenges to meet the surging demand, with talks underway to export to Egypt.

text:
We are back with good friend of the show Charlie Robinson.

He is a #1 best-selling author of such books as The Controlled Demolition Of The American Empire with co-author Jeff Berwick, The Octopus Of Global Control, and Hypocrazy: Surviving In A World Of Cultural Double Standards.

The United States has intensified its response to Moscow's alleged use of chemical weapons against Ukrainian forces by imposing additional sanctions on over 280 entities. These measures, targeting both Russian and non-Russian organizations, aim to cripple Russia's military and industrial capabilities. Among the targeted entities are 20 firms based in China and Hong Kong, reflecting concerns about growing military cooperation between China and Russia. The US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen emphasized that these sanctions would disrupt Russia's war efforts and support Ukraine's resistance. The Russian and Chinese embassies in Washington, DC, have yet to respond to these actions. Additionally, the US Department of State accused Russia of violating the Chemical Weapons Convention by using chloropicrin, a choking agent. Such actions highlight the international community's condemnation of Russia's aggressive tactics in the ongoing conflict.

Overnight and into Saturday, Russian missile strikes in Ukraine claimed the lives of eight individuals and left 12 others wounded, officials reported.

In the city of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest, six people were killed and 11 wounded in missile attacks overnight, damaging residential areas, a gas station, a kindergarten, a cafe, a shop, and vehicles, according to Oleh Syniehubov, the governor of the Kharkiv region. Additionally, a further strike on Kharkiv on Saturday afternoon resulted in one more casualty, confirmed Kharkiv mayor Ihor Terekhov. Meanwhile, in the southern Odesa region, a civilian was killed in another missile strike, as reported by its governor, Oleh Kiper.

According to Ukraine's air force commander, Russia launched 32 Iranian-made Shahed drones and six missiles overnight. Ukrainian air defense forces managed to intercept three cruise missiles and 28 drones, stated Lt. Gen. Mykola Oleshchuk, adding, "Russian killers continue to terrorize Ukrainians and attack Kharkiv and other peaceful cities."

विज्ञान के क्षेत्र में उच्च शिक्षण संस्थाओं में शुमार Indian Institute of Science (IISc) बेंगलुरु में विगत दिवस 23 सितंबर को #IndiaIsraelBusinessSummit2024 के आयोजन की तैयारी थी, जो छात्रों के तमाम विरोधों के बावजूद भी संस्थान द्वारा आयोजित किया गया । 

इजराइल और गाज़ा युद्ध के दौरान इजराइल के हमलों से गाज़ा में एक आंकड़ों के अनुसार अबतक लगभग 41000 हजार पलेस्तीनी मारे जा चुके है । मरने वालों में यह आंकड़ा उपलब्ध रिकॉर्ड के आधार पर है, जबकि मरने वालों के वास्तविक आंकड़े इसके चार गुना से अधिक हैं । गाज़ा में कूल जनसंख्या में मरने वालों की संख्या 10 प्रतिशत से अधिक है ।  इजराइल के हमलों से अंतराष्ट्रीय कानूनों के साथ ही विश्वभर में निर्धारित मानवाधिकार के मापदंडों का खुले तौर पर उल्लंघन किया गया जिसके कारण गाज़ा के 96 प्रतिशत नागरिकों के सामने खाद्य सुरक्षा के संकट पैदा हो गया हैं । इजराइल के द्वारा अपने हमलों से गाज़ा के शिक्षण संस्थानों, यूनिवर्सिटियों, स्वास्थ्य सेवाओं को पूरे तरीके से ध्वस्त किया जा चुका है । 

इजराइल ने गाज़ा में नरसंहार कर मानवाधिकारों के सभी मापदंडों का उल्लंघन किया है और ऐसे नरसंहार के बाद भी इंडियन इंस्टीट्यूट ऑफ साइंस, बेंगलुरु के द्वारा इसराइली प्रतिनिधियों के साथ समीट किया जाना,यह बताता है कि संस्थान दुनिया में हो रहे नरसंहार का समर्थन करता है । इस समीट के विरोध में देश भर के शिक्षण संस्थानों के छात्र-छात्राओं के हस्ताक्षर कराकर आईआईएस, बेंगलुरु को भेजा गया था कि संस्थान तत्काल प्रभाव से इजराइल के साथ होने वाले इस समीट को रद्द किया जाए, किंतु संस्थान ने छात्रों के लिखित विरोध और प्रदर्शन के बावजूद इस समीट को होने की अनुमति दी है । उल्लेखनीय है कि इस समीट के विरोध में खड़े छात्रों में देश भर के आईआईएम, आईआईटी, केंद्रीय विश्विद्यालयों के अलावा मेडिकल जगत से भी छात्रों ने अपना विरोध दर्ज कराया है ।

Concerned about possible threats to a Turkish vessel performing energy research and exploration in Somali waters, Turkiye is apparently preparing to send frigates there to defend it.

Turkiye is reportedly exercising extreme caution when it comes to the safety of its "Oruc Reis" vessel, especially because it is meant to operate in open waters off the coast of Somalia, according to a report by Middle East Eye that quoted two people with knowledge of the situation.

The vessel is scheduled to carry out a 3D seismic survey in the region, which Turkish Energy Minister Alparslan Bayraktar stated last week "had never been done before." Turkish Petroleum holds a license for three areas in Somali waters, each field covering 5,000 square kilometers.

In the men's javelin throw final of the Paris Olympics 2024, top athlete Arshad Nadeem broke the Olympic record with a throw of 92.97 meters, helping Pakistan win its first Olympic gold medal in forty years.

Pakistan last won gold in 1984 and had not won a medal at the Games since 1992. The hockey squad took home these two medals.

But Pakistan's top athlete, Arshad Nadeem, broke the four-decade wait by defeating second-place finisher Neeraj Chopra of India.

📌 Adidas recently launched a campaign featuring model Bella Hadid to promote the relaunch of their classic SL72 sneaker, which was originally released in 1972 - the same year as the Munich Olympics. However, this collaboration has sparked significant backlash due to the tragic events that occurred at those Olympics.

📌 In 1972, Palestinian militants from the group Black September attacked and killed 11 Israeli athletes during the Munich Olympics. Bella Hadid, who is of Palestinian descent, has been an outspoken critic of Israel's actions in Gaza. Her involvement in promoting a shoe tied to the Munich massacre has angered many, including the American Jewish Committee (AJC) and the Israeli government.

📌 The AJC stated that Adidas' choice of Hadid, a "vocal anti-Israel model," to represent a shoe commemorating the Munich Olympics was either a "massive oversight or intentionally inflammatory." Israel's Foreign Ministry accused Hadid of "spreading antisemitism and calling for violence against Israelis and Jews."

📌 In response to the backlash, Adidas issued an apology, stating: "We are conscious that connections have been made to tragic historical events - though these are completely unintentional - and we apologize for any upset or distress caused. As a result we are revising the remainder of the campaign."

📌 The company also emphasized its belief in sport as a unifying force and its commitment to championing diversity and equality. However, the incident has highlighted the ongoing tensions and sensitivities surrounding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, even in the context of sports and advertising.

Since then, it has constructed and gradually increased the number of settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Prior to its pullout in 2005, it established settlements in Gaza as well.

The UN and the vast majority of the international community consider the Palestinian territory as Israeli-occupied.

Tunisia’s Prime Minister urged European countries, on Wednesday, to increase financial assistance to his country and others to help tackle the flow of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, Reuters reports.

Tunisia has faced protests by local residents and extra financial costs over migrants arriving from other countries in the hope of traveling on to Europe by sea, risking perilous journeys on what, in many cases, are dilapidated boats.

Thousands of migrants are now concentrated in southern Tunisian towns such as Amra and Jbeniana, many of them fleeing poverty and conflict in Africa and the Middle East in the hope of a better life in Europe.

Israeli and US officials were hopeful last week about a potential ceasefire and hostage release deal between Israel and Hamas. The Palestinian militant group indicated willingness to compromise on a key issue. However, achieving an agreement remains uncertain despite these positive developments.There is optimism that a deal could be reached, especially after a senior Hamas official told CNN that the group is open to reconsidering its demand that Israel commit to a permanent ceasefire in Gaza before agreeing to a temporary truce. This agreement would also begin the process of releasing hostages still held in Gaza.Last week, a US official mentioned to CNN that a basic agreement framework is in place, and talks resumed on Friday in Doha. Egypt’s state-affiliated Al-Qahera News channel reported that discussions will continue in Cairo this week.However, a statement from the Israeli prime minister’s office on Sunday suggested doubts about the deal's progress. The statement outlined several principles Israel is not willing to compromise on, including the continuation of military operations in Gaza until all war objectives are met.

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, made a resolution on Sunday to pardon or commute the sentences of 2,654 convicts in honor of the Eid al-Adha and Ghadir Khum holidays, state television said.
The Iranian Constitution grants the supreme leader the authority to pardon or decrease the sentences of prisoners at the request of the chief of the court.
Khamenei grants pardons on a variety of occasions, including the anniversary of the 1979 revolution and religious holidays.

Geopolitics Review - 24th June 2024

Since the start of this conflict on October 7th, we’ve seen 38,151 Palestinians killed, 86,032 injured, and 1,139 Israelis killed. Gazan infrastructure has been destroyed, and aid isn’t being allowed in.

The Israeli operation made moves into Rafah in May, casting aside the international outcry not to invade the region. Israel has its goals of removing Hamas from power in the Gaza Strip and removing any security threats, and they’re going to continue on this path until they’ve achieved this.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is also incentivised individually. His rule as Prime Minister is part of a far-right coalition that wants to continue the war. One party in the coalition threatened to dissolve the government if Netanyahu was to agree to Biden’s recent peace proposal. It’s the far-right that typically most strongly opposes a Palestinian state and supports the expansion of settlements in the West Bank. To uphold his political career, Netanyahu has swayed further right. He also is facing corruption charges so prolonging the war could prolong the ongoing trial.

The war as it continues is raising tensions in the North between Israel and Hezbollah, and the international community continues to support the establishment of a Palestinian state, with 145 or 193 UN members supporting it. Even tensions are rising between Biden and Netanyahu. This week I’ll provide updates on the conflict and the rising tensions with many actors. Let’s get started with today’s piece.

A hotel in Kyoto, Japan, refused to accommodate an Israeli man, claiming possible ties to his country's military involved in the Gaza crisis, local media reported on Friday, according to Anadolu Agency.

According to Tokyo-based Kyodo News, the municipal government has informed Hotel Material in Higashiyama Ward that such an act violates a statute that prohibits hotels and other facilities from refusing to admit visitors unless in specific situations.

Following an investigation, authorities determined that the hotel's reasoning for rejecting the man's online booking "is not a legitimate reason for denying accommodation."

In the wake of Henley & Partners' Private Wealth Migration Report 2024, the UAE is on track to attract a record 6,700 millionaires by the end of this year, securing its status as the world's top "wealth magnet" for the third year running.

The UAE's luxurious lifestyle, golden visas, and low-tax environment have all contributed to its popularity. The Gulf state is predicted to attract nearly twice as many millionaires as its nearest rival, the United States, which expects 3,800 new billionaire inhabitants by the end of the year. Singapore is third, with an estimated net influx of 3,500 millionaires, followed by Canada and Australia.

Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh met with Iran's acting Foreign Minister, Ali Bagheri, in Qatar to explore methods to cease Israel's attack on the Gaza Strip, the Palestinian group announced on Thursday.

The talks between the two parties on Wednesday evening focused on Palestinian developments and efforts to halt Israel's assault on Gaza, according to a Hamas statement, Anadolu Agency reports.

Bagheri discussed Iranian efforts to support Palestinians in international forums such as the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the BRICS bloc of rising economies, and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, according to the statement.

Victims of Hamas' October 7 attack on Israel sued Iran, Syria, and North Korea on Monday, alleging that their governments provided the militants with the money, weaponry, and know-how required to carry out the assault, which sparked Israel's current war in Gaza.
The case, filed in federal court in New York, demands at least $4 billion in damages for orchestrating extrajudicial killings, hostage takings, and other atrocities for which the defendants supplied material support and resources.

According to the Anadolu Agency, Indonesia and Malaysia hailed the approval of a UN Security Council resolution on Tuesday that supports US President Joe Biden's Gaza ceasefire plan.

The resolution, written by the United States, gained 14 votes in favor from the 15-member Security Council on Monday, with Russia abstaining.

"The adoption of UNSC Resolution 2735 (2024) on the three-phase ceasefire proposal is a long overdue yet important step to stop the ongoing atrocities against the people of Palestine and towards achieving an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza," the Indonesian Foreign Ministry said in a statement regarding X.

A report from Reuters, Egypt has conducted mass arrests and illicit deportations of thousands of people escaping the Sudanese conflict.

According to the rights group, 12 incidences occurred between January and March this year in which Egyptian officials returned an estimated 800 Sudanese people without giving them the opportunity to claim refuge or dispute deportation decisions.

It further stated that it has thoroughly documented the cases of 27 Sudanese refugees apprehended between October 2023 and March 2024, 26 of whom were collectively expelled. Refugees have been confined in brutal and inhumane conditions prior to their deportation, it noted.

Syrian opposition militants have apparently been recruited for combat and security missions in many African nations, in what appears to be the most recent deployment of Syrian rebels overseas at the request of Turkey.

Several Syrian rebel sources told Middle East Eye that hundreds of fighters had been deployed to the African nations of Burkina Faso, Niger, and Nigeria. While some have apparently been assigned combat tasks against Daesh in the Sahel region, others have been assigned close protection or security roles to protect Turkish industries in those countries, such as factories and mines.

A lifesaving humanitarian agenda in Yemen, where 13.5 million people face food insecurity, must be a priority for international financial organizations. According to the World Food Program, over 5 million people in Yemen are at the brink of famine, and the child malnutrition rate is one of the world’s highest. The World Bank’s funding of $127 million is critically important support for this country which has struggled for over 6 years in the ongoing civil war. Word Bank Country Manager Tania Meyer stated “Food insecurity is one of the most pressing human development challenges facing Yemen.” The situation is already severe, and can still get even worse. The world must act with urgency.⁠

As reported by local media on Sunday, a coal mine explosion in northeastern Iran claimed the lives of at least 51 people, Anadolu reports.

According to the state news agency IRNA, the explosion was brought on by a sudden leak of carbon monoxide and methane on Saturday night in two blocks of the Tabas mine in the Khorasan region.

Approximately seventy people were at the mine when the explosion occurred, according to the local authorities.

Iranian authorities claimed that underground conditions made it difficult to conduct a quick rescue effort.

An investigation into the incident has been ordered by Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian.

Hollow Peace Propositions

Amid the never ending conflict between Ukraine and Russia, discussions about a potential peace settlement have gained a facade of momentum. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky’s recent suggestion of holding a referendum to let the Ukrainian people decide on territorial concessions is nothing more than a distraction. Zelensky’s statement, made during an interview with the French newspaper Le Monde, appears to be a desperate move to placate a war-weary populace.

The feasibility of such a referendum is laughable. Furthermore, the Ukrainian Constitution does not allow for a plebiscite on territorial changes, making the suggestion a political ruse. Despite these obvious hurdles, Zelensky’s simulated optimism about the prospects of peace, claiming his administration is committed to preparing a viable peace settlement by the end of the year is a ruse.

The UAE has led in mediating prisoner exchanges between Russia and Ukraine, showcasing its strong commitment to humanitarian efforts and international diplomacy. The most recent exchange saw 95 prisoners released from each side, marking the sixth successful exchange this year facilitated by the UAE.

Moscow has promised to retaliate against Ukrainian attacks within its borders after a drone allegedly set fire to a warehouse storing munitions, leading to a state of emergency in Russia’s Voronezh region in the southwest. The incident occurred in a settlement within the Podgorensky district, according to Voronezh governor Aleksandr Gusev on Sunday. Ukrainian sources claim the warehouse was targeted because it supplied ammunition to Russian troops in Ukraine.

Gusev reported that several unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) were detected and destroyed by air defense forces overnight, causing a fire and explosions at the warehouse site. He didn’t specify the settlement but confirmed a state of emergency there. Fortunately, no injuries were reported, although two elderly women were hospitalized for precautionary checks.

Emergency services, military personnel, and officials are currently on-site working to contain the situation. Around 50 people from nearby villages have been evacuated to temporary shelters, where they are receiving necessary assistance.

In a significant move to bolster Ukraine’s defenses against Russian aggression and advance the country’s bid for NATO membership, U.S. President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy signed a “historic” 10-year bilateral security agreement on Thursday.

The agreement, which was finalized on the sidelines of the G7 conference in Italy, aims to ensure continued U.S. support for Ukraine regardless of potential changes in American leadership, including the possibility of a Republican victory in the upcoming November election. The initiative seeks to cement long-term security ties and enhance Ukraine's defense capabilities amid ongoing conflict with Russia.

During a joint press conference, President Biden emphasized the importance of this agreement, stating, "Our goal is to strengthen Ukraine's credible defense and deterrence capabilities for the long term." He further directed a message to Russian President Vladimir Putin, asserting, "You cannot wait us out. You cannot divide us."

In addition to the bilateral security agreement, the G7 countries collectively agreed to provide Ukraine with a $50 billion loan, financed by profits from frozen Russian assets. This financial support is intended to stabilize Ukraine’s economy and support its war efforts.

President Zelenskiy praised the security agreement as a pivotal moment for Ukraine, describing it as a framework for a sustained effort to modernize the country’s outdated armed forces and a significant step towards NATO membership. Despite long-standing aspirations, Ukraine has not yet been granted NATO membership, largely due to the alliance's stipulation that an attack on one member is considered an attack on all under its Article Five clause.

The agreement stipulates that in the event of an armed attack or credible threat against Ukraine, senior U.S. and Ukrainian officials will convene within 24 hours to discuss and coordinate an appropriate response.

According to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Russia managed to destroy the Trypilska thermal power station, a major electricity provider for the Kyiv region, due to a shortage of air defense missiles.

Zelenskyy revealed in an interview with American broadcaster PBS that although 11 missiles were launched, only seven were intercepted. The remaining four successfully hit the Trypilska power station because there were no more available missiles for defense.

In other developments, Zelenskyy has signed a new mobilization law which will come into effect one month after its official publication. This legislation mandates men to update their draft information with authorities, increases payments for volunteers, and imposes additional penalties for those evading the draft.

How you can support Ukraine

As the war in Ukraine keeps raging, the humanitarian toll keeps mounting. The United Nations reports roughly 14 million people have been forced to flee their homes since the start of the Russian invasion. Scores of global nonprofits have responded to the crisis, delivering desperately needed aid to Ukrainians who have fled abroad and those who remain in the war-torn country. The NGOs include GlobalGiving — which has raised more than $48 million to provide shelter, water and economic assistance to refugees — and the International Committee of the Red Cross, which is providing medical equipment and emergency supplies and aiding civilian evacuation efforts.

At a Yad Binyamin conference organized by Israel Hayom today, Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich declared that halting humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip might be “justified and moral,” even if it means that two million Palestinians will go hungry.

"We are importing aid because we have nowhere else to go. In the world we live in today, we are unable to conduct a war. Until our captives are released, no one will allow us to inflict the deaths of two million civilians from hunger, even though it could be morally and legally justified. It is morally acceptable to swap humanitarianism for humanitarianism, but how can we act? We need worldwide legitimacy for this conflict because we are living in a specific context today," he declared.

Hamas Chief Ismail Haniyeh Killed in Iran Bomb Attack

Reports are emerging that Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, has been killed in a bomb attack in Iran. The incident occurred in the Iranian capital, Tehran.

Details of the Attack:

- The bomb attack targeted a vehicle carrying Haniyeh in the Iranian capital.
- The blast caused significant damage and casualties.
- Iranian authorities have confirmed the attack and are investigating.

Reactions:

- Hamas has not officially confirmed Haniyeh's death.
- Palestinian groups have denounced the attack.
- Israeli officials have declined to comment.

Implications:

- The killing of Haniyeh could lead to a power struggle within Hamas.
- The incident may escalate tensions between Iran and Israel.
- Regional stability and peace efforts may be impacted.

Russia has strongly condemned the killing of a senior Hamas leader, calling it a "political murder" and a "gross violation of international law". The Russian Foreign Ministry stated that the killing was a deliberate attack on a political figure and a blatant disregard for Palestinian sovereignty.

The Hamas leader, who was not named, was killed in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza. Israel has not commented on the incident, but it is believed to have been a targeted killing. Russia's condemnation of the attack reflects its support for the Palestinian cause and its criticism of Israel's actions in the region.

Russia's Foreign Ministry also called for an international investigation into the killing, stating that those responsible must be held accountable. The ministry expressed its condolences to the family of the deceased and the Palestinian people, and reiterated its support for a comprehensive and just settlement to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The incident has sparked widespread outrage and condemnation from across the globe, with many countries and organizations calling for restraint and an end to the cycle of violence in the region. The killing has also raised tensions between Israel and Hamas, which has vowed to retaliate for the attack.

The Knesset, the Israeli parliament, rejected the establishment of a Palestinian state.

The Israeli parliament passed a resolution against the two-state plan for peace in the Middle East, the first time in Israel's history that the parliament has passed such a resolution.

According to Israeli media, 68 members of parliament voted against the establishment of a Palestinian state in the resolution, while 9 members opposed the resolution.

The Knesset resolution stated that the Palestinian state would remain a threat to the existence of Israel and to Israeli citizens.

According to Israeli media, the resolution has dealt a blow to diplomatic efforts for peace in Israel and Arab countries.

Israel’s Organ Trafficking and Legal Immunity

Organ trafficking remains a pressing global issue, with ongoing allegations against Israel regarding the harvesting of organs from deceased Palestinians. The Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor recently accused Israeli forces of stealing organs from Palestinian bodies in Gaza, including livers, kidneys, hearts, cochleas, and corneas. Medical professionals in Gaza have corroborated these claims, despite denials from Israeli authorities.

Recent reports continue to underscore historical accusations against Israel for organ theft. Investigations have documented instances of organ harvesting from Palestinian corpses for medical research and transplants. In 2014, an Israeli television investigation revealed the extraction of skin from deceased Palestinians and African workers for medical purposes. These consistent reports indicate Israel's involvement in the global black market for human organs.

The involvement of Israeli military authorities in organ trafficking has been suggested by investigations, which indicate the participation of medical professionals and students in these activities. Despite persistent allegations and evidence, Israel denies any wrongdoing.

These allegations not only raise serious human rights concerns but also highlight broader issues regarding accountability and the rule of law. The need for international scrutiny and robust legal frameworks is evident to address these allegations impartially and ensure justice.

These ongoing challenges underscore the importance of comprehensive investigations and international cooperation to uphold human rights and the rule of law effectively.

Judges at the International Criminal Court (ICC) concluded on Thursday that the United Kingdom can present legal reasons to judges deliberating the prosecution's request for arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, Reuters reported.

Court documents made public on Thursday showed that the UK, an ICC member state, filed a request with the Court earlier this month to provide written observations on whether "the Court can exercise jurisdiction over Israeli nationals, in circumstances where Palestine cannot exercise criminal jurisdiction over Israeli nationals (under) the Oslo Accords".

Israeli occupation troops blocked the call to Friday prayer from being aired from the minarets of the Ibrahimi Mosque in the occupied West Bank city of Hebron and stopped Palestinians from entering the Muslim shrine for prayers today.

The director of the Islamic Endowments in Hebron, Ghassan Al-Rajabi, informed the WAFA news site that the occupying troops had stopped broadcasting the adhan, or call to prayer, for Friday services, forcing many worshippers to offer their prayers outside in the courtyard. This is the mosque's 23rd consecutive year that the adhan has been prohibited.

Israeli soldiers positioned at military checkpoints close to the mosque inspected locals and their identity credentials, according to Al-Rajabi.

Čínský těžký kulomet W-85,kulomet je i znám pod označením Type 85. Slouží už 80.let. Samotný kulomet váží 18.5 kg a s trjnoškou 39 kg. Ráže je 12.7x108mm. Kadence je 550 - 600 ran/min. Úštová rychlost náboje je 850 m/s. K zásobování munice slouží pás s náboji. Vznikla i verze pro tanky,které mají označení QJC-88. Je ve výzbroji Alžírska,Afghanistánu,Bangladéše,Kambodže,Iráku,Iránu,Libye,Mali,Rwandě,Jižího Sudánu,Sri Lanky,Sůdanu,Sýrie, dále slouží u Tamilských Tygrů,Lidové obrané jednotky a u Vlajky Syrie. V Alžírsku je ve výrobě v licenci. A ve výrobě v Sudánu. Rwanda je mají mírové jednotky v Darfůru. Kulomet byl použítý za války v Darfuru,v konfliktu Severním Mali,Syrské občanské války,Lybijské občanské války,Irácké občanské válce a v Jemenské občanské válce. #w85 #china🇨🇳 #heavymachinegun #127108 #80s #qjc88 #algerienne🇩🇿 #afghanistan🇦🇫 #bangadesh #cambodia #iraq🇮🇶 #iran🇮🇷 #lybia #mali #rwanda🇷🇼 #southsudan #syria🇸🇾 #darfurwar #malinorthafrica #syriacivilwar #lybiancivilwar #iraqcivilwar #yemencivilwar #jonzus @militarytechnology

India has strongly dismissed a recent Reuters report alleging that European buyers diverted Indian-made artillery shells to Ukraine without Delhi's intervention. The report claimed that this transfer has been ongoing for over a year, despite protests from Moscow.

The Ministry of External Affairs has labeled the report as "speculative" and "misleading," emphasizing that India has an impeccable track record of adhering to international arms export regulations. India's spokesperson, Randhir Jaiswal, reaffirmed the country’s commitment to non-proliferation and strict compliance with its export rules.

While Moscow has yet to respond, India continues to call for diplomacy and dialogue to resolve the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has dismissed the China-Brazil peace initiative for the war in Ukraine, labeling it as "destructive" and merely a political statement. He criticized the proposal for not consulting Kyiv, claiming it disrespects Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. Zelenskyy expressed frustration over Russia’s support for the initiative, adding that meaningful peace talks require action from Russian President Vladimir Putin. The Ukrainian leader highlighted his own peace terms, including the full withdrawal of Russian troops and restoring Ukraine’s 1991 borders, contrasting with the China-Brazil approach.

So heres Day 25 of my history class, educated talk on important events in history and issues that need to be spoken about today!

Today It is something different and sadly is still currently  waging/going on right now. Today i will be giving you a brief understanding of the Syrian and Yemeni Civil war. 

So the Syrian Civil war started in 2011  It is an ongoing multi-sided civil war in Syria fought between the Ba'athist Syrian Arab Republic led by Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, along with domestic and foreign allies, and various domestic and foreign forces opposing both the Syrian government and each other in varying combinations. This also involved the rise of a horrifying extremist/terrorist group who committed acts of terror killing thousands whilst trying to promote Extremism and terror using Religion (Will not be naming them due to the respect for all victims that suffered at the hands of these horrible people) The terrorist group were thankfully dealt with and eliminated by Syrian National Army amongst other allies who helped like the US. The war is still ongoing.

The Yemeni Civil War is is an ongoing conflict that began in 2015 between two factions: the Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi-led Yemeni government and the Houthi armed movement, along with their supporters and allies. Both claim to constitute the official government of Yemen. War still ongoing. 

Lessons learnt here. Government power is real and money talks. Were all categorized and selfish and narcism and Fascism come into play here. Always be nice to your peers amd be equal. Dont categorize, welcome people of all backgrounds/walk of life. Everyone is here for a reason and most importantly, respect peoples beliefs/faith/opinions and be kind!

New podcast episode! President Joe Biden ends support in Yemen Civil War:

President Joe Biden is ending the United States’ support for Saudi Arabia in the Yemen civil war. Yemen has been in a civil war since 2014, it is a proxy war between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Earlier this month, President Biden called off U.S. support for the war, and instead focused on ending the war.
*
The United Nations describes Yemen as the world’s biggest humanitarian crisis, with 80% of its people in need and millions on the verge of a large-scale famine. According to UNICEF, with the pandemic spreading, Yemen is facing an “emergency within an emergency.”

Do you see the Biden administration’s act for diplomacy valid and optimistic, maybe even realistically successful? 
Should we maintain military presence for the sake of national security? 
Should we get ourselves involved in humanitarian issues or stay out of them?

Russia has warned Western countries about the serious consequences of allowing Ukraine to launch deep strikes into Russian territory using Western-supplied missiles. The statement from Moscow comes amid ongoing tensions and conflict in the region.

Earlier this month, Ukraine launched an attack on Russia's western Kursk region, marking the most significant foreign strike on Russian soil since World War II. In response, Russian President Vladimir Putin promised that Russia would respond appropriately to the attack.

Russia's Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, who has held his position for over two decades, accused the West of provoking a broader conflict by even considering Ukraine's request to relax the restrictions on using foreign weapons. Lavrov described such actions as "playing with fire."

He also emphasized the potential global consequences of such a move, warning that if World War III were to occur, it would not be confined to Europe. Lavrov cautioned that Western leaders who control nuclear weapons should recognize the dangers of escalating tensions.

Since its invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Russia has repeatedly warned of the risks of a broader war involving nuclear powers. However, President Putin has maintained that Russia does not desire a direct conflict with NATO, the U.S.-led military alliance.

Lavrov's comments come as Russia reviews its nuclear policy. According to Russia's 2020 nuclear doctrine, the use of nuclear weapons would be considered only if the nation faced an existential threat, whether from nuclear, mass destruction, or conventional weapons.

Yemen is going through one of the worst man made humanitarian crises as a result of the ongoing civil war. Though Yemen was always besieged with internal conflicts since its unification in 1990, the severity of fighting and destruction is the current phase of civil war since 2015 is unimaginable.

Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. As of early this year, it has added another layer to the war: the failing healthcare infrastructure and the rise of COVID-19. 

Much of the current conflict can only be understood as a result of the events of the latter half of the 20th century. A brief look at the history that has shaped today’s wars in Yemen is given in  a series of six short explanatory articles.

Israel has agreed to a series of “humanitarian pauses” in Gaza to allow for the vaccination of children against polio, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said.
The campaign will aim to vaccinate around 640,000 children across the Gaza strip and will begin on Sunday, senior WHO official Rik Peeperkorn said.
It will be rolled out in three separate stages, across the central, southern and northern parts of the strip. During each stage, fighting will pause for three consecutive days between 06:00 and 15:00 local time.

Israel is tightening the noose around Palestinians by forcibly transferring them into an increasingly narrow area no more than 10 percent of the Gaza Strip. Even before the war, the Gaza Strip was one of the most densely populated places in the world, with 2.3 million Palestinians – two-thirds of them refugees from areas conquered by Zionist forces in 1948 – concentrated in 141 square miles. Since October, two percent of Gaza’s population has been killed, and many more injured or gone missing. But nearly everyone has been displaced, many multiple times.

The Government Media Office in Gaza published a timeline demonstrating how Israeli evacuation orders beginning in November have forced Palestinians from the north of the territory to the south under the threat of death, pushing much of the population to a so-called humanitarian zone along the coast of southern Gaza. Since 16 August, the Israeli army has issued at least five evacuation orders directing Palestinians in central Gaza, primarily in the town of Deir al-Balah, to flee to an ever-shrinking area of the Gaza Strip.

On 25 August, patients, staff and displaced families inside and around the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir Al-Balah packed up what they could and fled.

Swedish prosecutors said on Wednesday that they intend to charge two individuals with lighting fire to copies of the Qur'an in a series of instances last year that sparked indignation in the Muslim world and stoked worries of Islamist strikes, Reuters reported.

The two men committed "offenses of agitation against an ethnic or national group" four separate times by burning Islam's sacred book outside a mosque and in other public places, according to the Swedish Prosecution Authority.

Sweden's internal security service boosted its terrorism warning level in response to the burnings, while neighboring Denmark, which also saw a surge in Qur'an burnings, tightened its legislation to criminalize the practice.

Russia expressed skepticism towards Ukrainian President Zelensky’s invitation to a second summit aimed at ending the war in Ukraine. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stressed the need to define what constitutes a “peace summit” before considering participation, highlighting that the first summit did not meet these criteria. Zelensky’s invitation marks a shift from his prior stance, as Russia and China were excluded from the initial summit in Switzerland last month. Attended by over 90 states, the June 15 summit aimed to address the Ukraine conflict. The Kremlin criticized the exclusion of Russia, deeming such discussions “absurd.”

NATO allies selected Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte as NATO’s next boss, as the war in Ukraine rages on its doorstep and uncertainty hangs over the United States’ future attitude to the transatlantic alliance.

Rutte’s appointment became a formality after his only rival for the post, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis, announced last week that he had quit the race, having failed to gain traction.

NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg earlier said that the alliance had no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine, despite many of its members supplying Kyiv with weapons since Russia’s invasion.

“NATO has no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine,” Stoltenberg said during a visit to Finland, adding that the alliance was seeking “long term financial commitment to ensure that we stand by Ukraine for as long as it takes”.

“Over the last months, we have seen some gaps, some delays in the provision of military support to Ukraine,” Stoltenberg said, adding: “we need to ensure that that doesn’t happen again.”

The visit marked Stoltenberg’s first to Finland since the country joined NATO in April 2023, prompted by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, thereby leaving decades of military non-alignment behind.

Stoltenberg’s visit came as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday joined Western leaders in France to commemorate D-Day.

While there, Zelensky is due to meet US President Joe Biden for talks on how Ukraine can gain background after recent Russian advances.

Asked to comment on the risk of a Russian attack against a Nato member, Stoltenberg replied: “We don’t see an imminent military threat against any NATO ally.”

“This idea that there’s a kind of a countdown to the next war is wrong.”

Pakistan is grappling with the decision to attend the Ukraine Peace Summit in Switzerland on June 15-16. The summit, focusing on the ongoing conflict in Ukraine following Russia's invasion in 2022, presents a significant international engagement for Islamabad. However, Pakistan's participation remains uncertain due to its long-standing policy of non-alignment.

Spokesperson for Pakistan's Foreign Office, Mumtaz Zahra Baloch, confirmed last week during a briefing that Pakistan had received an invitation to the summit. "The invitation is under consideration," Baloch stated, highlighting the careful deliberation underway in Islamabad.

Sources in local media suggest that Pakistan might refrain from attending the summit to maintain its neutral stance. The absence of Russia from the summit, despite being a key player in the conflict, has also raised questions about the efficacy and impartiality of the gathering.

China, another influential player, has already decided to abstain from the summit, citing the exclusion of Russia as a significant flaw. Beijing's decision has been noted in Islamabad, which often aligns its foreign policy closely with that of China. Analysts believe that Pakistan's final decision may hinge on further diplomatic pressures from Western nations seeking broader participation from the Global South.

The backdrop to this summit and Pakistan's dilemma is rooted in the complex geopolitical landscape that emerged following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the time, Pakistan's then-Prime Minister Imran Khan was visiting Moscow, a trip that, despite its coincidental timing, drew international scrutiny and criticism.

Since then, Pakistan has navigated a cautious diplomatic path, avoiding outright condemnation of Russia's actions while seeking to maintain balanced relations. This delicate balancing act was evident as Pakistan hosted the Ukrainian Foreign Minister and dispatched humanitarian aid, yet refrained from supporting U.S.-backed resolutions against Russia at the United Nations.

Breaking News: Russia has launched a new military offensive in Ukraine, starting earlier than anticipated and with fewer soldiers, according to experts. 🇷🇺⚔️🇺🇦

Analysts suggest that Russia’s strategy was to strike ahead of the anticipated US aid to Ukraine, aiming to gain an advantage before the additional support could bolster Ukrainian defenses. However, the offensive’s early start and limited troop numbers have raised questions about its potential effectiveness. 🌍❗

Military experts are closely monitoring the situation, noting that the premature timing and insufficient manpower might undermine Russia‘s efforts on the battlefield. The geopolitical stakes are high, and this move signals a critical phase in the ongoing conflict. 🕊️🔍

Vladimir Putin was sworn in as Russia's president for a record fifth term, promising to lead the country through its "difficult" period. The inauguration at the Grand Kremlin Palace was boycotted by the United States, United Kingdom, and several European Union countries amid ongoing tensions over Russia’s war in Ukraine. In his speech, Putin emphasized national unity and resilience, stating that the country would overcome obstacles and emerge victorious. Critics questioned the legitimacy of the election and the conduct of Putin's rule, citing issues such as the death of political rival Alexey Navalny and the crackdown on opposition.

Russia Steps Up Offensive in Eastern Ukraine

Russia has deployed more troops to Ocheretyne in eastern Ukraine as part of an offensive, but Ukrainian forces maintain control of most of the village and anticipate US arms deliveries to bolster their position, according to the Ukrainian military, Reuters reports.

The Russians have advanced through several villages in the east since capturing Avdiivka in February, as Ukrainian forces faced dwindling supplies. Fierce fighting continues in Ocheretyne, but Ukrainian forces claim to have two-thirds of the village under control. Russian forces are also targeting the strategic town of Chasiv Yar to the north, aiming to capture it as part of their larger push to control the Donbas region.

Despite being outnumbered and outgunned, Ukrainian morale received a boost with the approval of a major US aid package containing military assistance. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned of a possible Russian offensive in late May or June.

📌 In the dead of night in May, Russia launched a Kinzhal hypersonic missile at the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, reaching speeds up to Mach 10 (about 7,700 mph). The U.S. had sent a Patriot air defense system to Ukraine to counter Russian missiles, successfully intercepting the Kinzhal missile and others. The Patriot system has demonstrated its capabilities by intercepting Russian aircraft and missiles in Ukraine. The U.S. Army is planning to replace the Patriot system with an Integrated Air and Missile Defense system, but the Patriot’s recent success has attracted global interest.

Al-Habbash stated that although more than 120 countries have supported UN resolutions on Palestine, they have not yet been put into effect.

According to Reuters, Saudi Arabia's Dunya Abu Talib defeated Israel's Abishag Semberg in the women's flyweight taekwondo round of 16 at the Olympic Games in Paris today.

After winning 2-6 5-4 10-0, Abu Talib—the first Saudi woman to receive straight qualification to the Olympics—finished the match with two head and two body kicks.

The spectators cheered both fighters on with loud voices.

Semberg expressed her disappointment with her performance, citing the significance of representing Israel on the world's largest sporting platform.

Digital settler colonialism, defined most recently in Kawsar Ali’s publication on the integration between technology, race, and cyberspace, is the practice of using the internet to perpetuate the legacy of settler states.

Indeed, studies hinting at digital settler colonialism date back to 1972 when Herbert I. Schiller explored the impact of digital communication tools enhancing Western cultural domination but received little press attention. Attempts to explain relationships between digital platforms and the politics of war have appeared more frequently following Wendy K. Chun’s characterization of race and technology as not cohabitating factors, but the former as a technique of the latter – for the one that uses, it and the one used by it. 

In today’s context, Big Tech’s maintenance of the content of Israel’s latest genocide of Palestinians in Gaza via social media and beyond catches the convergence of Big Tech digital colonialism and Israeli settler colonialism, translating previous suspicions to reality.
(Image Credit: The New York Times)

Regarding Turkey's peace efforts in Syria, Erdogan stated: "The United States and Iran should welcome these positive developments and support the process to end immense suffering."

Five members of Nahdliyin met with President Isaac Herzog in Israel. This meeting has caused significant repercussions because the Executive Board of Nahdlatul Ulama (PBNU) never gave permission for it.

PBNU Chairman Savic Ali expressed regret over the five Nahdliyin meeting with Israel's President Isaac Herzog. Savic stated that the visit by the five Nahdliyin was not in the name of NU.
"The visit was likely made in a personal capacity. We do not know their purpose or who sponsored them. This is a regrettable action," said Savic, as quoted by the official NU website, Monday (15/7/2024).

Savic assessed that the visit by the five Nahdliyin resulted from a lack of understanding of geopolitics and NU's organizational policies, as well as the sentiments of all NU members. He said PBNU does not yet know who sponsored the departure of the five Nahdliyin to Israel.
He added that although the visit was personal, the five are known as NU members and activists. This, according to Savic, worsens NU's image in the public eye. Especially since PBNU and Nahdliyin's stance is in support of Palestine and condemns Israel's military aggression.

"Israel still does not recognize Palestine and continues its military aggression, causing thousands of casualties. Israel continues to drop bombs and bullets on Palestinians. The number of victims is enormous, mostly civilians," he said.
PBNU Secretary General Saifullah Yusuf stated that they would summon the five Nahdliyin who met with Israel's President Isaac Herzog. PBNU will clarify the background of the departure of these five young figures.

"These five individuals did not receive a mandate from PBNU, nor did they ever seek permission from PBNU," he said.
.

In line with a report in Yedioth Ahronoth, Avigdor Lieberman, the head of the opposition Yisrael Beiteinu Party, has stated that "Israel is losing the war in Gaza" and warned that "Israeli deterrence has declined to zero." Lieberman also called Defense Minister Yoav Gallant's handling of the conflict a "failure," noting that he is directly responsible after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

He went on to say that without a clear plan for the battle, Israeli soldiers and officers in Rafah are frustrated, and the government is unable to make a choice or win victory in the south or north.

Israel's Walla website stated earlier this week that the Israeli occupation army is experiencing a shortage of soldiers and is attempting to construct a new division that will be established to handle a variety of tasks.

Satan and Lucifer: The Duality of Light and Shadow

In the shadow of conflicts where hatred is woven, Satan, the horned god, amuses and provokes us, His malevolent grin poisons the hearts, de
The armies tear each other apart under his dark lightning.

On the table of destiny, the figurines fall, Chaos reigns supreme, death in numbers, Souls in suffering, trapped in war, Under the cruel gaze of Satan, the sinister father.

But beyond the darkness, a light rises, Lucifer, the bringer of flame, with a noble dream, On the same table, he watches tenderly, Yesterday's enemies reconcile, in joy.

His face illuminated with divine gentleness, He lights the paths to finer ways, Hearts untangle, hands finally clasp, Peace settles, under his serene gaze.

Thus goes the duality of this fragile world, Between shadow and light, an eternal exile, Satan and Lucifer, two sides of the same mirror, Reveal our choices, our essence, our hope.

In the tumult of conflicts, let us seek clarity, For even in the heart of shadows, hope can shine, May Lucifer's light guide our steps, And may Satan be but an echo of the past, already.

Anadolu Agency reports that Cuba opted on Friday to join South Africa's complaint against Israel before the International Court of Justice.

According to Radio Havana Cuba, under its duties to the agreement on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, Cuba will use its right as a third country to convey its interpretation of the agreement, which it claims Israel has flagrantly violated in Gaza.

The case seeks to put an end to atrocities against Palestinians caused by Israel's disproportionate and indiscriminate use of force in Gaza, which is illegally occupied.

On October 7, 2023, Israel faced an unexpected attack by Hamas, leading to immense loss of life and a breach of its defense systems. It has been a year of attack on Israel, the region is still mired in conflict. Missile launches and rising tensions in the Middle-East have worsened the humanitarian concerns in Gaza, leaving innumerable dead and displaced. The global powers remain divided on the conflict, with no peaceful resolution in sight yet.

Both Israel and India share a tragic bond as victims of terrorism from neighboring threats, standing united against this menace that endangers regional peace. India’s support for Israel is unwavering. While condemning the attacks, India continues to advocate for dialogue, peace, and justice, recognizing the humanitarian toll on civilians. Israel’s right to self-defense is recognized, and we stand in advocating peace during these challenging times. Both nations remain committed to defending their people from the constant threat of terror.

🕌 De acordo com a imprensa internacional, os Houthis do Iêmen continuam a atacar navios ocidentais que passam pelo Mar Vermelho apesar de todas as garantias de retaliação do Ocidente.

Os Houthis são militantes fundamentalistas do Iêmen que, pelo menos desde 2014, estão em confronto aberto contra as forças do governo do país e contra tropas sauditas - importantes aliados do Iêmen. 

Recebem apoio, financiamento e treinamento do Irã e cumprem o papel de verdadeiro proxy no embate que existe entre iranianos e sauditas pela hegemonia do Oriente Médio, quase como uma verdadeira Guerra Fria.

Graças aos ataques Houthis no Mar Vermelho, países ocidentais decretaram um ultimato ao grupo para que todo e qualquer ato ofensivo nestes mares cessasse, algo que não foi e, ao que parece, nem será correspondido pelo grupo islâmico. 

Nesta quinta-feira, dia 4, um barco não tripulado Houthi se aproximou a poucas milhas de distância dos navios da marinha americana, segundo a imprensa global, o que pode ser entendido como uma verdadeira provocação e isso pode representar o escalar dos conflitos no Oriente Médio.

Pemerintah Britania Raya mengumumkan bahwa mereka telah memberikan dana sebesar $205 Juta USD untuk menunjang keberlangsungan kemanusiaan di Yaman pada Jumat, (28/7). 

Berdasarkan laporan dari Kantor Luar Negeri Inggris, sana tersebut diberikan dalam rangka menunjang kebutuhan primer di Yaman seperti alat-alat kesehatan, bahan pangan, dan perairan. 

Selain itu, melalui unggahannya di Twitter resmi, Kementerian Luar Negeri Inggris mengonfirmasi telah meluncurkan program kemanusiaan baru dalam rangka memberikan dukungan kesehatan yang krusial bagi perempuan dan anak-anak Yaman. 

"Program empat tahun £ 160 juta ($205 Juta USD) akan memberikan perawatan kesehatan primer, termasuk nutrisi, kebersihan air dan sanitasi serta layanan kesehatan seksual dan reproduksi untuk beberapa yang paling rentan di Yaman," ucap pihak Kementerian Luar Negeri Inggris. 

Diadakannya program tersebut juga bertujuan untuk mengurangi potensi kematian dan penyakit yang terjadi pada perempuan dan anak-anak. 

Menteri Luar Negeri James mengatakan," Konflik di Yaman terus menyebabkan rasa sakit dan penderitaan bagi jutaan orang Yaman, dengan wanita dan anak-anak khususnya membayar harga yang mahal (kesehatan)," ucapnya. 

"Inggris tetap berkomitmen untuk mengatasi krisis kemanusiaan di Yaman, dan program wanita dan anak-anak Yaman yang baru akan memberikan dukungan penting kepada yang paling rentan," lanjut James Cleverly.

Sebagai informasi, Yaman telah dideklarasikan sebagai 'failed state' atau negara yang gagal dalam menjaga kesejahteraan masyarakatnya. Hal tersebut dikarenakan negara tersebut telah menjadi korban perang antara pasukan pemerintah dan kelompok Houthi (kelompok Islam Syiah yang memihak pada Iran) selama sembilan tahun. 

Perang tersebut telah menempatkan negara itu pada krisis kemanusiaan dan menyebabkan ekonomi negara kehilangan $126 M USD. 

Perang sipil yang terjadi di Yaman juga telah menyebabkan masyarakatnya bergantung pada bantuan internasional. 

(Sumber: Middle East Monitor)

La plenaria del Parlamento europeo ha approvato a larga maggioranza, oggi a Strasburgo, una risoluzione che chiede agli Stati membri di togliere le restrizioni esistenti per le forniture di armi e munizioni all'Ucraina, che in certi casi ne impediscono l'uso per attaccare obiettivi in territorio russo. La risoluzione è stata approvata con 425 voti a favore, 131 contro e 63 astensioni Il paragrafo 8 della risoluzione "invita gli Stati membri a revocare immediatamente le restrizioni all'uso dei sistemi d'arma occidentali forniti all'Ucraina contro legittimi obiettivi militari sul territorio russo, in quanto ciò ostacola la capacità dell'Ucraina di esercitare pienamente il suo diritto all'autodifesa ai sensi del diritto pubblico internazionale e lascia l'Ucraina esposta ad attacchi contro la sua popolazione e le sue infrastrutture".

‼️Il Parlamento europeo approva a larghissima maggioranza la risoluzione a sostegno dell'Ucraina nella quale si chiede, tra le altre cose, di togliere le restrizioni alle armi per colpire la Russia più in profondità. Come hanno votato i partiti italiani?

External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Tuesday held wide-ranging discussions with his German counterpart Annalena Baerbock and took stock of the India-Germany Strategic Partnership, covering areas such as trade, defence and security.
Jaishankar, who arrived here from Saudi Arabia after attending the first India-Gulf Cooperation Council Ministerial Meeting for Strategic Dialogue, said they also exchanged views on Ukraine, Gaza and the Indo-Pacific region.

External Affairs Minister (EAM) S. Jaishankar shared that he had an exchange of views on several global issues, including the situations in Ukraine, Gaza, and the Indo-Pacific region. He also expressed his anticipation of welcoming German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock to India for the 7th Intergovernmental Consultations.

In a press statement alongside Baerbock, Jaishankar stated, "We had a productive discussion on the state of the world, covering a wide range of topics. Our conversation included Prime Minister Narendra Modi's recent visit to Ukraine, the ongoing conflict in Gaza and its wider implications, and other developments in West Asia and the Middle East."

He further mentioned that they focused on the Indo-Pacific region and briefly discussed events occurring in their respective neighborhoods. "Our engagement in defense and security has seen significant growth, including the first-ever air exercises this year. We look forward to welcoming German naval ships to Goa next month. Our policy dialogues and exchanges have been mutually beneficial, and we are eager to explore closer cooperation between our defense industries," Jaishankar added.

Jaishankar highlighted India's plans to establish 12 new industrial zones across the country, presenting new opportunities for collaboration with Germany. He noted, "Currently, our trade stands at approximately $30 billion annually, with German investments in India around $25 million, and slightly lower investments from our side. However, there remains vast untapped potential for growth."

प्रधानमंत्री नरेंद्र मोदी अमेरिका के तीन दिवसीय दौरे पर हैं। इसी बीच उन्होंने न्यूयॉर्क में फिलिस्तीन के राष्ट्रपति महमूद अब्बास से मुलाकात की। पीएम मोदी ने बातचीत के दौरान गाजा में चल रहे युद्ध पर मानवीय स्थिति को लेकर गहरी चिंता व्यक्त की। विदेश मंत्रालय के प्रवक्ता रणधीर जायसवाल ने बताया कि "प्रधानमंत्री नरेंद्र मोदी ने गाजा में मानवीय स्थिति पर गहरी चिंता व्यक्त की, साथ ही फिलिस्तीन के लोगों के लिए भारत से हमेशा समर्थन की बात कही। पीएम मोदी ने इजराइल-फिलिस्तीन मुद्दे पर युद्ध विराम, बंधकों की रिहाई और वार्ता व कूटनीति के मार्ग पर लौटने का आह्वान किया।" उन्होंने जोर देकर कहा कि "केवल दो राष्ट्र समाधान ही क्षेत्र में स्थायी शांति और स्थिरता प्रदान कर सकता है। भारत फिलिस्तीन को मान्यता देने वाले पहले देशों में से एक था। पीएम ने संयुक्त राष्ट्र में फिलिस्तीन की सदस्यता के लिए भारत के निरंतर समर्थन को दोहराया।"

I servizi di sicurezza russi (Fsb) hanno aperto un'inchiesta contro i due giornalisti della Rai che hanno realizzato un reportage dalla regione al confine di Kursk, tetro di un'offensiva delle truppe ucraine. L'accusa è di aver attraversato "illegalmente" il confine, entrando nella Federazione russa dall'Ucraina. Lo ha riferito il servizio stampa dell'Fsb come riportano le agenzie russe.

L'Fsb "ha aperto un'indagine penale" contro la giornalista Stefania Battistini e l'operatore Simone Traini per "attraversamento illegale della frontiera", hanno riferito i Servizi in un comunicato. L'ambasciatrice italiana in Russia, Cecilia Piccioni, è stata convocata a Mosca dal ministero degli Esteri in relazione al caso.l'Fsb ha anche fatto sapere che sta effettuando "una valutazione giuridica dei materiali distribuiti dai media che indicano la presenza sul territorio del posto di controllo russo di Sudzha del corrispondente Nick Paton Walsh". "Sulla base dei cui risultati verrà presa una decisione procedurale", si legge nel comunicato rilanciato dalle agenzie russe.

Come i due inviati della Rai, anche Nick Paton Walsh della Cnn ha firmato un reportage dalla città di Sudzha, di cui le truppe ucraine hanno rivendicato il controllo nell'ambito della loro offensiva in corso nella regione di Kursk da oltre 10 giorni.

Yulia #Navalnaya, vedova di Alexei #Navalny, arrestata in contumacia da un tribunale di Mosca per partecipazione a una comunità estremista e inserita in una lista internazionale di ricercati.

‼️Un tribunale di Mosca ha ordinato l'arresto in contumacia di Yulia Navalnaya con l'accusa di coinvolgimento in un gruppo estremista. Lo scrive RIA Novosti che cita il ;;servizio stampa del tribunale. Il tribunale "ha scelto una misura preventiva sotto forma di detenzione per un periodo di 2 mesi. Il periodo viene calcolato dal momento dell'estradizione nel territorio della Federazione Russa o dal momento della detenzione nel territorio della Federazione Russa", riferisce il tribunale. La corte ha chiarito che Navalnaya è stata inserita nella lista internazionale dei ricercati perché "si è nascosta dalle autorità investigative".

🚨🇷🇺 Il primo commento di Yulia Navalnaya: "Oh, non c'è una procedura normale? Un agente straniero, poi un caso penale, poi un arresto?! Quando scrivete di questo, per favore non dimenticate di scrivere la cosa principale: Vladimir #Putin è un assassino e un criminale di guerra. Il suo posto è in prigione, e non da qualche parte all'Aja, in una cella accogliente con una TV, ma in #Russia - nella stessa colonia e nella stessa cella di 2 metri per 3 in cui ha ucciso Alexei".

Aggiornamento in corso.
