Doval's Moscow Mission: A Delicate Dance of Diplomacy 

Ajit Doval, India's National Security Adviser, recently visited Moscow to attend the BRICS NSA meeting and hold bilateral talks with Russian officials. This strategic move has sparked interest among geopolitical analysts and experts.

Delivering Messages from PM Modi 📨

Ajit Doval, India's National Security Adviser, recently visited Moscow to attend
Doval's visit was seen as a crucial moment to deliver messages from Prime Minister Narendra Modi to Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian National Security Advisor Nikolai Patrushev. This highlights India's expanding role in global diplomacy and its efforts to find a peaceful resolution to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

Exploring Diplomatic Solutions 

Doval's discussions with Russian and Chinese counterparts aimed to explore diplomatic solutions to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. With India's commitment to peace and diplomacy, this move could potentially pave the way for a peaceful resolution.

Expert Views 💬

According to foreign affairs expert Robinder Sachdev, Doval's visit has multiple objectives, including participation in the BRICS NSA meeting, delivering messages from PM Modi, and exploring diplomatic solutions to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Sachdev noted that the US and the West are surprised by India's changing gears in diplomacy towards the conflict.

A Delicate Dance of Diplomacy 

Doval's visit to Moscow signifies India's growing influence in global diplomacy and its commitment to finding peaceful solutions to conflicts. However, this delicate dance of diplomacy requires careful navigation to avoid taking sides and maintain relationships with all parties involved.

Conclusion 📝

Doval's Moscow mission demonstrates India's willingness to engage in global diplomacy and find peaceful solutions to conflicts. As the world watches, India's role in shaping global events becomes increasingly significant.

The victims, including Mohammad Sufiyan from Telangana, were lured by a job scam and made to endure inhumane conditions, with one man losing his life. They were forced into military service and had their communication restricted. Russia had agreed to India's demand to ensure early release of Indian nationals working with the Russian military as support staff after PM Modi "very strongly" raised the issue with President Vladimir Putin during his visit.

विदेश मंत्री एस जयशंकर ने मंगलवार को कहा कि रूस और यूक्रेन को बातचीत करनी होगी और भारत हमेशा सलाह देने के लिए तैयार हैI उन्होंने कहा कि यूक्रेन संघर्ष को युद्ध के मैदान पर हल नहीं किया जा सकताI बर्लिन में जर्मन विदेश मंत्रालय के वार्षिक राजदूत सम्मेलन में सवालों का जवाब देते हुए, जयशंकर ने बताया कि भारत ने 'चीन से व्यापार के लिए अपने दरवाजे बंद नहीं किए हैं', लेकिन यह देखना होगा कि किस क्षेत्र में और किन शर्तों पर व्यापार किया जाता हैI
रूस-यूक्रेन युद्ध पर उन्होंने कहा, 'हमें नहीं लगता कि यह संघर्ष युद्ध के मैदान पर हल होने वाला हैI किसी स्तर पर, कुछ बातचीत करनी होगीI जब भी बातचीत होगी, दोनों पक्षों, रूस और यूक्रेन, को शामिल होना होगाI' यह टिप्पणी सोमवार को रियाद में रूसी विदेश मंत्री सर्गेई लावरोव के साथ 'सार्थक बातचीत' के एक दिन बाद आई हैI

Russia, Ukraine Will Have to Negotiate, India Ready to Give Advice: Jaishankar
External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar on Tuesday (September 10) said that the Russia-Ukraine conflict cannot be resolved on the battlefield.

He added that Russia and Ukraine will have to negotiate and in case they want advice, India is always willing to give, reported

Jaishankar made the remarks while responding to questions at the Annual Ambassadors’ Conference of the German Foreign Office in Berlin.

A day before, he had held a conversation with his Russian counterpart Sergey Lavrov on the sidelines of the India-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) foreign ministers’ meeting in the Saudi capital.

“We don’t think this conflict is going to be resolved on the battlefield. At some stage, there’s going to be some negotiation. When there is a negotiation, the main parties – Russia and Ukraine – have to be at that negotiation. If you want advice, we are always willing to give it,” said Jaishankar, reported.

Jaishankar also said that India has not closed business with China and admitted that no country in the world can refuse doing business with the country..
.

A village on the edge of the front line north of Ma'rib. Yemen.

Ma'rib is the last northern bastion of the IRG (Internationally-recognized government) and the coalition forces led by the Saudis in the north of Yemen.

The war in Yemen has entered its seventh year and the country is into chaos. Tens of thousands of civilians have died, 3 million Yemenis have had to flee their homes and 80% of the population depend on humanitarian aid for their survival.
The black community of Muhamasheen (the marginalized) is the first to suffer from such a situation. Those who are also pejoratively called the Akhdam (servants) represent between 5 and 12% of the Yemeni population. Mixed marriages, high public functions, social developments, job opportunities, political posts, representations in the media, the Muhamasheen are deprived of them. 
A minority group who suffer discrimination, poverty and social exclusion, whose ancestors are usually of African descent, due to a caste system that has reigned in Yemen for centuries. They mainly live in slums in the outskirts of big cities, without running water, proper sanitation or rubbish collection. 

Yemen, 2021

On the global stage, the response to traditional and emerging challenges like climate change, nuclear proliferation, and pandemics reveals significant gaps. The World Health Organization’s limitations during the COVID-19 pandemic and the slow progress in climate action highlight the shortcomings of existing global institutions. The threat of nuclear proliferation, while less widespread than feared, remains significant, with countries like North Korea and Iran pursuing nuclear capabilities.

Domestically, the United States faces internal divisions and deteriorating social cohesion, impacting its global influence. Political polarization, rising violence, and economic mismanagement have eroded confidence in U.S. stability and effectiveness. The chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and inconsistent foreign policy approaches have further undermined America's position.

In response to these challenges, the United States should prioritize strengthening alliances and partnerships to deter aggression from Russia and China. It must balance immediate support for Ukraine with realistic strategies for resolving the conflict and consider economic distancing from China to reduce dependency. Strategic clarity on Taiwan and building resilient supply chains are crucial for managing relations with China.

Overall, U.S. foreign policy should be pragmatic, focusing on maintaining international order through alliances and selective partnerships rather than attempting to transform rival powers. Realism should guide diplomacy, emphasizing achievable goals and practical solutions over idealistic ambitions. Addressing these challenges requires increased defense spending, cautious yet bold economic policies, and a strategic approach to global issues.

The geopolitical landscape is increasingly complex and fraught with challenges. As the conflict in Ukraine reveals, Russia, despite its military aggression, is emerging as a weakened power. The sanctions imposed by Western nations, coupled with a failing economy and poorly organized armed forces, diminish Russia’s threat compared to the Cold War era. However, its significant military and nuclear capabilities, combined with Vladimir Putin’s willingness to act recklessly, still make it a formidable danger in the near term.

China presents a more substantial long-term challenge. The hope that integrating China into the global economy would lead to political openness and moderation has not materialized. Instead, China has grown more repressive domestically and aggressive internationally. Its military and economic might have increased, and its actions in the South China Sea, its treatment of Taiwan, and its influence over global supply chains reflect a serious challenge to the international order. China’s internal weaknesses, such as economic stagnation, political constraints, and demographic issues, complicate the situation. Moreover, the potential for a difficult leadership transition adds further uncertainty.

The alignment of Russian and Chinese interests against a U.S.-led international system complicates U.S. foreign policy. Both nations share a common hostility toward the existing global order, increasing their collaboration and challenging U.S. leadership. Cont'd....... #talkdiplomacy #Geopolitics

Part 1/2: Exploring the Deep Roots of the Israel-Palestine Conflict

The Israel-Palestine conflict is one of the longest-standing and most complex disputes in modern history. Understanding its historical roots is crucial to grasp the dynamics of today’s ongoing struggle.

In this first part of our two-part series, we’ll take a journey through the ancient religious significance of the region, colonial influences, the creation of Israel, and the early wars that shaped this conflict. Swipe through to discover the major turning points that led to the current situation.

Stay tuned for Part 2, where we explore the escalating tensions, resistance movements, and attempts at peace that followed.

Biden Sanctions Yemen’s Houthi-Financing Network Amid Increase in Terrorist Attacks

The Biden administration on Wednesday issued sanctions targeting an international business network that funds Yemen’s Houthi rebels and their attacks on civilians in Yemen and the Persian Gulf, an action that is part of efforts to bankrupt funds that prolong the country’s seven-year civil war. 

Secretary of State Antony Blinken said that the sanctions were closely coordinated with Gulf partners as a response to Houthi attacks inside Yemen and recent terrorist attacks targeting civilian sites in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates over recent weeks, which have caused numerous civilian casualties.

Excited family members were making plans to pick up Lebanese engineer Maya Gharib's outfit in advance of her wedding, which is scheduled for the following month, according to Reuters.

However, Gharib, her brother Reda, the only surviving member of the family, stated that on Monday, 23-year-old Gharib, her two sisters, and their parents perished in an Israeli strike on their home in a suburb of the southern city of Tyre.

Israel claims that Hezbollah weaponry was the focus of Monday's strikes. It was Lebanon's bloodiest day since the end of the 1975–1990 Civil War, according to the Health Ministry, with over 550 persons killed in the attacks, including at least 50 children and 98 women.

UNGA: PM Shehbaz demands immediate end to ‘systematic slaughter’ in Gaza 

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on Friday demanded an immediate end to the ongoing Israeli military offensive in the Gaza Strip, terming it “systematic slaughter” and “bloodshed”. 

The premier was addressing the plenary meeting for the UN General Debate as the second speaker at the 79th session of the 193-member United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York.

He said humanity was diminished when the “endless suffering” of Palestinians was ignored. It is not enough to condemn … we must act now and demand an immediate end to this bloodshed.

He said the world must work for a durable peace for Palestine through a two-state solution. PM Shehbaz demanded that Palestine be immediately admitted as a full UN member.

PM Shehbaz said it was a matter of “great honour” for him to address the UNGA for the second time as the prime minister of Pakistan.

An airstrike by the Saudi-led coalition fighting Yemen’s Houthi rebels killed at least 70 people and injured over 130 in the city of Saada on Friday. ⁠
⁠
Another strike reportedly hit a telecommunications building in the city of Hodeidah, knocking out internet access throughout the country. The airstrikes were the latest escalation in Yemen’s civil war as it continued into its eighth year and extended the country’s humanitarian crisis. On Monday, Yemen’s Houthi rebels claimed responsibility for a drone attack that killed three oil workers — two Indians and one Pakistani — in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. The drone attack prompted Emirati officials to formally ask the U.S. to reinstate the Houthis as a terrorist organization. When a reporter at President Joe Biden’s Wednesday press conference asked if he was considering this, Biden said, “It’s under consideration. And ending the war in Yemen takes the two parties to be involved to do it.  And it’s going to be very difficult.” Secretary of State Antony Blinken previously removed the Houthis from the terrorist list in February 2021. ⁠
⁠
Coverage was more common on the left than on the right. Some outlets on the left published explainers on the situation after the Abu Dhabi attack. ⁠
⁠
To compare the bias and differences in coverage, use the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
📣📣 Support balanced news and media bias ratings: allsides.com/support⁠
⁠

➡️ #Biden ha dichiarato alla stampa di essere contrario a un'operazione di terra israeliana: "Sono a conoscenza dei piani, dobbiamo avere un 'cessate il fuoco' ora". Il primo ministro libanese Najib Mikati annuncia: "Siamo pronti a inviare l'esercito a sud del fiume Litani".

Lo scenario terrificante delineato pochi giorni fa è divenuto una triste realtà: registrati spari di tank e artiglieria nel sud del Paese. Secondo diverse testimonianze locali, l'esercito libanese si starebbe ritirando dalle posizioni al confine con #Israele, tuttavia la notizia necessita di conferme. #Libano

With misinformation and propaganda being the usual mode of Western news and education on SWANA, it can be difficult to find people who are already doing the work to amplify native voices, radical voices, and the voices of anyone who is directly facing oppression and trying to reclaim their agency, retain and maintain their culture, heritage, and history. Yemen is certainly no exception - while your feed may have gone silent on the topic, the oppression is ongoing and interconnected to transnational struggles. Thanks to assistant professor Shireen al-Adeimi, our favorite show “The East is a Podcast” features professor Adeimi in conversation about modern to present Yemeni history and events. “Nowhere can you really read an article and get an accurate picture of what’s happening in Yemen. Which is why I started writing about this even though it’s not my field - I don’t study this, I don’t do this for a living.” -Professor al-Adeimi. Swipe to the end for the episode titles and make sure to tune in to learn more about the things they don’t tell us about Yemen.

On the most active front line in Yemen’s long civil war, the months-long battle for the city of Marib has become a dragged-out grind with a steady stream of dead and wounded from both sides.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
Houthi rebels have been trying since February to take the city, but have been fended off by heavy air attacks by Saudi Arabia. Yemeni government troops defending Marib say they need more and better weapons to turn the tide.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
Amid another round of peace talks, this time led by Oman, officials and observers believe the final victors in Marib will dictate terms for peace.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
Marib – 115km (70 miles) east of the capital Sanaa on the edge of Yemen’s large desert – is a strategic gateway from the central highlands to southern and eastern provinces.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
Its relative stability in past years made it a haven for those fleeing the war’s other fronts. The area, which had a prewar population of 400,000, now hosts some 2.2 million displaced people, many of them crowded into camps.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠

Kids play pools in one of the main streets of Aden.
In the background a heavily damaged building.
In 2015 there was the Battle for Aden, where Houthi forces managed to take the important southern coastal city with one of the main commercial seaports of Yemen. 
The coalition managed to retake the city after 6 months of bloody fights in the streets and pushed the Houthi back to the north. 
Aden is now controlled by STC, a secessionist movement backed by the UAE (for its own commercial interests) with the aim of bringing back national borders as they were before 1990: two different countries, North and South Yemen.
Aden was once a cosmopolitan and buzzing city, now it is a poor city that carries with it the signs of war everywhere.

@sociolegalcorp Human rights lawyers representing hundreds of victims of Yemen’s civil war are calling on the International Criminal Court to open an investigation into war crimes and crimes against humanity allegedly committed by the Saudi Arabia-led coalition during the devastating conflict.

British lawyer Toby Cadman filed the request Monday, highlighting three separate incidents – an August 2018 airstrike that destroyed a school bus and killed dozens; a missile attack in October 2016 that killed at least 110 people; and allegations of torture and murder of civilians being held in prisons in the south of Yemen.

The filing came a day after a missile and drone attack, blamed on the Houthi rebels, on a key military base in Yemen’s south killed at least 30 troops.

The civil war in Yemen erupted in 2014, when the Iranian-backed Houthis swept across much of the north and seized the capital, Sanaa, forcing the internationally recognized government into exile. The Saudi-led coalition entered the war the following year on the side of the government. All sides are accused of atrocities in the yearslong conflict.

Lawyer Almudena Bernabeu, representing victims of the school bus attack, said that the coalition said it would investigate the deadly strike and bring those responsible to justice.

“Of course, they did no such thing,” Bernabeu said in a statement. “As the court of last resort, victims and families have no choice but to call on the International Criminal Court to ensure justice is done.”

A spokesman for the Saudi-led coalition did not respond to phone calls seeking comment.

Yemen is not a member state of the court and nor are key coalition members Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. 

However, in a 212-page written submission, the lawyers argue that the court should exercise jurisdiction because some members of the coalition are ICC member states.

.
“Speed &  Surprise  is  the  essence  of  any  combat”
~StuG. 

[ A Ratel ICV ( Infantry Combat Vechile ) in its top speed during combat manuvers ] 
.
.
Named after the Honey-badger, the Ratel ICV is a a long-running family of 6x6 armored vehicles which has been developed & produced in South Africa. After using tracked armored vechiles for several years, they realized that wheeled AFV’s were more mobile, more reliable & more ideally suited for dashing across the sandy, grassy & bushy parts of the country. It also meant the vehicles could drive to their target areas, rather than being delivered by transporters or railway like the tracked vehicles. 

The South Africans have since become something of experts in the field of wheeled armored vehicles, “primarily where land mines are a concern”. The production of Ratel commenced in 1978 & final deliveries were made during 1987. All models of the Ratel have a 6x6 drive configuration with the long armored steel hull being specially contoured underneath to minimize land mine damage, & if necessary it can also travel with two wheels missing. 

It has a turbocharged diesel engine which produces 282 hp & provided the vehicle with a road speed of 105 km/h on ideal surfaces and up to 30 km/h on uneven terrain at an perational range of 997 km. Tests have also proven that it is also amphibious.

Ratel was designed for speed & mobility, thus it had to sacrifice its armor. It has an effective thickness of 20 mm over the frontal arc. The upper hull sides are 8 mm, lower hull 10 mm, rear hull 10 mm & floor hull 8 mm. It’s mine resistance is derived from the hull`s height above the ground, which is due to its large oversized wheels. The original production version was the Ratel 20 which featured a 20mm cannon. The Ratel 60 had a 60mm mortar, the similar Ratel 80 made use of an 81mm mortar. The Ratel 90 included a 90mm cannon as well as interior room for up to 6 troops. There were also other variants such as Command vechiles, ATGM & logistics carrier etc.

As the 79th session of the UN General Assembly continues, the U.S. government is watching to see how other nations' votes align or do not align with their own. But is the prevalence of Israel-Palestine votes at the UNGA making the U.S. appear more isolated than it actually is?

UC Santa Barbara's Bridget Coggins, Julia Morse, JungJae Hong, and Annjulie Vester look at voting data to find that by overweighting issues of contention that draw UNGA roll-call votes, the U.S. government is overlooking areas of broad consensus. 

Head to the link in our bio to read their analysis in the latest blog post for IGCC's Global Policy at a Glance!

I attended a talk on "Historical Origins of the #Palestine War" this evening at the India International Center, presented by Prof. Madavan Palat, former Chairman of the Centre for Historical Studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, editor of Selected Words of Jawaharlal Nehru, and trustee of the Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Fund. I must say this was the best lecture about the historical perspective of the crisis I have come across in recent years.

In an extensive one-hour lecture, Prof. Palat, in the presence of former National Security Advisor Shiv Shankar Menon and Mr. C. Aday Bhaskar, explained the reasons behind the brutality of Israel against the Gazans as well as the people of Lebanon. He also stated that, in reality, it's the Arabs who should have been involved in this crisis more than Iran, but the monarchs and kings there are not accountable to their public.

When I asked why the Arabs are not as involved as Iran, not even 20 percent of the same, he said that it is due to the fear of revolution. He explained that they know public anger against Israel on the Arab streets can anytime turn toward Arab rulers, and they won't be able to save themselves from the ire.

I must say people like Mr Palat keep on reviving our diminishing hope in humanity through their ways of speaking out against the brutality of the state and society. #IsraelPalestineConflict #GazaGenocide‌ #IsraelLebanonConflict

📌 The US has debunked claims that allowing Kyiv greater freedom to use its donated ATACMS for strikes deep in Russia would significantly reduce the number of hostile aircraft targeting Ukraine. White House National Security Advisor John Kirby explained that the ATACMS is ineffective against Russian warplanes used for long-range strikes in Ukraine, as they are stationed deep within enemy territory beyond the weapon’s reach, which has a maximum of 300 kilometers. Kirby stated that 90% of the aircraft are outside this range, inside Russia.

Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed willingness to resume peace talks with Ukraine, despite previously stating that Ukrainian military actions in Kursk made negotiations impossible. He referenced a peace deal that was initially outlined during earlier discussions in Istanbul, suggesting that it could serve as a foundation for a new agreement. Putin emphasized that Russia has never refused negotiations, but any dialogue should be based on the existing framework from the Istanbul talks rather than new or vague demands.

Putin also suggested that BRICS member nations, specifically China, Brazil, and India, could potentially act as mediators in future negotiations. As the current chair of BRICS, which includes South Africa as well, Russia seeks to involve these emerging economies in the peace process to help facilitate discussions and potentially reach a resolution.
Source: AP, Reuters, AFP

So what
It seems possible that Putin may be willing to negotiate, but it is unlikely that much of his positions will change. In particular, Ukraine has continued to state that they want Russia to withdraw outside of the pre2014 borders, something Russia is highly unlikely to do. In an additional statement today, Putin stated that Russia's primary goal in Ukraine is to control the Donbas region, indicating they are highly unlikely to give it up in any peace negotiation.

Het dodentol van de oorlog in Jemen zal oplopen tot 377 000 tegen het einde van dit jaar. Dat blijkt uit een nieuw rapport van het VN-Ontwikkelingsprogramma (UNDP). Volgens het agentschap zouden 60% van deze slachtoffers omkomen door de indirecte gevolgen van de oorlog zoals extreme honger of gebrek aan toegang tot gezondheidszorg. 

Er woedt al zeven jaar een bloedige burgeroorlog in Jemen die ondertussen al honderdduizenden mensenlevens heeft geëist. In 2014 namen de sjiitische Houthi-rebellen de hoofdstad Sanaa in na een militaire coup. In maart 2015 schoot buurland Saudi-Arabië de verdreven soennitische Jemenitische regering te hulp met een militaire interventie. Sindsdien zijn de regeringstroepen, gesteund door een internationale coalitie onder leiding van de Saudi’s, en de Houthi’s, gesteund door Iran, verwikkeld in een hevige strijd. Volgens de VN is dit aanhoudende conflict uitgemond in ‘de ergste humanitaire crisis ter wereld’.

Russia has launched a fresh wave of devastating attacks on Ukraine, killing scores of people in the cities of Lviv and Poltava. A mother and her three daughters were among the victims in Lviv, where a drone and hypersonic missile strike damaged over 50 buildings, including homes, schools, and clinics.

Our new article "Theses on Capitalism and the Generalisation of War" has now been published on our website! 

"As war rages around the world, it is the working class who invariably pay the price, without so much as a choice in the matter of their own lives. Against the chorus of bourgeois political actors, and even so-called “socialists” and “anarchists”, who exhort us to line up behind one camp of imperialist murderers or another, we reject their paradigm altogether, and instead insist on the need for the working class to develop and maintain its political independence with respect to capital and its institutions; to refuse to allow itself to be used as cannon fodder by any of the warring sides and organise itself to achieve their mutual overthrow.

The defence of proletarian internationalism—the core communist principle that workers’ interests are the same everywhere and that, contrarily, they have no interest in common with “their” exploiting class—and its practical application: revolutionary defeatism, is fundamental today for communists who wish to act to stem the bloody tide of capitalist civilisation."

Full text:
https://internationalistcommunists.org/2024/09/03/theses-on-capitalism-and-the-generalisation-of-war/

'भारत, चीन और ब्राजील करा सकते हैं रूस-यूक्रेन के बीच शांति वार्ता..', व्लादिमीर पुतिन का बड़ा बयान

रूसी राष्ट्रपति व्लादिमीर पुतिन ने रूस-यूक्रेन के बीच शांति वार्ता को लेकर एक बड़ा बयान जारी किया है. उन्होंने कहा कि भारत, चीन और ब्राजील दोनों देशों के बीच शांति वार्ता करा सकते हैं. उन्होंने कहा कि दोनों देशों के बीच इस्तांबुल में हुआ प्रारंभिक समझौता इस वार्ता का आधार बन सकता है. 2022 में युद्ध के पहले कुछ हफ्तों के दौरान दोनों देशों ने इस्तांबुल में बातचीत की थी. भारत ने संघर्ष को हल करने के लिए बातचीत और कूटनीति का आह्वान किया है.

YEMEN 2018 - I love this picture of these two roadside merchants with all their colorful goods. I met them on my way to a refugee camp in Abs in the northern part of Yemen back in 2018. Seeing the flags in their headgear and how they were just packed with stuff I immediately knew I needed a picture of them. After having taken the picture the rest of the team and I went into the restaurant we were having lunch at and thought nothing more of the guys outside. 
Coming back outside after our lunch I was met by a group of soldiers and the officer in charge asked me in a harsh tone asked what the hell I was doing in their district and why I was taking pictures of people. Luckily my fixer quickly got there and sorted out the situation. But I still love this little colorful and cheerful moment in the middle of the world's worst humanitarian crisis.
------

Sanighdha writes:
“It is in common parlance that the war going on in Yemen has been and is still inflicting huge losses on the nation as a whole- including its people, its limited natural resources coupled with the loss of property and impairment of foreign relations with almost all the worldly nations. While the conflict has its root in the Arab Spring when stability of most of the Arab nations was questioned by their own citizens, the war in Yemen has acquired several other political, economic and social dimensions; not to mention the chaos that the world powers have created in Yemen for furthering their own interests. However, it is pertinent to note that the Yemen Civil war must end, for conflicts lead to more conflicts and not to solutions.”

Through this article, the author tries to bring the inevitability of a ceasefire in the Yemen civil war, to the notice of the readers.

Houthi fighter in Yemen can be seen here posing for a picture while armed with an interesting Chinese QBZ-97 rifle that is essentially an export version of the QBZ-95 chambered in 5.56x45mm instead of the 5.8mm ammunition it usually uses. The rifle also has a modified magazine well in order to accept STANAG magazines. However, this rifle could also be a QBZ-97A variant that has a 3 round burst feature and is missing the "front grip" part in front of the trigger guard. It is unknown how this rifle ended up in Yemen although is it is thought that China may have sold some rifles to the Government prior to the civil war, or perhaps these rifles came from Sudan where the rifle is made at the Military Industry Corporation from components shipped from China. Known as Sinan.

Ukraine has urged Mongolia to arrest Russian President Vladimir Putin during his upcoming visit on September 3, in compliance with an International Criminal Court (ICC) warrant issued last year for war crimes related to the deportation of Ukrainian children. The Kremlin, however, expressed confidence that Mongolia, an ICC member since 2000, would not take such action. This visit marks Putin's first trip to an ICC member state since the warrant was issued, and according to ICC rules, Mongolia is obligated to arrest and transfer him to The Hague.

Volontari greci insieme al GRU ucraino a Kursk, all'inizio dell'invasione dell'oblast russo. Nel febbraio-maggio 2022 la Federazione russa assediò Mariupol, riducendo la città in cenere; la città ucraina contava una nutrita e numerosa comunità greca, che venne spazzata via dalla macchina bellica russa. Quei pochi greci rimasti hanno deciso di vendicarsi, prendendo parte alle operazioni a Kursk.

Very nice image depicting a Houthi fighter in Yemen armed with a very nice example of a Dragunov SVU rifle that is essentially a bullpup version of the SVD. Yemen received a batch of these rifles from Russia prior to the ousting of the Saleh government in February 2012. Additionally, a fighter next to him can also be seen armed with an AK-104 which is essentially a shortened version of the AK-103. The AK-104 is actually rather common in Yemen as Russia delivered quite a few of them to different units of the Yemeni army prior to the outbreak of the civil war. 

#yemen #yemenwar #houthi #ak104 #svu #militaryhistory #warhistory #gunhistory #gunfacts #warhistorians #yemencivilwar #ak103 #combathistory

Yemeni Houthi fighters can be seen here armed with either an American M47 Dragon ATGM supplied to the Saudi’s or an Iranian reverse engineered copy of the American M47 known as the “Saeghe”. The United States military officially resigned this weapon in 2001 and destroyed its remaining stocks in September 2009, but the Saudis do still operate this platform, albeit in small quantities. In my opinion it is much more likely for these to be Iranian copies due to the large amounts of munitions that the IRGC supplies to the houthi movement. The Saeghe 1 was first shown by the Iranians in 2001 and is thought to have entered serial production in 2002. Iran later introduced the Saeghe 2, a more advanced variant with a tandem warhead to defeat explosive reactive armor,and the Saeghe 4, with a thermobaric warhead. Despite being essentially obsolete, Saegheh anti tank guided missiles have been exported to Syria, Hezbollah, and Shia militias in Yemen and Iraq. The Saeghe 1 and Saeghe 2 were in production and service as of 2011, though they were not widely deployed. The Saeghe ATGM is extremely hard to aim and operate and in Iranian service it appears to be limited to IRGC and rapid response forces.

"Antony Blinken’s decades of experience in top Democratic foreign policy circles brings with it assets and liabilities. On the plus side, he understands the bureaucratic workings of the State Department and the value of traditional alliances, the lack of which demoralized many career diplomats during the Trump administration.

On the negative side, he also comes to the position saddled with the calamitous foreign policy decisions of the elected officials he advised, most notably Biden’s leading role in providing Democratic support as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to authorize the Bush administration’s illegal war on Iraq.

Although Biden eventually expressed regret for this mistake, as late as this year, Blinken was still deceptively referring to the authorization for use of force against Iraq as a “vote for tough diplomacy.”

More recently, as a senior foreign policy figure in the Obama administration, Blinken shares in the blame for the president’s incoherent, piecemeal, and unprincipled response to the Arab Spring, which consisted of a combination of questionably unauthorized uses of force against long-time adversaries and a studied indifference to the repression inflicted by brutal allies against their citizens."

writes Josh Ruebner for Politics Today. Read the full article by clicking the link in our bio.

Today It is something different and sadly is still currently  waging/going on right now. Today i will be giving you a brief understanding of the Syrian and Yemeni Civil war. 

So the Syrian Civil war started in 2011  It is an ongoing multi-sided civil war in Syria fought between the Ba'athist Syrian Arab Republic led by Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, along with domestic and foreign allies, and various domestic and foreign forces opposing both the Syrian government and each other in varying combinations. This also involved the rise of a horrifying extremist/terrorist group who committed acts of terror killing thousands whilst trying to promote Extremism and terror using Religion (Will not be naming them due to the respect for all victims that suffered at the hands of these horrible people) The terrorist group were thankfully dealt with and eliminated by Syrian National Army amongst other allies who helped like the US. The war is still ongoing.

The Yemeni Civil War is is an ongoing conflict that began in 2015 between two factions: the Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi-led Yemeni government and the Houthi armed movement, along with their supporters and allies. Both claim to constitute the official government of Yemen. War still ongoing. 

Lessons learnt here. Government power is real and money talks. Were all categorized and selfish and narcism and Fascism come into play here. Always be nice to your peers amd be equal. Yemen is going through one of the worst man made humanitarian crises as a result of the ongoing civil war. Though Yemen was always besieged with internal conflicts since its unification in 1990, the severity of fighting and destruction is the current phase of civil war since 2015 is unimaginable.

Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. As of early this year, it has added another layer to the war: the failing healthcare infrastructure and the rise of COVID-19.

This is the Great Marib Dam. Built in the 8th century BCE, it was one of the truly great architectural marvels of the ancient Mediterranean world. It also signified the power and grandeur of the ancient civilisations that resided in Yemen such as the Sabaeans and Himyarites. Slide along and you will see other images that attest to this nations' historic prosperity and cultural richness. Indeed, Yemen's wealth was unmatched in the Arabian peninsula well into the second millennium. This is made all the more surprising by the fact that today, Yemen is one of the poorest countries in Central Asia and remains in the thrall of a complicated and devastating war. There are no consolations we can offer to the horrors that have occurred there, though we sincerely hope that Yemen - and the international community, who is fully implicated in the disaster - can bring about the peace that Yemenis deserve. With that, perhaps Yemen might one day return to its former glory.

Slide along to see images of the Great Mosque of Sana'a, the Dar al Hajar in Wadi Dhar, and the ancient skyscraper city of Shibam.
 
If you would like to understand a bit more about Yemen's complicated but fascinating history, then tune in to our latest episode. We hope you enjoy!

🇬🇧 The war in Yemen is dragging on and has led to the worst humanitarian crisis in the world today. This internationalized conflict has also damaged Yemen's cultural heritage including the historic town of Zabid. The former capital of Yemen from the 13th to the 15th century has an exceptional historical value. Firstly because it had a key importance in the history of the Arab and Muslim world, secondly because it contains relics and historic buildings including 86 mosques and houses in the Tihama style and finally because the organization of its urban plan and its military architecture makes it unique. The air strikes of the coalition led by Saudi Arabia on Zabid and the looting of the historical library by the Houthist forces supported by Iran are examples showing the consequences of war, destroying our universal past and memory.

🇫🇷 La guerre au Yémen s’éternise et a entraîné la pire crise humanitaire actuelle dans le monde. Ce conflit internationalisé a aussi endommagé le patrimoine culturel yéménite dont la ville historique de Zabid. L’ancienne capitale du Yémen du XIIIe au XVe siècle, a une valeur historique exceptionnelle. D’abord parce qu’elle a eu une importance clé dans l’histoire du monde arabe et musulman, ensuite parce qu’elle recèle de reliques et d’édifices historiques dont 86 mosquées et maisons de style Tihama et enfin parce que l’organisation de son tissu urbain et son architecture militaire la rend unique. Les frappes aériennes de la coalition dirigée par l’Arabie saoudite sur la ville mais aussi le pillage de la bibliothèque historique par les forces houthistes soutenues par l’Iran mettent aujourd’hui en péril cette mémoire universelle qui se doit d’être protégée pour les populations actuelles et futures.

IMT Hyderabad takes immense pride in announcing the research paper titled “Reflection of public perception of Russia-Ukraine conflict and Metaverse on the financial outlook of Metaverse coins: Fresh evidence from Reddit Sentiment Analysis” authored by our distinguished faculty member Prof. (Dr.) Indranil Ghosh (Assistant Professor, IT & Analytics), co-authored by Dr. Esteban Alfaro- Cortés, Dr. Matías Gámez and Dr. Noelia García-Rubio has secured successful publication in the prestigious journal “International Reviews of Financial Analysis”.

The study investigates the relationship between Metaverse coin prices and social media attitudes about the Russia-Ukraine war and Metaverse potential. Using Wavelet Coherence Analysis, the research uncovers a short-term link between these factors. Furthermore, Reddit sentiment analysis on both topics demonstrates their influence on Metaverse coin prices. Forecasting is done using nonlinear approaches such as UMAP and PSO-tuned XGBR, with XAI interpreting the findings. The study concludes that short-term media discussion and Reddit sentiment can effectively forecast Metaverse coin price patterns.

To discover in-depth insights and findings about the research paper, please click here: https://bit.ly/46Y7ACm

SA'DAH, YEMEN 2018: Said was nine months old when I photographed him in the triage section of the Al-Jumhuri hospital in Sa'dah back in 2018. He was one of the more than 400,000 children suffering from severe acute malnutrition according to the UN. He measured 68 cm, weighed 5,6 kg, and was furthermore diagnosed with measles while suffering from diarrhea, vomiting, and fever. 
------
Unfortunately, the situation hasn’t improved in the two-and-a-half years that have passed since I was in the country with journalist @tparabien. According to the @unitednations, more than 400,000 children under the age of five are suffering from severe acute malnutrition to a degree where they are at risk of dying within a short period of time, and more than 16 million people are starving and are also at risk of dying as a result. 
The UN estimates that the country right now is in need of aid and protection for close to 4 billion USD.
------

He and his eight children had narrowly escaped the fighting in their home town, Taiz, three months before I took this picture.

Fighting intensifies in the Yemeni province of Marib as the Iran-backed Houthi rebels push closer towards the city. Sources told the Hindu, that at least 90 combatants have been killed in less than 24 hours on Saturday.

The fighting in Yemen which has been raging on since 2014 has left many displaced and killed. The Civil war in Yemen is being fought between an Iranian-backed Houthi armed movement and the internationally recognized Hadi-led Yemeni government-backed mostly by Saudi Arabia. The lives of civilians have become catastrophic.

The city of Marib, located between Sana’a and Sa’dah (which are under the control of the Houthis) is the last stronghold for the Yemeni Government in the Northern part of the country. The loss of Marib would be a huge blow to the Saudi-led coalition as the area is also rich in oil but moreover, it would threaten the lives of countless citizens of the city as well as those in refugee camps situated in the province.

The siege of the city was started last month by the Houthis and after a steady advance, a three-prong offensive was launched into the city. The area is under constant threat of ballistic missiles from both sides and a long battle for the city seems to be in the offing. US Secretary of state, Antony Blinken has urged the Houthis to halt their advance as he announced $191 million in aid. 

Writer: @shasanath 
Media: @tanisha.badrinath

OTR-21 Tochka Tactical ballistic missile of the Soviet Union
-
The OTR-21 is a mobile missile launch system, designed to be deployed along with other land combat units on the battlefield. While the 9K52 Luna-M is large and relatively inaccurate, the OTR-21 is much smaller. The missile itself can be used for precise strikes on enemy tactical targets, such as control posts, bridges, storage facilities, troop concentrations and airfields. The fragmentation warhead can be replaced with a nuclear, biological or chemical warhead. The solid propellant makes the missile easy to maintain and deploy. OTR-21 units are usually managed in a brigade structure. There are 18 launchers in a brigade; each launcher is provided with 2 or 3 missiles. The vehicle is completely amphibious, with a maximum road speed of 60 km/h (37 mph) and 8 km/h (5.0 mph) in water. It is NBC-protected. The system has been in development since 1968. Three variants were developed.
-
Warhead : Chemical, 100 kt nuclear warhead, EMP, or fragmentation filling
-
Engine : Single-stage Solid-fuel rocket
-
Maximum speed : 1.8 km/s (1.1 mi/s; Mach 5.3)
-
Guidance
system : Inertial guidance, Tochka-P added passive radar against radar installations
.
.
.
.

👉follow @thenormalnews 🇾🇪Ethiopian migrants were driven out of northern Yemen by Houthi rebels, at least 12 migrants being killed in the process, with survivors transported to the border of Saudi Arabia where Saudi guards opened fire on any migrants that attempted to flee, killing at least 24 more.
.
Houthi rebels reportedly believe Ethiopian migrants are carriers of coronavirus, similar to the stigma and discrimination faced by Black people in China, and have been continually removed from Yemen as the pandemic slowly ravages the region.
.
A researcher at Human Rights Watch says, “United Nations agencies need to step in to address the immediate threats to the Ethiopian migrants and press for accountability for those responsible for the killings and other abuses.”
.
A number of migrants were granted entry to Saudi Arabia only to be detained in harsh facilities with at least 200 migrants are estimated to have escaped and are assumed stranded along the mountainous border.
.

Student Clayton Hawes describes his experience in the IWP-Oxford Study Abroad this summer:

"This summer term during the IWP-Oxford Study Abroad, I researched with my tutor, Dr. Mark Almond, looking at Russian military lessons learned from the Russo-Japanese War, from its military rearmament through the First World War.

"The research question was, 'If Russia was prepared for war in 1914, why did things go so wrong by 1917?'

"I looked at what the Russians did and what shortfalls were present and examined what trends we see today in the Russia-Ukraine conflict. My assessment was that similar shortcomings are still drawn out from then to what we see of Russian military shortcomings in Ukraine.

"My study experience at Oxford and New College was filled with academic enrichment and personal fulfillment."

Yemen is going through one of the worst man made humanitarian crises as a result of the ongoing civil war. Though Yemen was always besieged with internal conflicts since its unification in 1990, the severity of fighting and destruction is the current phase of civil war since 2015 is unimaginable.

Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. As of early this year, it has added another layer to the war: the failing healthcare infrastructure and the rise of COVID-19. 

Much of the current conflict can only be understood as a result of the events of the latter half of the 20th century. A brief look at the history that has shaped today’s wars in Yemen is given in  a series of six short explanatory articles.

To read more check the link in bio.

Series by @oleodoodle

#yemen @unicef_yemen @yemenisfinest @save_yemen #aden #civilwar #history #saudiarabia #yemencantwait #yemencrisis #yemencivilwar

The civil war in Yemen has taken a toll on the healthcare infrastructure of the country. Most of Yemen's 3,500 medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning.

In June 2015 itself, aid agencies warned of the humanitarian risks brought by the US and UK-backed Saudi blockades.

According to UNICEF reports, over 3.3 million children and pregnant or lactating women suffer from acute malnutrition. 

In 2017, the World Food Programme estimated that an additional 3.2 million people would be pushed into hunger. If left untreated, 150,000 malnourished children could die within the coming months. 

Save the Children, the international charity and aid agency, estimated that 85,000 children under the age of five have starved to death in between 2015 to 2018. 

A solution to the war must be found soon, before the pandemic eviscerates more of the healthcare infrastructure.

To read more check the link in bio.

Plain clothed member of the Saudi 64th special forces brigade Armed with a Saudi AK-103 in Yemen. In 2017, Saudi Arabian military industries (SAMI) signed a contract with Russia’s Rosoboronexport to domestically produce the AK-103 under license in Saudi Arabia.embers of the Saudi special forces brigades do not follow standard military procedure in regards to organisational structure, instead, they report only and directly to Prince  Mohammad Bin Salman who is the current minister of defence. Additionally, several members of the Jamal Khashoggi assassination team were members of this particular unit and some even worked in the Prince’s office.

The two leaders also discussed measures to further strengthen special and privileged strategic partnership. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Ukraine on August 23, 2024, marked the first-ever visit by an Indian Prime Minister to the country since the establishment of diplomatic relations. Arriving in Kyiv by 'Rail Force One' from Poland, PM Modi received a ceremonial welcome at the Kyiv Central Railway Station. Despite the ongoing conflict with Russia, the visit highlighted India's commitment to peace and humanitarian aid.

During his visit, PM Modi paid tribute to Gandhiji at the ‘Oasis of Peace’ park, emphasizing the relevance of Gandhiji's message of peace in today’s global challenges. He also visited the Martyrologist exposition at the National Museum of History of Ukraine, where he was deeply moved by the memorial dedicated to children who lost their lives in the conflict.

PM Modi held fruitful discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Maryinskyi Palace, where they reviewed bilateral ties and signed agreements in agriculture, medical products, and cultural cooperation. PM Modi reiterated India's stance for peace and offered to mediate in the Russia-Ukraine conflict without taking sides.

As a gesture of humanitarian support, PM Modi handed over four BHISHM Cubes, containing medicines and medical equipment, to President Zelenskyy. Additionally, PM Modi interacted with Ukrainian students learning Hindi, commending their efforts to promote Indian culture in Ukraine.

PM Modi's visit underscored India's growing role in global diplomacy, with his ability to engage both Russia and Ukraine, demonstrating India's commitment to peace and humanitarian assistance amidst the ongoing conflict.

China has issued alert for its citizens to leave Israel “as soon as possible”, as rising tensions between Israel and Lebanon’s Hezbollah escalate.

The embassy urged Chinese citizens in Israel to “return home or relocate to safer areas as soon as possible”.

„Man erreicht keinen Frieden dadurch, dass man alle Feinde tötet,“ sagte Ami Ajalon in einem Interview mit Zeit Online.

Diese Einsicht zieht sich wie ein roter Faden durch sein Buch „Im eigenen Feuer“, in dem der frühere israelische Geheimdienstchef und sozialistische Knesset-Abgeordnete seine militärische und geheimdienstliche Laufbahn reflektiert.

Ami Ajalon schildert eindrucksvoll, wie er sich vom „Falken“ zu einem scharfen Kritiker der israelischen Politik wandelte. Er schreibt mit großer Ehrlichkeit über die zerstörerischen Folgen eines Lebens im Anti-Terror-Krieg und die Notwendigkeit, Palästinenser nicht als Feinde, sondern als Menschen mit Rechten zu sehen.

Seine Memoiren sind ein eindringliches Plädoyer für Selbstreflexion und Empathie. Diese fordert er auch von der israelischen Gesellschaft ein. „Unsere mangelnde Empathie unterminierte unsere Fähigkeit, Gefahren und Chancen richtig einzuschätzen.“

Ein tief bewegender Text, der die Standpunkte beider Seiten erfasst und in einer Zeit des Stillstands im Friedensprozess neue Wege zur Verständigung eröffnet.

On the sidelines of the UN General Assembly session, PM Narendra Modi met Palestinian President Mahmour Abbas, and expressed his concerns over the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

PM Modi said: “Reiterated India’s support for early restoration of peace and stability in the region. Exchanged views of further strengthening long standing friendship with the people of Palestine.”

This comes just days after India abstained in the UN General Assembly on a resolution that demanded that Israel bring an end, “without delay”, to its unlawful presence in the Occupied Palestinian Territory within 12 months.

The 193-member General Assembly adopted the resolution, with 124 nations voting in favour, 14 against and 43 abstentions, including that by India.

Israeli forces raided Al Jazeera's office in Ramallah, ordering a 45-day closure.

Heavily armed and masked Israeli soldiers handed the closure order to the network's West Bank bureau chief without providing a reason.

The raid follows a previous ban in May that barred Al Jazeera from operating inside Israel, citing national security concerns.

Al Jazeera condemned the closure, calling it a violation of human rights and an effort to suppress press freedom.

The Gaza Government Media Office described the raid as a scandal and a blatant violation of press freedom.

Al Jazeera has consistently faced restrictions and attacks on its journalists, including the killing of reporter Ismail Al-Ghoul in Gaza.

World Health Organization (WHO) chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus today said Israeli tanks have fired on an aid convoy in northern Gaza. Posting on X, he wrote that a WHO-led convoy encountered two Israeli tanks on the way back from a mission on 14 September.

Shots were fired from tanks near the convoy, he said, adding that the convoy had received clearance and the attack was "not acceptable". Nobody was hurt during the incident, he said.

📌 The Ukrainian military has been capturing up to 150 Russian soldiers per day amid its ongoing incursion into Russia’s Kursk region. This was announced by Oleksii Drozdenko, the head of military administration in northeastern Ukraine, on the 12th day of Kyiv’s surprise offensive. According to him, many of the captured soldiers are young conscripts tasked with guarding the southwestern Russian border. Some of them also admitted that they did not want to fight the advancing Ukrainian troops. The high number of Russian prisoners of war and the relatively low number of casualties on Kyiv’s side only prove that the cross-border offensive has been a major success so far, Drozdenko told The Guardian.

Russian Su-34 Bomber Destroys Ukrainian Armor with Glide Bombs in Kursk Region

In a significant escalation, a Russian Su-34 frontline bomber conducted a nighttime strike on massed Ukrainian troops and armored vehicles in the Kursk Region. The Russian Defense Ministry announced that the attack utilized upgraded aerial bombs with a unified glide/adjustment module to target fortified enemy positions, reports TASS news agency. 

The operation, which occurred in the borderline area of the Kursk Region, successfully destroyed the intended targets, according to reconnaissance data. Following the strike, the bomber crew returned safely to their airfield.

This comes after a massive Ukrainian attack on the Kursk Region on August 6, heightening tensions in the area.

प्रधानमंत्री नरेन्द्र मोदी रूस-यूक्रेन संघर्ष के शांतिपूर्ण समाधान के लिए प्रयास करने हेतु यूक्रेनी राष्ट्रपति वोलोडिमिर ज़ेलेंस्की के निमंत्रण पर शुक्रवार को युद्धग्रस्त यूक्रेन पहुंचे। यह यात्रा महत्वपूर्ण है क्योंकि 1992 में द्विपक्षीय संबंधों की स्थापना के बाद से यह पहली बार है जब किसी भारतीय प्रधानमंत्री ने यूक्रेन का दौरा किया है।

प्रधानमंत्री का गर्मजोशी के साथ हुआ स्वागत 
पोलैंड से रेल फोर्स वन पर 10 घंटे की ट्रेन यात्रा के बाद कीव पहुंचने पर प्रधानमंत्री मोदी का स्टेशन पर गर्मजोशी से स्वागत किया गया। इसके बाद वे शुरुआती बैठकों के लिए हयात होटल पहुंचे, जहां भारतीय प्रवासियों ने उनका उत्साहपूर्वक स्वागत किया। प्रधानमंत्री मोदी की यात्रा का मुख्य उद्देश्य रूस-यूक्रेन विवाद के शांतिपूर्ण समाधान पर चर्चा करना है। भारत को दोनों देशों के बीच मध्यस्थता में संभावित रूप से रचनात्मक भूमिका निभाने के रूप में देखा जा रहा है।

प्रधानमंत्री मोदी ने दिल्ली से रवाना होने से पहले कहा, "मैं राष्ट्रपति जेलेंस्की के साथ द्विपक्षीय सहयोग को मजबूत करने तथा चल रहे यूक्रेन संघर्ष के शांतिपूर्ण समाधान पर विचारों को साझा करने के लिए पहले की बातचीत को आगे बढ़ाने के अवसर की प्रतीक्षा कर रहा हूं।" प्रधानमंत्री मोदी की यह यात्रा उनकी मॉस्को यात्रा और रूसी राष्ट्रपति व्लादिमीर पुतिन के साथ बैठक के लगभग छह सप्ताह बाद हो रही है, जिस पर पश्चिमी देशों ने आपत्ति जताई थी।

PM Narendra Modi is set to visit war-torn Ukraine today. He is scheduled to meet the Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. PM Modi's Ukraine visit comes nearly six weeks after he visited Russia to discuss the conflict-ridden situation in the region. This is also an Indian PM's first visit to Ukraine. The UN secretary-general's office said that they hope that the Indian PM's visit to Ukraine might bring up the possibility of putting an end to the war. Meanwhile, Russia and the US will be keeping a close eye on PM Modi’s visit to see if India shows any bias towards Moscow or the West.

A Russian court sentenced US-Russian citizen Ksenia Karelina to 12 years in prison on charges of "treason" after she allegedly donated around $50 to a pro-Ukraine charity. Karelina, a 32-year-old ballerina who had been living in Los Angeles, was arrested while visiting family in Yekaterinburg in January. The Russian FSB claimed that the funds she collected were used to purchase supplies and equipment for the Ukrainian armed forces. Karelina reportedly pleaded guilty to the charges last week, according to Russian state media.

This sentencing occurs amid heightened tensions between Russia and the West, particularly following Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Just two weeks prior, Russia released 16 prisoners with US and other Western citizenships in a major prisoner swap, the largest since the Cold War. The case of Karelina, along with others involving Western citizens, highlights ongoing concerns that Russia is imprisoning foreigners on questionable charges to use them as leverage in diplomatic negotiations.
Source: AFP, Reuters

So what
I guess following the large prisoner exchange that occurred a few weeks ago Russia is in need of some new prisoners for bargaining. Though this charge seems quite straightforward when compared to previous political prisoners, it is similar to what would happen to people who are caught raising money for terror groups in the West. Of note around this is some reporting about Russia initiating talks to exchange prisoners for the first time in the conflict, following the capture of some FSB units during Ukraine’s attack on Kursk. It could be possible Russia plans to use Karelina to pressure Ukraine into a trade for these forces.

These missile deployments are scheduled to take place from 2026. They are broadly similar to those deployed in the ‘80s but these new ones will not be armed with nuclear warheads, just conventional ones…apparently. The number of US nuclear weapons in Europe peaked at 7,000 in the ‘70s before declining sharply from the ‘80s. It is currently estimated there are 100 nuclear weapons in Europe owned by the US but note that this is an estimate since the actual number is classified.

റഷ്യയിൽ കടന്നുകയറിയ മുഴുവൻ യുക്രെയിൻ സൈന്യത്തേയും ഒരൊറ്റ എയർ റെയ്‌ഡിലൂടെ കരിച്ചുകളയുമൊന്നൊക്കെ റഷ്യ പറയുമ്പോഴും കഴിഞ്ഞ പത്ത് ദിവസമായി അതിനവർക്ക് സാധിച്ചിട്ടില്ല. രണ്ടര കൊല്ലമായി തുടരുന്ന അനാവശ്യവും വിനാശകരവുമായ ഈ യുദ്ധത്തിൽ ഇങ്ങനെയൊരു വഴിത്തിരിവ് പുടിൻ പ്രതീക്ഷിച്ചിരുന്നില്ല. സ്വീഡനിലെ ചാൾസ് പന്ത്രണ്ടാമനും, നെപ്പോളിയനും, ഹിറ്റ്ലറിനും പറ്റിയ അതേ ചരിത്രപരമായ അബദ്ധത്തിലേക്കാണോ സെലൻസ്കി വീണിരിക്കുന്നത്?

വിഴുങ്ങാൻ ചെന്നപ്പോൾ ഇര വാലിൽ കടിച്ചെന്ന് പറഞ്ഞ പോലെയായി കാര്യങ്ങൾ. കയ്യേറിയ ഭൂമി കൈവശം വെക്കാൻ ഉദ്ദേശിച്ചിട്ടില്ലെന്നും അള മുട്ടിയപ്പോൾ കടിച്ചു പോയതാണെന്നും യുക്രെയിൻ തുറന്ന് പറയുന്നുണ്ട്. സൈനിക ഭീമനായ റഷ്യയ്ക്ക് കയ്യേറിയ പ്രദേശം മുഴുവൻ തിരിച്ചുകൊടുക്കേണ്ടി വരുമെന്ന് അവർക്കറിയാം. പക്ഷേ അത്രയും നാൾ റഷ്യയ്ക്ക് അപമാനത്തിൻ്റെ നാളുകളാണ്. ഇസ്രായേൽ ജനതയ്ക്ക് മുമ്പിൽ നെതന്യാഹുവിന് സംഭവിച്ച പ്രതിച്ഛായ ഇടിവ് പുടിന് റഷ്യയിൽ സംഭവിച്ചിട്ടുണ്ട്. പ്രധാന വ്യത്യാസം ഇവിടെ റഷ്യ തന്നെയാണ് അക്രമകാരി എന്നതാണ്. ആയിരത്തിലധികം പരാജിതരായ ശത്രുസൈനികർ യുദ്ധകാലത്ത് അതിർത്തി കടക്കുന്നത് തിരിച്ചറിയാനായില്ലെങ്കിൽ എന്തിനാണ് ഒരു രാജ്യം ഇൻ്റലിജൻസിനെ തീറ്റിപ്പോറ്റുന്നത്?

സമാധാന ചർച്ചയിൽ വിലപേശൽ നടത്താനുള്ള അവസരത്തിന് വേണ്ടിയാണ് റഷ്യയിലെ ആയിരം ചതുരശ്ര കിലോമീറ്ററുകൾ അവർ പിടിച്ചെടുത്തതെന്ന് കരുതാം. സമീപ പ്രദേശമായ ബലഗരോദിലേക്കും യുക്രെയിൻ ആധിപത്യം വ്യാപിക്കുകയാണ്. നൂറിലധികം റഷ്യൻ സൈനികരെ യുദ്ധത്തടവുകാരായി പിടികൂടിയിട്ടുണ്ട്. ആയിരക്കണക്കിന് റഷ്യൻ സിവിലിയൻമാർ സ്വന്തം രാജ്യത്ത് അഭയാർത്ഥി കേന്ദ്രങ്ങളിലേക്ക് മാറിയിരിക്കുകയാണ്. യുദ്ധം റഷ്യയുടെ പടി കടന്നെത്തിയിരിക്കുന്നു.

പുടിൻ കോപം കൊണ്ട് ജ്വലിക്കുന്നുണ്ട്. സിറിയയും യുക്രെയിനുമൊക്കെ നിർദ്ദയമായി ബോംബിട്ട് തകർക്കുന്നത് പോലെ സ്വന്തം രാജ്യം നശിപ്പിക്കാൻ റഷ്യയ്ക്കാവില്ലല്ലോ. അതിർത്തി കടന്നെങ്കിൽ തിരിച്ചിറങ്ങാനുള്ള exit plan യുക്രെയിൻ ആസൂത്രണം ചെയ്തിട്ടുണ്ടാവണം. 2024 ൽ ഇതുവരെ 1300 ചതുരശ്ര കിലോമീറ്റർ ഭൂമിയാണ് റഷ്യ കീഴ്‌പ്പെടുത്തിയെങ്കിൽ കഴിഞ്ഞ ഒരാഴ്ചയ്ക്കുള്ളിലാണ് ആയിരം ചതുരശ്രമീറ്റർ റഷ്യൻ ഭൂമി യുക്രെയിൻ പിടിച്ചെടുത്തത്. റഷ്യ പിടിച്ചെടുത്ത യുക്രെയിൻ ഭൂമി കുറച്ചെങ്കിലും തിരിച്ചുകൊടുത്തു കൊണ്ടുള്ള ചർച്ചയിലേക്ക് കുർസ്ക് ആക്രമണം നയിച്ചാൽ അതൊരു ആശ്വാസമാണ്. പക്ഷേ മറക്കുക, പൊറുക്കുക തുടങ്ങിയ വാക്കുകളൊന്നുമില്ലാത്ത നിഘണ്ടുവാണ് പുടിൻ കൊണ്ടുനടക്കുന്നത്.

Hope is a Woman's Name is the extraordinary story of Amal, who was at five years old a shepherd in the Negev region of Palestine. By her teens, she ran literacy classes for Bedouin women, sparking a lifelong career in organizing and policy change. She built economic empowerment programs, founded an Arab-Jewish school, and created organizations promoting shared society.

Amal builds bridges by embracing every part of her identity—Bedouin, Arab, woman, feminist, Palestinian, and Israeli—ensuring no one is left out.

Mujaheddin ceceni durante l'assedio di Groznyj del 1994-1995.I russi attaccarono la notte di Capodanno, alle 5 di mattina. Nel 1994, alla fine dell'anno si era svolta una dura battaglia per la città, quando dei ceceni pagati da Mosca tentarono un colpo di Stato. I russi ottennero una vittoria di Pirro, ma ben presto dovettero ritirarsi dalla città, per le azioni di guerriglia dei ceceni. I russi, in quell'occasione, fra bombardamenti ed esecuzioni sommarie massacrarono più di 25mila persone.

An Israeli airstrike on a designated humanitarian zone in the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 40 people and injured dozens more, according to Gaza's civil defence authorities. The strike targeted the Mawasi area in Khan Younis, which had been identified by Israel as a humanitarian zone. Local civil defence official Mohammed al-Mughair confirmed the death toll, and both the Hamas-linked Shehab news agency and Fatah-linked Wafa news agency corroborated the reports of 40 fatalities. The impact of the strike caused extensive damage, with over 20 tents catching fire and craters up to nine meters deep left in the area.

In response, the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) stated that the target was a Hamas command centre, accusing Hamas of using human shields within the civilian and humanitarian infrastructure. Hamas denied the presence of its fighters in the area, calling the claims a "blatant lie." The IDF further alleged that Palestinian militant groups have consistently exploited humanitarian zones for terrorist activities against Israel. The incident adds to the escalating conflict, deepening the humanitarian crisis in the region.
Source: AFP, AP, Reuters, dpa

So what
It will be interesting to see what comes of this strike. Numerous commentators online mentioned how abnormal this strike was even for Israel and speculated that the targets must have been important. However, it will likely come at the cost of significant public backlash; even if they can show clear signs that they hit military targets, the general public will likely criticize the strike. Yet it seems like Israel no longer cares about the opinion of the general international community so long as they maintain US support.

Israel continues to massacre Palestinians in Gaza using American bombs supplied by Washington, intensifying accusations of genocide. The Israeli military has deployed powerful US-made munitions to strike a so-called “humanitarian safe zone” in southern Gaza, burying entire families, according to a Geneva-based human rights group.

Early Tuesday, Israeli airstrikes on a refugee tent camp in Khan Younis, located in the al-Mawasi area, resulted in at least 40 Palestinians killed and dozens more injured. This zone had been designated by Israel as a “humanitarian zone” for displaced civilians seeking refuge from the ongoing violence. Gaza’s civil defense service reported that the Israeli bombs created craters as deep as nine meters, devastating the camp.

The Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Monitor confirmed that Israeli warplanes dropped three US-made MK-84 bombs, each weighing 900 kg, on the camp while civilians were sleeping. These bombs were among the more than 14,000 transferred from the US to Israel in 2023 and 2024, according to media reports.

The targeting of civilians coerced into relocating to designated "safe zones" and then bombed during the night highlights America’s direct complicity in what many are calling the Palestinian genocide.

"The bombs caused craters as deep as several meters, burying about 20 tents with families inside," the rights group said. "Many tents, with entire families inside, were buried under the sand."

Euro-Med condemned the global silence, stating that it emboldens Israel to continue its atrocities.

The group further emphasized the role of the US, which provides Israel with the weapons used to kill civilians, labeling America a partner in these crimes.

Minilateralism ,the brand new way to conflict resolution:

Why and how minilateralism ?

Proper implementation of law requires its enforcement and enforcement requires a central superior authority that's not biased nor coerced.Since international law is considered a weak law, as there's no central superior authority nor there's way to strictly prevent a crime or implement a solution for any conflict, as in today's world the Palestine issue.
the perspective of world is now shifting towards the close cooperative conflict resolution as minilateralism.Which ensures that justice is offered to all parties and conflict resolution is rational.

Minilateralism provides a forum to negotiate on mutual interests and future sustainable goals.For instantiation ,the UAE and Indonesia and five other states started an initiative with the name of "Mangrove Alliance for Climate" at COP'27 (conference of parties) in Egypt.QUAD (Quadrilateral security dialogue) is also an example of minilateralism.Quad is a group where big nations are cooperating in a small group.In international arena minilateralism is considered an effective solution as compared to multilateralism to make fruitful negotiations; especially When it comes to disastrous conflicts like Syrian conflict, Palestine conflict , Russo-Ukrainian war and South China sea.

CNN Granted Permission to Appeal Employment Tribunal Decision in Saima Mohsin Case

The Court of Appeal has allowed CNN to proceed with their appeal against an Employment Tribunal's ruling in favor of British-Pakistani journalist Saima Mohsin. Mohsin, who was injured while reporting on the Israel-Palestine conflict in 2014, had her contract terminated by CNN in 2017 after requesting a role adjustment and support during her rehabilitation. Despite undergoing extensive physiotherapy, Mohsin still lives with constant pain, uses a walking stick, and cannot work full-time.

After a polio case was reported in Gaza for the first time in 25 years, a vaccination campaign for children began on Saturday. At Al-Nasr Hospital, Palestinian health workers administered polio drops to children.

The recent conflict between Israel and Hamas began on October 7, following a terrorist attack by Hamas on Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,200 people.

Watching the atrocities being committed on the land of Palestine and on Palestinians, my hands ended up penning down this piece of poetry, which entirely doesn't represent the pain and struggles of Palestinians but is an attempt to comprise a small part of their tale of oppression in the form of a poem. 
Their pain and struggle are known by the entire world, but we all remain helpless. Let's hope and pray for their lives to get better and for peace to finally embrace their land. 🇵🇸

-

On the land of olives, 
Somewhere in the old city its engraved, 
A nation led by the Prophet will not
surrender, 
The history echoes the torture of offenders.
From Alleys of Gaza to grounds of Jerusalem, 
Engulfs the mist filled with resilient squalls,
Tales of oppression moulds in mosaics of minarets and walls.
Even in the ruins of bustling cities,
The hope in people is not forsaken,
The faith in them remains unshaken.
Children inherit the trauma their mothers bore,
Flows the streams of sorrow till shore.
From the refugee camps to watermelon yards,
Threads weave the story of every soul scarred.
An Ice-cream truck to mortuary,
General newspaper to thousand obituaries. 
Hustling city to a rubble, 
Fashioning dreams to watching them crumble.
Abode of families to cemetery, 
Bombed the barren and residuary.
Missiles fall like rain pouring down, 
The smears of innocent blood cover the town.
Endured everything they stand steadfast,
Their hope for freedom and peace outlast.
May solace embrace their land,
Palestinians with courage withstand.

The explainer discusses the impact of Houthi attacks on global trade through the Red Sea, especially following their involvement in the Israel-Palestine conflict that began on October 7th. The Red Sea is highlighted as a crucial global trade route, with significant geopolitical importance due to its connection to the Suez Canal and various strategic straits. 

The Houthi attacks have disrupted trade, particularly affecting shipping companies and various global industries, leading to increased freight costs and delayed shipments.

 Despite these disruptions, the energy sector remains largely unaffected, and the Houthis have not achieved their goal of enforcing a ceasefire in Gaza. 

The situation underscores the evolving geopolitical dynamics in the region, with major global powers involved and the potential for further escalation.

Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17)[b] was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was shot down by Russian-controlled forces[4][5][6][7] on 17 July 2014, while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew were killed.[8] Contact with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was about 50 kilometres (31 mi; 27 nmi) from the Ukraine–Russia border, and wreckage from the aircraft landed near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi; 22 nmi) from the border.[9] The shoot-down occurred during the war in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces.

Alexander Petrovich Barkashov, leader del partito di estrema destra russo Unità Nazionale Russa e del gruppo paramilitare sempre fascista "Esercito Ortodosso Russo". Durante il servizio militare in Bielorussia, durante l'epoca sovietica Barkashov si interessò delle vicende di Gengis Khan e dell'epopea del barone russo Roman Nicolaus von Ungern-Sternber, che durante la guerra civile russa tentò di creare una dittatura lamaista in Asia Centrale. Entrato a far parte dell'organizzazione di estrema destra Paymat ne divenne presto il capo, fondando poi il suo partito Unità Nazionale Russa. Durante la crisi costituzionale del 1993, Barkashov e i suoi si schierarono contro El'cin. Numerosi i suoi contatti con Vladimir Putin, anche se non sono mai apparse foto dei due insieme, durante le rivolte del Donbass nel 2014 Barkashov spedì i suoi dell'Esercito Ortodosso Russo, in aiuto delle milizie separatiste.

04.03.2024 / Toretsk, Donetsk region, Ukraine 

Summary of one of the attempts to evacuate a disabled man named Ivan. It was our last evacuation point for the day. Unfortunately, when we arrived, we couldn’t find the man; the entire area was ablaze and smoldering after recent shelling.

While searching for Ivan, our positions were hit by 3-4 shells, but in dramatic circumstances, we managed to leave the shelled positions. That day, out of three addresses, we were able to evacuate only one person, an elderly woman named Valentin.

🚨 Breaking News: Russia Tightens Internet Grip, Orders Apple to Remove 25 VPN Apps! 🚨

In a significant move, Russia's internet and mass media watchdog, Roskomnadzor, has directed Apple to remove 25 VPN apps from its App Store. This directive targets popular VPNs like NordVPN, Proton VPN, Red Shield VPN, and more, frequently used to access content deemed illegal in Russia. 🇷🇺🔒

This crackdown is part of a broader campaign that has intensified since the Russia-Ukraine conflict began in February 2022. VPNs, vital tools for internet freedom, are now being systematically restricted. Apple confirmed the directive to affected VPN vendors, emphasizing compliance with Russian laws.

Earlier this year, Apple faced a $13.7 million fine from Russia's Federal Antimonopoly Service over market dominance issues. Despite these challenges, Apple's products have played crucial roles in the conflict, with Ukraine's Air Force using iPads for operating modern weapons in older jets.

What do you think about this latest development? Should tech companies comply with such directives? Share your thoughts below! 💬👇

Releasing this month, Hope is a Woman's Name is the extraordinary story of Amal, who was at five years old a shepherd in the Negev region of Palestine. By her teens, she ran literacy classes for Bedouin women, sparking a lifelong career in organizing and policy change. She built economic empowerment programs, founded an Arab-Jewish school, and created organizations promoting shared society. 
Amal builds bridges by embracing every part of her identity—Bedouin, Arab, woman, feminist, Palestinian, and Israeli—ensuring no one is left out.

The United Nations has urgently called for de-escalation as tensions between Israel and Hezbollah continue to rise.

On 25 August, the conflict intensified with Israel launching airstrikes on Hezbollah targets in Lebanon, while Hezbollah responded with a barrage of rocket attacks.

The UN secretary-general, Antonio Guterres, expressed deep concern over the escalating violence, which endangers both Israeli and Lebanese civilians, and threatens regional stability. The UN has emphasised the need for both sides to cease hostilities and adhere to Resolution 1701, which calls for an end to the conflict.

I don't post these here often, as the internal political situation in Israel is too chaotic for most people to understand, let alone people that don't live here, and I get too much hate responses. But I keep going to these protests and documenting them, as the struggle to bring the Israeli hostages back to their family is a moral human obligation that is above all political affairs. It is not a matter of sides or party. It is not a matter of pro- or anti- or whatever. It is a basic demand to let innocent people out of captivity after 10 months. 
In the 4th photo meet Einav Zangauker, mother of 24 years old hostage Matan. Every Saturday she is there. Screaming. Fighting. You can tell she is barely sleeping. Going crazy without knowing anything about her son's medical and mental situation. And tens of thousands  Israelis surround her and the hostages families. Calling for an immediate hostage deal and ceasefire. For 324 agonizing days now.

The young cook takes advantage of every opportunity to connect to the internet, which sometimes requires walking several hours to find coverage.

He went from visiting restaurants on the Strip to cooking for displaced families. From receiving food from local businesses and providing food reviews to watching humanitarian aid sacks parachute from the sky – since Israel limits the entry of goods by land and sea.

The UAE  have successfully mediated in the 180 prisoner trade between Russia and Ukraine, which is a significant diplomatic victory. This is the UAE’s sixth such involvement since the beginning of 2024, underscoring the crucial role that the country plays in promoting peace and cooperation in conflict areas.

The UAE Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that the UAE’s essential connections and organisations with both Russia and Ukraine have been shown by its most recent involvement. By using its unique relationships with all parties, the UAE has emerged as a trustworthy mediator, well-suited to facilitate communication and dialogue between the competitors.

The UAE has played a crucial role in  prisoner transfers between Russia and Ukraine since the beginning of 2024. These initiatives reflect the UAE’s commitment to helping norms, relieving tension, and promoting peace. The international community has acknowledged and appreciated the nation’s proactive dedication to intervention procedures.
